questions.question: What was the former name of the Yamuna Expressway Project constructed in Uttar Pradesh, India?
questions.explanation: Taj Expressway. It is presently India's 3rd longest expressway since February 2017.

questions.question: Which of the following is the first six-lane expressway in India?
questions.explanation: Mumbai Pune Expressway. Purvanchal Expressway (Lucknow- Ghazipur).Yamuna Expressway (Noida to Agra).

questions.question: The Barabati Fort is situated in the city of.
questions.explanation: Cuttack. More Forts in Odisha: Chudanga Gada Fort (Bhubaneswar), Raibania Fort (Baleswar district), Sisupalgarh Fort (Bhubaneswar), Asurgarh Fort (Kalahandi district), Potagarh Fort. Gulbarga Fort - Karnataka. Q.2069. The aviation sector was inaugurated in India in the year _____ with the establishment of Tata Airlines. SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Morning) (a) 1925 (b) 1932 (c) 1929 (d) 1935 Sol.2069.(b) 1932 . The airline, founded by J.R.D Tata, started as an airmail carrier within India after winning a contract with Imperial Airways. The airline flew its inaugural flight in October 1932, flying from Karachi to Mumbai. Q.2070. Who among the following founded the ‘Shillong Chamber Choir’ ? SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Morning) (a) Neil Nongkynrih (b) Madhup Mudgal (c) Debashish Chaudhuri (d) António Fortunato de Figueiredo Sol.2070.(a) Neil Nongkinrih. The Shillong Chamber Choir, established in 2001, is a multi-genre choir, which won the reality TV show India's Got Talent in 2010.

questions.question: In which year was the ‘Lotteries Regulation Act’ passed?
questions.explanation: 1998. The Lotteries Regulation Act, 1998 is an important piece of legislation that lays down thorough guidelines for the central government to conduct lotteries in India.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indigenous dairy breed of cattle?
questions.explanation: Red Sindhi is a reputed heat tolerant milch cattle breed originating from Sindh province of Pakistan. The Chippiparai is a breed of sighthound from Tamil Nadu in southern India. The Kanni is a rare indigenous South Indian sighthound breed of dog. The Kombai or Polygar dog is a breed of sighthound native to Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: ______ is one of the languages in which the denomination is printed on the reverse of a contemporary Indian currency note.
questions.explanation: Nepali. Sinhala, is an Indo - Aryan language primarily spoken by the Sinhalese people of Sri Lanka.

questions.question: Who among the following was a saint from Maharashtra?
questions.explanation: Chokhamela. Dadu Dayal was a poet - saint from Gujarat. Q.2075. For which of the following productions is the Ramagundam power plant famous ? SSC MTS 18/10/2021 (Evening) (a) hydroelectricity (b) nuclear energy (c) thermal energy (d) Bio-gas Sol.2075.(c) Thermal energy. Ramagundam power plant - It is part of the National Thermal Power Corporation, a 2600 MW power station located in Ramagundam, Telangana.

questions.question: Which of the following is the name of the spacecraft developed by SpaceX for NASA’s manned mission to the International Space Station?
questions.explanation: Crew Dragon is the name of the spacecraft developed by SpaceX for NASA’s manned mission to the International Space Station. NASA headquarters is in Washington DC.

questions.question: Which is the national heritage animal of India?
questions.explanation: Elephant (2010). Project Elephant (PE) was launched by the Government of India in the year 1992.

questions.question: Unique Transaction Reference number is a ______ character code used to uniquely identify a transaction in the RTGS system.
questions.explanation: 22. Unique Transaction Reference number used to uniquely identify a transaction in the RTGS system. It is used to identify a specific bank transaction in India. All banks in India use UTR numbers for all types of money transfers.

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of Homeopathy?
questions.explanation: Samuel Hahnemann espoused the law of cure known as "Similia Similibus Curentur", or "Like Cures Like".

questions.question: SIMBEX is a military exercise conducted between the defense forces of which of the following nations?
questions.explanation: India and Singapore. India and Thailand (Maitree, CORPAT), India and the US (Vajra Prahar, Yudh Abhyas), India and Sri Lanka (Mitra Shakti).

questions.question: Who among the following is the founder of the field of psychoanalysis?
questions.explanation: Sigmund Freud. Carl Jung - Founded analytical psychology. Kai T Erikson - specializing in the social consequences of catastrophic events. Jean Piaget - Worked on child development.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest sea bird with the longest wingspan?
questions.explanation: Wandering Albatross. The maximum dimensions in this species are a length of 1.44 m (4.7 ft) and a wingspan of 3.65 m (12.0 ft).

questions.question: ‘Oolong’ is a variant of ______.
questions.explanation: Tea. Oolong - It is a traditional semi-oxidized Chinese tea. It is made from the leaves of the Camellia Sinensis plant. The same plant is used to make Green tea and Black tea. Q.2084. Hakki, Pikki and Siddi are _________ from Karnataka. SSC CHSL 12/04/2021 (Morning) (a) language (b) Theater form (c) Music type (d) dance form Sol.2084.(a) Language. These languages ​are critically endangered in Karnataka. Hakki, Pikki and Siddi is a mix of Konkani, Kannada and Hindi. Kannada is the official language of Karnataka.

questions.question: In which year was the Marine Products Export Development Authority (MPEDA) established in India?
questions.explanation: 1972. The Marine Products Export Development Authority (MPEDA) is a statutory body that was established under the Ministry of Commerce and Industry for the promotion of the export of marine products from India.

questions.question: Since 2000, Euro norms are followed in India under the name ______ Stage Emission Standards for four wheeled vehicles.
questions.explanation: Bharat. Vehicle emission norms were introduced in India in 1991 for petrol and in 1992 for diesel vehicles.

questions.question: When was the Editors Guild of India founded?
questions.explanation: 1978. It was established with the twin objectives of protecting press freedom and raising the standards of editorial leadership of newspapers and magazines.

questions.question: Where was the first factory of the Indian Iron and Steel Company (IISCO) set up?
questions.explanation: Hirapur. IISCO Steel Plant of Steel Authority of India Limited is an integrated steel plant located at Hirapur (later to be called Burnpur) in the Asansol subdivision of Paschim Bardhaman district, West Bengal.

questions.question: Where is the Rumi Darwaza located?
questions.explanation: Lucknow. It is an imposing gateway that was built by Nawab Asaf-Ud-Daula in 1784. Q.2090. In the context of forest conservation, Navadanya Movement was founded in 1987 by ______. SSC CPO 23/11/2020 (Evening) (a) Medha Patkar (b) Vandana Shiva (c) Baba Amte (d) Pandurang Hegde Sol.2090.(b) Vandana Shiva. Navdanya is an Indian-based non-governmental organization that promotes biodiversity conservation, biodiversity, organic farming, the rights of farmers, and the process of seed saving.

questions.question: How many windows are there on the outside walls of Hawa Mahal of Jaipur?
questions.explanation: 953. Hawa Mahal of Jaipur was designed by Lal Chand Ustad.

questions.question: In which color are the railway lines and telephone lines shown in the topographic map?
questions.explanation: Black - Railroads, boundaries, telephone lines. Brown - Topographic contours. Blue - Lakes, streams, irrigation ditches and other hydrographic features Red - Land grids and important roads.

questions.question: Which of the following was previously known as 'the Lady Willingdon Park'.
questions.explanation: Lodhi Garden. Lady Willingdon Park was inaugurated in April 1936.

questions.question: Which ISO certification pertains to Environmental Management Systems?
questions.explanation: 14001. ISO 22000 - It is an international standard for food safety established by the International Organization for Standardization. Q.2095. Who designed the logo for Lokpal in India? SSC CGL 09/03/2020 (Morning) (a) Deepak Punia (b) Prashant Mishra (c) Kamareddy (d) B.P.Raju Sol.2095.(b) Prashant Mishra. The logo of Lokpal: LOK - people and PAL - caretaker, i.e. "caretaker of people”. History History Ancient History

questions.question: With which of the following relief sculptures were the walls of the great Stupa of Amaravati in the Lower Godavari region adorned?
questions.explanation: Bas relief. The Amaravati school of art flourished under the patronage of the Satavahanas in the Andhra region. Nagarjunkonda, another notable site, is renowned for its Buddhist architecture.

questions.question: Select the correct alternative on the given statements based on Ashoka's Lion capital and India's State Emblem. Statement I: In the original Ashoka's Lion Capital, there are four lions mounted back- to-back on a circular abacus that itself rests on a bell-shaped lotus. Statement II: The State Emblem is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Asoka at Sarnath in which the bell-shaped lotus was omitted.

options.b: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
options.c: Neither Statement I nor Statement II is true.

questions.explanation: Both Statement I and statement II are true. The Lion Capital of Ashoka, carved around 250 BCE, is the head of a column erected by Emperor Ashoka at Sarnath, near Varanasi, India. Ashoka, the 3rd ruler of the Mauryan Empire (c. 268–232 BCE), governed a vast territory that stretched from present-day Afghanistan to Bangladesh, with Pataliputra as its capital.

questions.question: Sun temple at Modhera was built by which of the following rulers?
questions.explanation: Raja Bhimdev I. He was a Chaulukya king who ruled parts of present-day Gujarat, India. The Sun Temple of Modhera, dedicated to the solar deity Surya, is located in Modhera village, Mehsana district, Gujarat, on the bank of the river Pushpavati. Q.176. Kautilya has mentioned the concept of Saptanga Rajya to understand the State with seven organs and one of them is Danda, which means: SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning) (a) Ministers (b) Ally (c) Fort (d) Force Sol.176.(d) Force. Kautilya, also known as Chanakya, outlined the Saptanga theory of the state in the Arthashastra, identifying seven key components: Swami (King), Amatya (Minister), Janapada (Territory), Durga (Fort), Kosa (Treasure), Danda (Army or Force), and Mitra (Ally). Q.177. The Dhakeshwari Temple in present day Bangladesh has been constructed under the rule of which dynasty? SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning) (a) Chandela (b) Parmara (c) Rashtrakuta (d) Sena Sol.177.(d) Sena. The National Temple of Bangladesh is the Dhakeshwari Temple, located in the capital, Dhaka. Dhakeshwari means "Goddess of Dhaka" and was built in the 12th century by King Ballal Sen of the Sena dynasty.

questions.question: Nataraja represents the dancing figure of which Hindu deity?
questions.explanation: Shiva. Nataraja is a depiction of Shiva performing the cosmic dance of creation and destruction, known as the Tandava, while surrounded by flames. Q.179. The excavated ruins of the Nalanda University indicate that bright red _____ was/were used in its construction. SSC MTS 18/10/2024 (1st Shift) (a) stone (b) bricks (c) granite(d) marble Sol.179.(b) bricks. The Ancient Nalanda University was founded by Kumaragupta I. Nalanda University was destroyed in 1193 CE by Bakhtiyar Khilji, a Turkish military general. The Chinese scholars I-Qing and Xuan Zang visited Nalanda in the 7th century CE. The ancient Nalanda was a centre of learning from the 5th century CE to 12th century CE. Located in present day Rajgir, Bihar.

questions.question: The Dravidian style of temple architecture can be largely seen from which part of India?
questions.explanation: Southern India. Dravidian style of temple Features: Vimana, Shikhara, Gopurams. Hindu temples can be characterised under broad categories - Nagara Style (northern India), Dravida, and Vesara style (combination of both Nagara and Dravida, its superstructure is bell-shaped). Q.470. Diwan-I-Am, containing the marble canopy ornamented with beautiful panels of pietra dura work, is a part of which monument? SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Bibi ka Makbara (b) Red Fort (c) Taj Mahal (d) Humayun Tomb Sol.470.(b) Red Fort. The Diwan-i-Am (Hall of Public Audience) is part of the Red Fort in Delhi. It is a significant structure that was used by the Mughal emperors for public meetings. Pietra dura is an Italian term that refers to a decorative art technique of inlaying cut, polished, colored stones into marble or other hard surfaces to create images.

questions.question: Which red and buff sandstone is the tallest tower in India built in the thirteenth century?
questions.explanation: Qutub Minar (Delhi). It has a diameter of 14.32 m at the base and about 2.75 m on the top with a height of 72.5 m. Qutbu'd-Din Aibak laid the foundation of Minar in AD 1199. Q.472. Which of the following statements is/are correct temples of Khajuraho? a) Equal importance is given to human experience and spiritual pursuit. History b) Jain and Hindu temples are also found at Khajuraho. c) Chausanth Yogini temple is one of the important temples here. SSC MTS 11/11/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) All a, b and c (b) Only a and b (c) Only c and a (d) Only b and c Sol.472.(a) All a, b and c. Khajuraho’s temples are also known for their extensive erotic sculptures. Khajuraho’s sculptures are highly stylised with typical features. Notable examples include the Kandariya Mahadeo temple, dedicated to Lord Shiva, and the Lakshmana temple, dedicated to Vishnu. Q.473. The title of ‘Chief of the Merchants’ or ‘Malikut-Tujjar’ was conferred on Mahmud Gawan by which of the following Bahamani kings ? SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Mohammad Shah (b) Humayun Shah (c) NizamuddinAhmad III (d) Bahman Shah Sol.473.(b) Humayun Shah. Mahmud Gawan (Khawaja Mahmud Gilani), a Persian trader who arrived in Deccan, rose to prominence in the Bahmani kingdom. Under Humayun Shah's reign, he was appointed as Prime Minister with complete control over military affairs and received the title 'Malik-ut-Tujjar' (Chief of Merchants).

questions.question: Match the following books with their respective authors. Book Author a) Tajul Ma'asir i) Yahya bin Ahmad Sirhimdi b) Khazain-ul Futuh ii) Hasan Nizami c) Tarikh-i-Firuzshahi iii) Ziauddin Barani d) Tarikh-i- Mubarakshahi iv) Amir Khusrav
questions.explanation: a-ii; b-iv; c-iii; d-i. Some other ancient books and their authors : ‘Akbar-Namah’ - Abul Fazal, ‘Buddhacharita’ - Ashvaghosha, ‘Prithviraj Raso’ - Chand Bardai, ‘Geet Govinda’ - Jaidev, ‘Rajtarangini’ - Kalhana, ‘Kumarasambhavam’ - Kalidasa, ‘Ashtadhyayi’ - Panini, and ‘Mahabhasya’ - Patanjali. Q.475. According to which of the following foreign travellers, people of Delhi used to write letters containing abuses to the Sultan, therefore, in order to punish them Sultan decided to shift the capital? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Isami (b) Hasan Nizami (c) Ibn Batuta (d) Al Biruni Sol.475.(c) Ibn Battuta, a traveler from Morocco, authored a book of travels called Rihla, which is written in Arabic and provides rich and fascinating details about the social and cultural life in the subcontinent during the 14th century. Muhammad Bin Tughlaq was the ruler of the Delhi sultanate when Ibn Batuta came to India. The Sultan was impressed by his scholarship, and appointed him the qazi or judge of Delhi.

questions.question: Chand Bardai’s famous literary work ________, mentions Prithviraj Chauhan‘s love story and heroic deeds.
questions.explanation: Prithviraj Raso. It is a Braj language epic poem about the life of Prithviraj Chauhan. Other Ancient Books and Authors : ‘Ain-i-Akbari’ - Abul Fazl, ‘Mahabharata’ - Vyasa, ‘Ramayana’ - Valmiki, ‘Shakuntala’ - Kalidasa, and ‘Mudrarakshas’ - Vishakhadatta.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers built five astronomical observatories at different places in north India?
questions.explanation: Sawai Jaisingh II founded the city of Jaipur on 18 November 1727 AD. He was appointed the Subedar (governor) of Agra in 1722. He established five Jantar Mantar observatories, located in Delhi, Jaipur, Ujjain, Mathura, and Varanasi.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties’ genealogy was found in the Bijolia inscription?
questions.explanation: Chahamana. Bijoliya Inscription reveals that Chauhans are Vats Gotriya Brahman. This inscription provides information about the names of Jabalipur, Shakmbhari, Srimal. An inscription of Vikram Samvat Falgun Krishna Tritiya is inscribed on a rock near the northern wall of the ancient Parshvanath temple located in Bijolia.

questions.question: Who was the founder of the Bahmani Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Hasan Bahman Shah founded the Bahmani Sultanate in 1347. Its capital was Ahsanabad (Gulbarga) from 1347 to 1425, later shifted to Muhammadabad (Bidar). Q.480. Which State was founded by Nizam-ul-Mulk in 1724? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Mysore (b) Hyderabad (c) Bengal (d) Awadh Sol.480.(b) Hyderabad. Nizam-ul-Mulk Asaf Jah (Chin Qilich Khan) was one of the most powerful members at the court of the Mughal Emperor Farrukh Siyar. He was entrusted first with the governorship of Awadh, and later given charge of the Deccan.

questions.question: Under the Bahmani kingdom, the provinces were administered by_______
questions.explanation: Tarafdars. The Bahmani Kingdom, established in by Ala-ud-din Hassan Bahman Shah after revolting against the Delhi Sultanate. It was divided into four administrative regions known as "taraf." These regions included Daulatabad, Bidar, Berar, and Gulbarga, each governed by a tarafdar or subedar. Q.482. Who among the following is known as Tuti-e-Hind ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift) (a) Surdas (b) Tansen (c) Amir Khusro (d) Naubat Khan Sol.482.(c) Amir Khusro is one of India's greatest Persian-language poets. His books - Tughlaq Nama, Khazain-ul-Fatuh. Other writers: Surdas - Sur Sagar, Sur-Saravali. Tansen - Tashrih-ul-moosiqui.

questions.question: Which of the following forts was built by Raja Rai Singh in 1588?
questions.explanation: Junagarh Fort. It is located in Bikaner, Rajasthan. It was originally called Chintamani and later renamed to mean "Old Fort." Amer Fort: It is situated History in Amer near Jaipur, was initially built by Raja Man Singh and expanded by Sawai Jai Singh. Kumbhalgarh Fort: It is located in Rajsamand district, was constructed by Rana Kumbha in the 15th century, with chief architect Mandan showcasing his style in Raja Vallabh.

questions.question: After the breakup of the Bahmani kingdom, how many independent states arose?
questions.explanation: 5. After the death of Muhammad Shah-III (ruler) in 1482, the Kingdom was disintegrated into five kingdoms: Bijapur, Ahmednagar, Bera, Golconda and Bidar. Q.485. Who among the following Bahmani sultans transferred his capital from Gulbarga to Bidar? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning) (a) Ahmad Shah (b) Humayun (c) Mujahid Shah (d) Firuz Shah Sol.485.(a) Ahmad Shah (1422-1435). Bahmani sultanate was established by Alauddin Hasan Bahman Shah (Zafar Khan) in 1347. Bahmani kingdom comprises the parts of the current day’s Karnataka, Maharashtra, and Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Europeans entered India with a mindset of trading only. This streak was initiated by which of the following European nations ?
questions.explanation: Portuguese - They were the first Europeans to come to India by Sea routes in 1498, led by Vasco da Gama at Calicut (Kerala). European nations arrived in India after Portuguese: Dutch, English, Danish, and French. The Portuguese were also the last to leave India in 1961.

questions.question: Who succeeded Alivardi Khan as Nawab of Bengal ?
questions.explanation: Siraj-ud-Daulah (Reign: 1756 -1757) - Last independent Nawab of Bengal. Alivardi Khan - Nawab of Bengal from 1740 to 1756. He is known for his victory during the battle of Burdwan against Maratha Empire during the Maratha invasion of Bengal. Mir Qasim - Nawab of Bengal (1760-1763).

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT pair of a famous minaret and its construction year in India.
questions.explanation: Char Minar–1664 CE. It was built by Sultan Mohammed Quli Qutb Shah in 1591. It was built in honour of his wife, Bhagmati in Hyderabad. Shaheed Minar: It was built in the memory of Major-general Sir David Ochterlony, commander of the British East India Company.

questions.question: What did the term 'bhoga' refer to during the medieval period?
questions.explanation: Revenue Assignment. Other Type of Tax : Kara - It was a generic term used for taxes. Hiranya - Tax on special produce taken in cash. Chat - Security Tax. Prataya -Toll Tax.

questions.question: Joseph Francois Dupleix was the Governor General of which of the following East India companies in India?
questions.explanation: French (Last European to arrive in India). Governor-General Dupleix was appointed in 1742. French East India Company : Established in - 1664. The First French Factory - Surat (1668), Second Factory - Masulipatam (1669), Headquarters - Pondicherry. Europeans in India - Portuguese (1498), Dutch (1602), British (1608), Danes (1616).

questions.question: Rajaram was the leader of which of the following revolts against the Mughlas?
questions.explanation: Jat revolt (Mathura). In 1669 CE against Aurangzeb. Satnami revolt (1672) - The Satnamis were a sect comprising peasants, artisans and untouchables who rebelled against the Aurangzeb in Narnaul (Haryana). Bundela Rebellion (1842) - Jawahar Singh Bundela of Chandrapur and Madhukar Shah of Narhat were the leaders of the revolt.

questions.question: Who composed 'Shahnama" ?
questions.explanation: Ferdowsi (Court poet of Mahmud of Ghazni) - A Persian poet and the author of Shahnameh ("Book of Kings''), which is one of the world's longest epic poems created by a single poet, and the greatest epic of Persian-speaking countries. Q.493. Malik Ambar, who resisted Mughals in Deccan, was an able administrator of which state? SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Bidar (b) Bijapur (c) Golconda (d) Ahmednagar Sol.493.(d) Ahmednagar. Malik Ambar was an African-origin statesman and military leader who served as the regent of the Nizam Shahi dynasty in the Deccan, of Ahmednagar (now part of Maharashtra).

questions.question: The Imadshahi family was known for the foundation of which state?
questions.explanation: Berar (Maharashtra). Imad Shahi Dynasty: Established by - Fathullah Imad Ul Mulk (1490). He fortified Gavilgad and Narnala. Berar Sultanate was annexed by Sultan Murtaza Shah of Ahmednagar Kingdom in 1574. Capital - Ellichpur.

questions.question: In the 15th century, a text called _____ is ascribed popularly to Lochan Kavi.
questions.explanation: Raag Tarangini - Initiated an alternative system of the division of rags, 'the Thaat system'. Lochan Kavi (Lochan Panḍit) belonged to the Mithila region (Bihar). “Sangeet Darpan” was written by Damodar Pandit. “Anup Rag Vilas” is written by Kumar Gandharva.

questions.question: Who founded the independent State of Bengal?
questions.explanation: Murshid Quli Khan (Zamin Ali Quli) was born as Surya Narayan Mishra; the first Nawab of Bengal (1717 to 1727). He built the Katra Masjid (1723-1724) where he was buried after his death.

questions.question: Who among the following was the first principal of the Bengal National College started in 1906 ?
questions.explanation: Aurobindo Ghose was an Indian philosopher, yogi, poet, and nationalist. He also worked as a journalist, editing newspapers such as Bande Mataram. The Alipore Bomb Case, also known as the Muraripukur Conspiracy or Manicktolla Bomb Conspiracy, was a significant criminal trial in India in 1908, involving several Indian nationalists. Q.848. When was the All Bengal Students Conference held in the chairmanship of Jawaharlal Nehru? SSC MTS 01/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) 1928 (b) 1939 (c) 1934 (d) 1920 Sol.848.(a) 1928. All Bengal Students Conference - It was organized in response to the expulsion of students from Kolkata colleges for "unruly conduct" and the subsequent student protests. The conference led to the formation of the All-Bengal Students Association to unite and organize students across the region. Q.849. In 1927, where was the conference against colonial oppression and imperialism, in which Jawaharlal History Nehru participated on behalf of Indian National Congress, held? SSC MTS 29/10/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Bruges (b) Leuven (c) Antwerp (d) Brussels Sol.849.(d) Brussels. Pt. Jawaharlal Nehru became General Secretary of the All India Congress Committee in 1923. In 1926, he toured several countries, including Belgium, where he attended the Congress of Oppressed Nationalities in 1927. He also participated in the 10th anniversary of the October Revolution in Moscow. At the 1927 Madras Congress, Nehru advocated for full independence.

questions.question: What is the year of foundation of the Women’s Indian Association (WIA)?
questions.explanation: 1917. Women’s Indian Association, a heritage welfare organization of the women by the women for the women. It was formed on 8th May 1917 at Adyar, Chennai by Annie Besent. It was the first organization to create an overall awakening among women and to train them to shoulder their responsibility in public services.

questions.question: Which of the following national leaders of India inaugurated the first Akhil Bhartiya Kalidas Samman Samaroh held in Ujjain in 1958?
questions.explanation: Rajendra Prasad. The Akhil Bharatiya Kalidas Samaroh is an annual cultural festival held in Ujjain, Madhya Pradesh, since 1958, celebrating the works of poet Kalidasa. Q.852. Who became the Nawab of Bengal after the death of Alivardi Khan in the year 1756? SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Shuja-Ud-Daulah (b) Siraj-Ud-Daulah (c) Saadat Ali Khan (d) Wazir Ali Sol.852.(b) Siraj-Ud-Daulah. Following Alivardi Khan's death in 1756, Sirajuddaulah became Nawab of Bengal but faced conflict with the British, who aimed to install a puppet ruler.

questions.question: On which of the following dates did the British Empire transfer its powers to the Constituent Assembly in India?
questions.explanation: 15th August. India gained independence from British rule on August 15, 1947, ending nearly two centuries of colonial control. The transfer of power also led to the partition, creating India and Pakistan.

questions.question: Who among the following has authored the play ‘Nil Darpan’ ?
questions.explanation: Dinabandhu Mitra. Nil Darpan is a Bengali-language play written in 1858-59 by Dinabandhu Mitra, depicting the oppression of indigo farmers by British planters in Bengal. His other works include ‘Nabin Tapasvini’, ‘Biye Pagla Budo’, ‘Sadhabar Ekadashi’, and ‘Kamale Kamini’. Other authors and their works : Sarojini Naidu - ‘The Golden Threshold’, ‘The Bird of Time’. Chittaranjan Das - ‘India for Indians’, ‘Freedom Through Disobedience’. Q.855. Who among the following freedom fighters of India is the author of the book, 'The Indian Struggle' ? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Mahatma Gandhi (b) Motilal Nehru (c) Vallabhbhai Patel (d) Subhas Chandra Bose Sol.855.(d) Subhas Chandra Bose. His Books : An Indian Pilgrim, Jaruri Kichu Lekha, Famous Speeches and Letters of Subhas Chandra Bose. Q.856. Which of the following books is INCORRECTLY paired with its respective author? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Hind Swaraj – Mahatma Gandhi (b) Gitanjali – Rabindranath Tagore (c) The Discovery of India – Subhash Chandra Bose (d) Why I am an Atheist – Bhagat Singh Sol.856.(c) ‘’The Discovery of India’’ is a book by Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.question: Match the following institutes with their respective founders of British India. Institutes Their respective founders a. Asiatic Society of Bengal i. Warren Hastings b. Sanskrit College of Benaras ii. Lord Wellesley c. Fort William College iii. Jonathan Duncan d. Calcutta Madrasa iv. Sir William Jones
questions.explanation: A-iv, B-iii, C-ii, D-i.

questions.question: In which of the following areas did the Uprising of Khurda in 1817 take place?
questions.explanation: Odisha. The Khurda Revolt of 1817 was an armed uprising against the British, sparked by the rapid and disruptive changes introduced by the East India Company, which agitated the local population. This revolt also impacted other districts of Odisha, such as Cuttack. It is also known as the Paika Rebellion or Paika Bidroha, and it was led by Bakshi Jagabandhu.

questions.question: Where was the Hindu College established in the year 1791?
questions.explanation: Benaras. The Hindu College was founded by Jonathan Duncan, a British officer, and Raja Rameshwar Singh, the Maharaja of Banaras. The college was originally known as the Sanskrit College, and it was dedicated to the study of Sanskrit language and literature. In 1958, the Sanskrit College became a university and was renamed Sampurnanand Sanskrit University in 1974. Raja Ram Mohan Roy established the Hindu College in Calcutta in 1817, which is now known as Presidency University, Kolkata.

questions.question: In 1936, The Independent Labour Party was founded by _______.
questions.explanation: BR Ambedkar was an Indian jurist and social reformer who served as the first Minister of Law and Justice and was the chief architect of the Constitution of India. He was awarded the Bharat Ratna posthumously in 1990. Organizations and Founders: Swatantra Shramik Party (B.R. Ambedkar), Swarajya Party (Motilal Nehru and Chittaranjan Das), Muslim League (Agha Khan & Salimullah), Indian National Congress (A.O.Hume).

questions.question: When was the All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) established?
questions.explanation: 1920. All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) was formed in Bombay. The AITUC was a broad-based organisation involving diverse ideologies. The main ideological groups were the communists led by S.A. Dange and M.N. Roy, the moderates led by M. Joshi and V.V. Giri and the nationalists which involved people like Lala Lajpat Rai and Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.question: Who founded the Theosophical Society in New York in 1875?

options.a: Naoroji Furdunji and Satyendra Nath Bose
options.b: Baba Dayal Das and Madan Lal
options.d: Madame HP Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott

questions.explanation: Madame HP Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott. The Theosophical Society, emphasized the study of ancient Hindu, Buddhist, and Zoroastrian philosophies. It advocated for universal brotherhood based on principles from the Upanishads and Vedas. Annie Besant joined the society in 1889 and first came to India on 16 November 1893. Its headquarters in India was established in Adyar, Madras (now Chennai). Ramabai Ranade and G. K. Devadhar were both founders of the Poona Seva Sadan.

questions.question: What gave a major impetus to the cotton textile industry in India after Independence?

options.b: Export of raw cotton to England

questions.explanation: Swadeshi movement. The Swadeshi movement, led by Gandhiji, aimed to promote self-sufficiency by boycotting British goods and encouraging Indian-made products. India's first cotton mill, the Bombay Spinning and Weaving Company, was established in Mumbai on July 7, 1854. The world’s first cotton mill, the Upper Priory Cotton Mill, was founded by Lewis Paul and John Wyatt in Birmingham, England, in 1741. Q.864. ________ is one of the first criticism of the caste system written by Mahatma Phule and published in the year 1873. SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd shift) (a) Jati ka Unmoolan (b) Bharat Mein Jaati Evam Prajaati (c) Gulami Ki Kahani (d) Gulamgiri Sol.864.(d) Gulamgiri (Marathi Language), also known as Slavery, summarizes the sufferings of lower-caste people and is written in Marathi. Phule formed the Satyashodhak Samaj in 1873. He, together with his wife Savitribai Phule, opened a girls' school in Poona.

questions.question: In his ‘Drain of Wealth’ argument, who among the following stated that Britain was completely draining India?
questions.explanation: Dadabhai Naoroji - He was known as the "Grand Old Man of India”. He introduced thе 'drain thеory' in his rеnownеd book "Povеrty and thе Un-British Rulе in India”.

questions.question: Who is the author of the Indian national anthem?
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore. He wrote the Indian national anthem, "Jana Gana Mana" in Bengali in 1911, and it was officially adopted as the national anthem of India on January 24, 1950. Q.867. Which Commission drew the boundary line between India and Pakistan? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift) (a) Radcliffe Boundary Commission (b) Gandhi Irwin Pact (c) Hilton Young Commission (d) Bretton woods Commission Sol.867.(a) Radcliffe Boundary Commission. The "Radcliffe Line" became the border between India and Pakistan the partition of India on 17 August 1947. The Border Commission headed by Sir Cyril Radcliffe. Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931 - 32) was an agreement between Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin. The Hilton Young Commission (1926) recommended the establishment of the 'Reserve Bank of India'. The Bretton Woods Committee (BWC in 1944) created two organizations - the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank.

questions.question: Which British colonel is remembered as the Butcher of Amritsar for his role in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in 1919 ?
questions.explanation: Reginald Dyer. The Jallianwala Bagh massacre (Amritsar massacre) took place on April 13, 1919 (spring festival of Baisakhi) in Punjab. It happened under the rule of Lt. Governor of Punjab, Michael O’Dwyer, and viceroy of India, Lord Chelmsford. People gathered there to protest against the Rowlatt Act and arrests of pro-Indian independence leaders Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew and Dr. Satya Pal.

questions.question: Vasco da Gama, who discovered the sea route from Europe to India, belonged to which nation?
questions.explanation: Portugal. Vasco da Gama arrived in India at Calicut (Kozhikode) in 1498 AD during the reign of the Zamorin, a Hindu ruler. This event marked the discovery of the sea route from Europe to India. He reached India by sea via the "Cape of Good Hope". Francisco de Almeida was appointed as the first Portuguese governor in India. His policy is known for implementing the "Policy of Blue Water," which aimed to establish Portuguese dominance in maritime trade. Q.870. Tattvabodhini Patrika promoted the study of India’s past in which language? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Sanskrit (b) Hindi (c) English (d) Bengali Sol.870.(d) Bengali. Tattvabodhini Patrika was a Bengali monthly that started publishing from Calcutta (now Kolkata) in 1843 as a mouthpiece of Debendranath Tagore's Tattvabodhini Sabha.

questions.question: Who among the following stated in 1902, India was not ruled for its benefit, but rather for the benefit of its conquerors?
questions.explanation: Annie Besant first came to India on 16 November 1893. She joined the Theosophical Society in May 1889 History and founded a weekly newspaper, Commonweal, in January 1914 for her political work. Other personalities and their quotes: Bal Gangadhar Tilak - Swaraj is my birthright, and I shall have it. Lala Lajpat Rai - The shots that hit me are the last nails to the coffin of British rule in India.

questions.question: Sanskrit College at Benaras was founded by ________
questions.explanation: Jonathan Duncan. The Sanskrit College at Varanasi was established in 1791. The Hindu College (now Presidency University) in Kolkata was founded in 1817.

questions.question: Who designed India Gate, also called the All-India War Memorial?
questions.explanation: Edwin Lutyens (an English architect). Other buildings designed by him: Rashtrapati Bhavan, India Gate, The Cenotaph Whitehall (London). The Old Parliament of India was also designed by Herbert Baker and Lutyens. The foundation stone of India Gate was laid by His Royal Highness, the Duke of Connaught in 1921.

questions.question: Who was the political guru of Subhash Chandra Bose?
questions.explanation: Chittaranjan Das (Deshbandhu).

questions.question: The name of the Brahmin priest who later came to be known as Ramakrishna Paramahansa is:
questions.explanation: Gadadhar Chattopadhyay.

questions.question: When did the Drafting Committee publish the first draft of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: February 1948. Drafting committee : Formed - 29 August 1947, Chairman - Dr. BR Ambedkar Total member - 7.

questions.question: The All India Forward Bloc was founded by_______in 1939 after resigning from the Congress Presidentship
questions.explanation: Subhash Chandra Bose. All India Forward Bloc was a Political Party formed on May 3, 1939 in Makur Unnao, Uttar Pradesh. Its formation was announced in Calcutta.

questions.question: Who was the first Indian to qualify for Covenanted service?
questions.explanation: Satyendra Nath Tagore Qualified in 1863. Indian Services Act, reserved certain positions for covenanted civil servants. It was enacted in during Lord Canning's Viceroyalty. Charles Cornwallis is known as ‘the father of Civil services in India’. Q.879. The Hindu Mahasabha was founded as a response to muslim fundamentalism in which Year? SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 3rd shift) (a) 1917 (b) 1915 (c) 1925 (d) 1910 Sol.879.(b) 1915. Hindu Mahasabha (Founder - Madan Mohan Malaviya) First All India Hindu Mahasabha Conference - Haridwar (1915). In 1930, it emerged as a distinct party under the leadership of Vinayak Damodar Savarkar. Prominent Leaders - Lala Lajpat Rai, Navin Chandra Rai, Radha Mohan Das Agarwal, Chandroji Angre, Mahant Avaidyanath.

questions.question: Who among the following said that "English education has enslaved us" ?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi. Muhammad Iqbal - He wrote the famous song 'Saare jahan se achha', also known for giving birth to the 'idea of Pakistan'. Muhammad Ali Jinnah was a barrister, politician and the founder of Pakistan. Raja Ram Mohan Roy was a religious and social reformer, known as the 'Father of Modern India' or 'Father of the Bengal Renaissance'. Q.881. In 1921-22, farmers of the Malabar seacoast of Kerala undertook a great uprising, which is known as the __ . Matric Level 27/06/2023 (Shift - 2) (a) Munda uprising (b) Moplah uprising (c) Santhal uprising (d) Kol uprising Sol.881.(b) Moplah uprising - Led by Variyamkunnath Kunjahammed Haji, against the British and the Hindu landlords; Wagon tragedy - Moplah prisoners died of suffocation during transportation in a closed freight wagon.

questions.question: Who among the following social reformers of British India is known as Lokhitwadi ?
questions.explanation: Gopal Hari Deshmukh. Balshastri Jambhekar (Father of Marathi Journalism) - He started the very first newspaper, ‘Darpan’, and revolutionized the journalism system in Maharashtra. Q.883. Who among the following founded the Asiatic Society in 1784 in Calcutta? Matric Level 30/06/2023 (Shift - 3) (a) Jonathan Duncan (b) William Jones (c) Warren Hastings (d) Charles Eyre Sol.883.(b) William Jones. Asiatic Society - It was started with the goal of promoting oriental studies. Jonathan Duncan - He started Sanskrit College (1791) at Varanasi to study Hindu Law and Philosophy. He was the Governor of Bombay.

questions.question: The Social Service League was founded in Bombay by:
questions.explanation: Narayan Malhar Joshi - He was an Indian trade union leader, Founded social service league (1911). He started the All India Trade Union Congress (1920). He was the general secretary of AITUC. Manabendra Nath Roy - leader of India’s communists until the independence of India in 1947.

questions.question: When British rule ended in India in 1947 the literacy rate was just ______.
questions.explanation: 12 percent. This census revealed the population of the country to be 36, 10, 88, 090.

questions.question: What was the title given to the late Sarojini Naidu?
questions.explanation: Nightingale of India (Bharat Kokila). This title was given to Sarojini Naidu by Mahatma Gandhi. Notable Works - The Golden Threshold, The Broken Wing.

questions.question: The Deccan Riots of 1875 took place in ______ .
questions.explanation: Maharashtra. Deccan Riots: Began at - Supa village (Poona) in 1875. The farmers’ main motive was to destroy the account books of the moneylenders and they also socially boycotted the moneylenders. The movement was supported by the Poona Sarvajanik Sabha (co-founded by M G Ranade).

questions.question: Editor of a Marathi newspaper "Kesari” was .
questions.explanation: Bal Gangadhar Tilak.

questions.question: What happened in Bengal, India, in 1770 that resulted in the death of one-third of the population?
questions.explanation: Famine. 1770 Bengal Famine - It affected Bengal and Bihar. Relief - Attempts to prevent export and hoard or monopolize grain; 15,000 was spent on the import of food grains. Q.890. Tribal leader Birsa was associated with which tribe? SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening) (a) Munda (b) Bhil (c) Gond (d) Bhutia Sol.890.(a) Munda. questions.question: Dr. B.R Ambedkar was associated with which of the following communities?
questions.explanation: Mahar. It is listed as the Scheduled Caste in India. Dr. B.R Ambedkar - Architect of Indian Constitution.

questions.question: Who among the following was a Roman Catholic missionary who worked in Bengal for the majority of his/her life?
questions.explanation: Mother Teresa (from Macedonia) - Nobel Peace Prize (1979), founded the Missionaries of Charity. Saint Bernadette - French saint whose visions led to the founding of the Marian shrine of Lourdes.

questions.question: When did Indigo revolt, a peasant movement, start in India?
questions.explanation: 1859 (March). The Indigo Rebellion (Neel Bidroh) started in Bengal and was a revolt by the farmers against British planters who had forced them to grow indigo under terms that were greatly unfavorable to the farmers.

questions.question: The Paris Indian Society was an Indian nationalist organisation founded in ______.
questions.explanation: at Paris under the patronage of Madam Bhikaji Cama, Munchershah Burjorji Godrej and S. R. Rana. It was a branch of the Indian Home Rule Society which was established in London in 1905. Bhikaji Cama's important publication is 'Vande Mataram' (1909).

questions.question: In which year was India House established by Shyamji Verma?
questions.explanation: 1905. Other revolutionaries: V.D. Savarkar, Bhikaji Cama, V.N. Chatterjee, Lala Har Dayal, V.V.S. Aiyar, M.P.T. Acharya, P.M. Bapat, etc. Shyamji Krishna Verma founded the Indian Home Rule Society and The Indian Sociologist (Journal) in London. He became the first President of Bombay Arya Samaj.

questions.question: Identify the freedom fighter who, as a child, hated going to school and found it suffocating and oppressive.
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore. Rabindranath Tagore: Santiniketan (1901), Nobel Prize in Literature (1913, Gitanjali), composed Jana Gana Mana (India’s National Anthem) and Amar Shonar Bangla (Bangladesh’s National Anthem). Other Works: Manasi (1890) [The Ideal One], Sonar Tari (1894) [The Golden Boat], Gitimalya (1914) [Wreath of Songs], and Balaka (1916) [The Flight of Cranes]. Q.898. The claim for ‘swarajya’ or self-government within the British Empire, on the model of self-governing colonies like Australia and Canada, was put forward from the Congress platform in 1905 by: SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Lala Lajpat Rai (b) Dadabhai Naoroji (c) Bipin Chandra Pal (d) Gopal Krishna Gokhale Sol.898.(d) Gopal Krishna Gokhale (Diamond of India) was Political Guru of Gandhi, Congress President (1905), established Servants of India Society in 1905, English Newspaper (The Hitavada), founded The Ranade Institute of Economics (1905), ‘Dharmatma Gokhale’ (Writer - Mahatma Gandhi).

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of the Bhoodan Yojana (Land Gift) movement?
questions.explanation: Acharya Vinoba Bhave in 1951, the Bhoodan Movement (first started in Andhra Pradesh) was initiated at Pochampally village (Telangana). The Bhoodan movement attempted to persuade wealthy landowners to voluntarily give a percentage of their land to landless people.

questions.question: The first President of the All India Trade Union Congress was _________.
questions.explanation: Lala Lajpat Rai. All India Trade Union Congress, AITUC (created on October 31, 1920 in Bombay) is the first Central Trade Union of India and the second largest trade union federation in India after the Indian National Trade union Congress. In India, Trade Unions in India are registered under the Trade Union Act (1926).

questions.question: Who among the following was the first Indian to be selected to the British ‘House of Commons’ on a Liberal Party ticket?
questions.explanation: Dadabhai Naoroji. He was known as India Gladstone. The first attempt to calculate National Income of India was made by him. He was the first Asian (Indian) member of the British Parliament. He coined the name “Indian National Congress” (INC).

questions.question: Who among the following Indian freedom fighters was fondly called Gandhi Buri (Old Lady Gandhi) for her dedication towards Gandhian principles?
questions.explanation: Matangini Hazra. Matangini Hazra was an Indian revolutionary and social activist who participated in the Indian independence movement.

questions.question: Avadh Kisan Sabha was set up in the year ______.
questions.explanation: 1920. Oudh Kisan Sabha (Oudh Farmers Association) was an association formed by Baba Ram Chandra. He was a trade unionist who organized the farmers of Oudh and led the first protest against the landlords.

questions.question: India and Pakistan had signed the ______, under which the two countries agreed to sort out differences and disputes bilaterally.
questions.explanation: Shimla Pact was signed in 1972 by Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto, the President of Pakistan, and Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India. Q.905. What was the name of the operation that led to the annexation of the Hyderabad State into India? SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Afternoon) (a) Operation Sunrise (b) Operation Unity (c) Operation Polo (d) Operation Gateway Sol.905.(c) Operation Polo - The code name of the Hyderabad "police action" in September 1948. It was a military operation in which the Indian Armed Forces invaded the Nizam-ruled princely state, annexing it into the Indian Union.

questions.question: With whom is the 'Patharughat Uprising' associated?
questions.explanation: Peasants’ uprising. It was against the tax policies of the British in 1894. Patharughat is a place in Assam and is currently known as Patharighat.

questions.question: The ______ movement was led by Chaudhary Devi Lal in 1987.
questions.explanation: Nyaya Yudh. He founded the Lok Dal party.

questions.question: Chandernagore (Chandannagar) was a ______ colony captured by the British Navy on 23 March 1757.
questions.explanation: French. Battle of Chandernagore (1757) - Between French and British (led by Robert Clive) during the Seven Years' War (1756-1763).

questions.question: In which of the following years did Japan invade India resulting in the Battle of Imphal?
questions.explanation: 1944. The outcome of the battle of Imphal was a turning point of one of the most gruelling campaigns of the Second World War (1939-45).

questions.question: In which of the following years was the Bombay Reorganization Act passed?
questions.explanation: 1960. After this act, Bombay State was dissolved and split on linguistic lines into the two states of Gujarat (Gujarati speaking population) and Maharashtra (Marathi speaking population).

questions.question: Who among the following is one of the founder members of Bhartiya Jana Sangh?
questions.explanation: Shyama Prasad Mukherjee. BJS was an Indian right-wing political party that existed from 1951 to 1977 and was the political arm of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist volunteer organization.

questions.question: A large area of land demarcated as Damin-i-Koh in 1832 was declared as the land of the ______.
questions.explanation: Santhals (Tribal who inhabited the forest of Rajmahal hills). Damin-i-Koh - British promised non-interference in the land. Q.913. Fort Saint Louis was a ______ fort that stood in Pondicherry on the eastern coast of India. SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Morning) (a) French (b) Danish (c) Dutch (d) British Sol.913.(a) French. Fort Saint Louis - Built by Francois Martin History and Destroyed by the Britishers in 1761.

questions.question: What was the meaning of ‘Ryot’ in British records in the 18th century?
questions.explanation: Peasants. Ryots were Individual cultivators who had full rights regarding sale, transfer, and leasing of the land as long as they paid the rent under the Ryotwari system (Land revenue paid by the farmers directly to the state).

questions.question: Who was the Nawab of Bhopal that ruled from 1868 to 1901?
questions.explanation: Shah Jahan Begum. Nawab of Bhopal that ruled – Nawab Sikandar Begum:- 1860-1868, Begum Sultan Shah Jehan:-1844-1860 and 1868-1901. Begum Kaikhusrau Jahan:- 1901-1926, Begum Sajida Sultan:- 1961-1995.

questions.question: Who among the following was one of the speakers after Jawaharlal Nehru to address the Parliament on the midnight of 15 August 1947 ?
questions.explanation: Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishan (1st Vice President of India) was one of the three main speakers at the Central Hall of Parliament - Other than JL Nehru (Tryst with Destiny Speech) and Chaudhary Khaliquzaman.

questions.question: Who was the chairman of the Economic Programme Committee (EPC) that was formed by the All India Congress Committee in 1947?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru. The aim of this committee was to make a plan which could balance private and public partnership and urban and rural economies.

questions.question: In which of the following cities is the tomb of Rani of Jhansi situated?
questions.explanation: Gwalior. The Samadhi of Rani Lakshmi Bai is situated at Phool Bagh. It is to commemorate the great warrior of Jhansi. Q.919. The princely state of Hyderabad was brought under the Indian Union in the year ______. SSC CPO 24/11/2020 (Morning) (a) 1950 (b) 1952 (c) 1948 (d) 1963 Sol.919.(c) 1948. After the State Reorganisation Act 1956 Hyderabad was merged with Andhra state and later renamed as Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Which leader gave us the C-R Formula?
questions.explanation: Rajagopalachari's formula (or C. R. formula or Rajaji formula) was a proposal formulated by Chakravarti Rajagopalachari to solve the political deadlock between the All India Muslim League and the Indian National Congress on the independence of British India.

questions.question: ______ was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1913 and a knighthood in 1915.
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore became the first non-European to receive the Nobel Prize for his literary work. He was awarded knighthood in 1915 by King George V.

questions.question: Veteran freedom fighter, social reformer and feminist Savithribai Phule hailed from which of the following states of India?
questions.explanation: Maharashtra. Savithribai Phule - She was the first female teacher of India and opened a school for women in 1848, Married to Jyotirao Phule (Founded Satya Shodhak Samaj in 1873 in Pune). Q.923. Who among the following scholars is associated with the Tibet-home theory of the Aryans? SSC CGL 07/03/2020 (Evening) (a) Dayanand Saraswati (b) Bal Gangadhar Tilak (c) MacDonell (d) Max Muller Sol.923.(a) Swami Dayanand Saraswati in his book Satyarth Prakash propounded that the original abode of the Aryans was Tibet. The reasoning behind this was that due to the extreme cold in Tibet, sun and fire were worshiped and the flora and fauna described in the Rigveda were found in Tibet.

questions.question: Who among the following was NOT a minister of Cabinet Mission Plan, 1946 ?
questions.explanation: Lord Wavell. The members of the Cabinet Mission were Lord Penthick Lawrence, Secretary of State for India, Sir Stafford Cripps, President of the Board of Trade, and A.V Alexander, First Lord of Admiralty.

questions.question: Which of the following sites would be suitable for observing the architecture of the Harappan civilisation?
questions.explanation: Banawali, located in the Fatehabad district of Haryana, has revealed a three-fold cultural sequence through excavations: Pre-Harappan (Early Harappan), Harappan, and Bara (Post-Harappan) phases. The site was excavated by Dr. R.S. Bisht. It comprises a citadel and a lower town, both of which are fortified.

questions.question: The Iron Age site named Tekwada is located in _________.
questions.explanation: Maharashtra. The Iron Age is a time period when iron became the primary material for tools and weapons. Some Iron Age sites in India: Hallur (Karnataka), Adichanallur and Mayiladumparai (Tamil Nadu), Raja Nal ka Tila (Uttar Pradesh).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are true about the Iron Age? 1. The establishment of large cities took place on the basis of sizeable surplus. 2. The ceramic associated with this age was Painted Grey Ware. 3. The Indus Valley Civilization flourished during the Iron Age.
questions.explanation: Only 1 and 2. The Indus Valley Civilization flourished during the Bronze Age, not the Iron Age. The civilisations that flourished during the Iron Age were Greece, Rome, Persia and India.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct ?

options.a: Harappan culture spread only to Sindh and Punjab.
options.b: The script of the Harappan culture has been deciphered by historians.
options.c: At burials in Harappan sites the dead were generally laid in pits.
options.d: Granaries in the Indus Valley Civilization were found in Harappa only.

questions.explanation: Harappa was discovered in 1921-22 by Daya Ram Sahni. It is located on the banks of the Ravi River in Sahiwal (formerly Montgomery) district, Punjab, Pakistan. The city is divided into three main sections: the Citadel, the Middletown, and the Lower Town. The Harappans sourced copper from present-day Rajasthan. Significant findings include two rows of six granaries, workers' quarters, two sandstone statues depicting human anatomy, a sculpture of a dog attacking a deer, and small bullock carts (known as ekkas).

questions.question: Drains exiting from Mohenjo-Daro had ________ doors that were probably closed at night to prevent vagrants or negative elements from entering the city through that access.
questions.explanation: wooden. Mohenjo-Daro, discovered by R.D. Banerji in 1922, is located on the right bank of the Indus River in southern Pakistan.

questions.question: In which Harappan site was a paved bathroom found?
questions.explanation: Mohenjodaro. It is situated on the banks of Indus River in present-day Pakistan. Significant discoveries from Mohenjodaro include the bronze statue of a dancing girl, the sculpture of a bearded priest, and the Great Granary.

questions.question: At which of the following places in the Indus valley civilisation a brick structure has been identified as a dockyard meant for berthing ships and handling cargo ?
questions.explanation: Lothal (Gujarat). Location: Bank of the Bhogwa River. Features : Evidence of the earliest cultivation of rice, Served as a seaport for the Indus Valley people.

questions.question: In Harappa, the granary had rows of _________ brick platforms for threshing the grains
questions.explanation: Circular. Granaries of the Indus Valley Civilization were discovered in two key regions: Mohenjodaro and Harappa. Mohenjodaro, located south of the Indus River, is a major site where the Great Granary, the largest building, was found. Q.9. Which was the prominent architectural feature of the Indus Valley towns and cities? Graduate Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Citadel (b) Pyramids (c) False Arch (d) Stupas Sol.9.(a) Citadel. In 1921, Dayaram Sahni discovered Harappa, followed by R.D. Banerjee's discovery of Mohenjodaro in 1922. Key features of major cities include grid-based town planning, the use of burnt bricks, underground drainage systems (like Dholavira's water reservoirs), and fortified citadels (except Chanhudaro). Stupas - Buddhist architecture. Pyramids - Ancient Egypt.

questions.question: Select the correct alternative on the basis of the given statements on the cities of Harappan civilisation. Statement I: Most of the Harappan cities were divided into two parts: Higher Town and Lower Town. Statement II: The archaeologists describe the lower part of the towns as Citadel.

options.a: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
options.d: Neither Statement I nor Statement II is true.

questions.explanation: Only Statement I is true. The Harappan cities were typically structured into two distinct sections. The part to the west was generally smaller in area but higher in elevation, which archaeologists refer to as the Citadel. In contrast, the section to the east was larger in size but lower in elevation, commonly known as the Lower Town.

questions.question: Fire altars were found in which of the following groups of Harappan cities?
questions.explanation: Kalibangan and Lothal. Findings of different Indus valley civilization sites : Kalibangan - Lower fortified town, Boustrophedon style, Wooden drainage, Copper Ox, Evidence of earthquake, Wooden plough, Camel’s History bone. Lothal - Port Town, Evidence of Rice, Graveyard, Ivory scale, Copper dog. Mohenjo-Daro - Prepared Garments, Temple-like Palace, Pashupati seal, Statue of a dancing girl, The Great Bath, The Great Granary etc.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the Great Bath of the Indus Valley Civilisation ?

options.a: It was used for grain storage.
options.c: It was used as the water tank of the city.
options.d: It was probably used for religious purpose.

questions.explanation: "Great bath" is a public water tank located in Mohenjo Daro (Pakistan). It was a large rectangular tank in a courtyard surrounded by a corridor on all four sides. There were two flights of steps on the north and south leading into the tank, which was made watertight by setting bricks on edge and using a mortar of gypsum. There were rooms on three sides, in one of which was a large well.

questions.question: Which of the following Indus Valley sites is now located in Pakistan ?
questions.explanation: Harappa. The Indus valley civilization (Bronze Age) is also called the Harappan culture. Other Important Sites : Sutkagendor (Dast river, Balochistan); Chanhudaro (Pakistan, Indus river); Kalibangan (Rajasthan, Ghaggar river); Lothal (Gujarat, Bhogva river); Alamgirpur (Meerut, Hindon river).

questions.question: Pottery was first traceable to which period of ancient Indian history?
questions.explanation: Neolithic. Pottery has been discovered in the early villages of Mehrgarh. The Palaeolithic (the first and longest part of the Stone Age) was a period of prehistory when humans made stone tools.

questions.question: In India, the practice of erecting megaliths began about __________ ago.
questions.explanation: 3000 years. A megalith is a large stone that has been used to construct a pre - historic structure or monument. Type - Clairn Circles type of Megalith (grave/memorial) were the stone pieces set in a circular shape around the grave. Menhir (standing stone), Capstone (Single megaliths placed horizontally over burial chambers), Dolmen (A large capstone on two or more support stones creating a chamber). Megalith Sites - Nilaskal (Karnataka), Hanamsagar (Karnataka), Junapani (Maharashtra), Hire Benakal (Karnataka), etc.

questions.question: Cotton was probably grown at Mehrgarh from about ________.
questions.explanation: 7000 years ago. It is the oldest agricultural settlement in the Indian subcontinent.

questions.question: Which of the following Harappan town was located on Khadir Beyt in the Runn of Kutch and was divided into three parts?
questions.explanation: Dholavira. Discovered in 1968 by archaeologist Jagat Pati Joshi. Fifth largest metropolis of Indus Valley Civilization, 40th Indian site on UNESCO’s World Heritage list. Surkotada: Discovered in 1964-68 by Jagat Pati Joshi, located in northeast Bhuj in Gujarat. Chanhudaro: Discovered in 1931 by N. G. Majumdar, located in Sindh, Pakistan. Sotka koh - Discovered by George F. Dales, located on the Makran coast, near the city of Pasni, Balochistan (Pakistan).

questions.question: Bhimbetka, a noted site of the Palaeolithic period, is located in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Madhya Pradesh. Bhimbetka is located in the Vindhya ranges of Madhya Pradesh. It was discovered by V. S. Wakankar in 1957. Q.19. During which of the following period Ostriches were found in India? SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (3rd Shift) (a) Mesolithic (b) Chalcolithic (c) Neolithic (d) Palaeolithic Sol.19.(d) Palaeolithic age. Large quantities of ostrich egg shells found at Patne, Maharashtra.

questions.question: In which of the following sites of jadeite stone was found?
questions.explanation: Daojali Hading - A neolithic site in Dima Hasao District of Assam. Situated near Brahmaputra valley close to routes leading into China and Myanmar.

questions.question: Which of the following metals was used to make weapons and tools in Harappan cities?
questions.explanation: Copper was the first metal used in Indus Valley (Bronze Age civilization) to make tools, utensils, and other objects. Other metals used were lead, gold, bronze and silver.

questions.question: The Harappan brought Gold from present-day _______ in India.
questions.explanation: Karnataka. Gold ornaments are found at both Mohenjo-daro and Harappa. Other materials they imported: Copper - Brought from present-day Rajasthan, and from Oman in west Asia. Tin - Brought from present-day Afghanistan and Iran. Precious stones - Brought from present-day Gujarat, Iran and Afghanistan.

questions.question: Which of the following types of house remains were found in Mehrgarh site of Harappan civilization?
questions.explanation: Square or rectangle. Major findings at Mehrgarh are evidence of animal bones and the remains of houses. Mehrgarh was discovered in 1974 by Jean-Francois Jarrige. It is the first place where people started growing barley and wheat, reared the sheep and goat as it was one of the oldest villages.

questions.question: The duration of the Mesolithic period is from about ______ years ago to ____ years ago.
questions.explanation: 12000, 10000. The Mesolithic Period (Middle Stone Age) is the earliest History Holocene culture. Feature: Microliths, technological innovations (bow and arrow for hunting, querns, grinders, etc.), Excavated sites (Tilwara, Bagor, Tarsang, Morkhana, Lekhahia, Birbhanpur, etc.).

questions.question: Most Harappan seals made of ____.
questions.explanation: Steatite (a kind of soft stone). Some seals were also made of terracotta, gold, agate, chert, ivory, and faience. Two important seals were the Pashupati seal and the Unicorn seal.

questions.question: A celt is ______ from the Neolithic period.
questions.explanation: a tool. The term Neolithic Period refers to the last stage of the Stone Age. Q.27. Which of the following is a Palaeolithic site of archaeological importance in India? SSC MTS 06/10/2021 (Afternoon) (a) Chirand (b) Burzahom (c) Hunasagi (d) Mehrgarh Sol.27.(c) Hunasagi. Some Old Stone Age stone-cutting equipment has been found and kept in the Hunasagi Gram Panchayat office.

questions.question: Which of the following Harappan sites is located in Afghanistan?
questions.explanation: Shortughai was a trading post of Harappan times and it seems to be connected with lapis lazuli mines located in the surrounding area. Vedic Age (1500 BC to 600 BC)

questions.question: Consider the following statements in the context of the Vedas. 1.The Vedas are called Shruti. 2.The Rigveda consists of ten Mandalas. Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both 1 and 2. Vedas are sruti ("what is heard") distinguishing them from other religious texts, which are called smrti ("what is remembered"). Hindus consider the Vedas to be apauruṣeya, which means "not of a man, superhuman" and "impersonal, authorless". The Rigveda is the oldest Veda and contains 1,028 hymns (suktas) comprising about 10,600 verses.

questions.question: Which Rigvedic God is considered an intermediary between God and men?
questions.explanation: Agni. The Rigveda, with over a thousand hymns, praises deities like: Agni - the god of fire; Indra - the warrior god; and Soma - a sacred plant from which a special ritual drink was prepared.

questions.question: According to the Ashrama system of Vedic life, which of the following was the third stage of life?
questions.explanation: Vanaprastha, where a person handed over household responsibilities to the next generation, took an advisory role, and gradually withdrew from the world. The four stages of the ashrama system are : Brahmacharya (Student's life), Grihastha (household life), Vanaprastha (retired life), Sannyasa (renounced life).

questions.question: The Vedangas are Hindu auxiliary disciplines that originated in ancient times and are linked to the study of the Vedas. These are _________ in number.
questions.explanation: Six. Vedanga literally means "limbs of the Vedas," and refers to the six disciplines connected with studying the Vedas, the ancient Indian spiritual writings. The six Vedangas are as follows: Shiksha (phonetics), Kalpa (ritual), Vyakarana (grammar), Nirukta (etymology), Chandas (meter), and Jyotisha (astronomy).

questions.question: According to the Varna system that was prevalent in the Vedic period, which of the following was NOT a Varna?
questions.explanation: Samiti. The traditional caste system consists of a hierarchy of four castes (varnas) - Brahmins (priests and teachers), Kshatriyas (rulers and warriors), Vaishyas (merchants and cultivators), and Shudras (servants).

questions.question: Which among the following was NOT a part of the three sections of the Rigvedic tribe?
questions.explanation: Craftsman. The Rigvedic society was structured into three main varnas : Priests, who performed rituals and offered spiritual guidance; Warriors, who governed and protected the tribe and Ordinary People comprising farmers, traders, and artisans engaged in economic activities. Q.35. A large number of words are derived from the word ‘Go’ meaning cow. A wealthy person was known as ________ in Vedic times. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Gomat (b) Gotra (c) Gabaksha (d) Gaveshana Sol.35.(a) Gomat. The term Gomat was derived from the Sanskrit word 'gomati' which means possessing or having cows. Gotra : It refers to people who are descendants of a common ancestor through their father's side. Gaveshana: This means "search for cows," but it can also refer to battle. Q.36. How many Mandalas were in Rig Vedic Samhita? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift) (a) 11 (b) 10 (c) 12 (d) 20 Sol.36.(b) 10. Rig Veda is the oldest of the four Vedas. It is a collection of 10,600 verses and 1,028 hymns. The Famous Gayatri mantra is in Rig Veda Mandala 3. Each mandala consists of Suktas which are basically eulogies. The 10th mandala contains the Purusha Sukta which explains the four Varnas were born from the mouth, arms, thighs and feet of the Brahma or Purusha. Mandala 9 is completely devoted to Soma. Q.37. Which of the following is the earliest literary record of Indian culture? Graduate Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Yajurveda (b) Rigveda (c) Atharvaveda (d) Samaveda Sol.37.(b) Rigveda. There are four Vedas: Rigveda, Samaveda, Yajurveda, and Atharvaveda. Q.38. Asikni, which was a part of Sapta-Sindhu, is the name of which of the following rivers in present times ? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Jhelum (b) Beas (c) Chenab (d) Ravi Sol.38.(c) Chenab. Ancient names of Indian Rivers - Vitasta (Jhelum), Purushni History (Ravi), Shatudri (Satluj), Vipasha (Beas), Sadanira (Gandak), Drishdvati (Ghaghara).

questions.question: Which of the following Vedas is found in two recensions, black and white, and is full of rituals to be performed publicly or individually?
questions.explanation: Yajurveda : Notable Upanishads of Yajurveda - Brihadaranyaka, Isha, Taittriya, Katha, and Maithri.

questions.question: In which of the following Vedas was Dasarajna war (the war of ten kings) mentioned?
questions.explanation: Rigveda (Book of Mantras). Dasarajna war was fought between King Sudas of the Bharata tribe and a confederation of ten tribes, including the Puru, Yadu, Turvasa, Anu, Druhyu, Alina, Paktha, Bhalanas, Shiva, and Vishanin. The battle took place on the banks of the Parushni (Ravi) river.

questions.question: The main (chief) social unit of the Aryans was______ .
questions.explanation: Jana (Tribes). Gana - Tribal or clan based assemblies, Parishad - A small body similar to Samitis/sabhas consisting exclusively of Brahmins, Rajan - A kind of Chief or King.

questions.question: Which of the four Vedas contains a collection of magic spells and charms to fend off evil spirits and diseases?
questions.explanation: Atharva Veda (‘Book of magic spells’) - Has 730 hymns/suktas, 5987 mantras, and 20 books (Khandas). Sama Veda (‘Book of Chant’) - The earliest reference for singing; 1875 verses. Yajur Veda (‘Book of Rituals’) - Has two types, Krishna (or black) and Shukla (or white).

questions.question: The Purva Mimansa school of philosophy was founded by ________ in ancient India
questions.explanation: Jaimini. Purva Mimansa (‘Prior Study’) also known as Dharma Mimamsa and Karma Mimamsa (‘Study of Actions’). The six principal Hindu darshans are Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mimamsa, and Vedanta. Badarayana - Author of Brahma Sutra or Vedanta Sutra. Patanjali - Philosophy of Yoga sutra. Kapila - Philosophy of Sankhya. Vyasa - Author of the Mahabharata, Vedas and Puranas.

questions.question: India was named 'Bharat' after the name of the Bharat clan. In which of the following Vedas is this clan first mentioned ?
questions.explanation: Rigveda. There are Suktas in 10 Mandals (Chapters).

questions.question: The language of the Aryan texts was:
questions.explanation: Sanskrit was the first language spoken in India. Ardhamagadhi Prakrit was a Middle Indo-Aryan language. Prakrit is a group of vernacular Middle Indo-Aryan languages spoken in India between the third and seventh century BCE.

questions.question: As per the Rigvedic or Early Vedic Period (1500-1000 BC), who among the following was a River Goddess?
questions.explanation: Sindhu. The seven rivers mentioned in the Rig-Veda - Sindhu (Indus), Vitasta (Vehit/Jhelum), Asikni (Chenab), Prusni/Eravati (Ravi) Vipasha (Beas), Sutudri (Sutlej) and Sarasvati (which dried up). Agni (fire-god of Hinduism), Usha (Goddess of Dawn), Arika (God of Beauty).

questions.question: In the Rig Veda there is a hymn in the form of a dialogue between Sage Vishvamitra and two rivers that were worshipped as goddesses. Which are these rivers?
questions.explanation: Beas and Sutlej. The most prominent river in the Rig Veda is Saraswati.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the ‘Gotra’ practice in ancient India is true?

options.a: Men and women were expected to marry within the same gotra.
options.b: People belonging to the same gotra were regarded as descendants of the person after whom the gotra was named.
options.c: Women retained their father’s gotra after marriage.
options.d: Each gotra was named after a famous king.

questions.explanation: Gotra originally referred to the seven lineage segments of the Brahmans (priests), who trace their derivation from seven ancient seers: Atri, Bharadvaja, Bhrigu, Gotama, Kashyapa, Vasishtha, and Vishvamitra.

questions.question: ‘Purusha Sukta’ is a hymn from which Veda?
questions.explanation: Rigveda. The most commonly used portion of the Sukta contains 24 mantras or stanzas. Purusha Suktam is dedicated to Lord Vishnu, who is described as the great Purusha in the hymn. Purusha Suktam is one of the Pancha Suktam (5 Suktams) – Purusha Suktam, Vishnu Suktam, Sri Suktam, Bhu Suktam, and Nila Suktam.

questions.question: With reference to Ajivikas, consider the following statements: a) Makkhali Gosala was the prominent teacher of this sect. b) Ajivikas believed in fatalism. Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Both a and b. Ajivika - It was a school of thought that developed in India during the same time as Jainism and Buddhism. It is one of the schools under Nastika philosophy (it does not believe in the authority of Vedas). It was founded by Goshala Maskariputra. The sect is seen as professing total determinism in the transmigration of souls, or series of rebirths. Q.51. Mahavir Jayanti celebrates the birthday of Lord Mahavira who is the ____ Tirthankara of Jainism. SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift) (a) 23rd (b) 26th (c) 24th (d) 25th History Sol.51.(c) 24th. Lord Mahavir was born on the 13th day of the Chaitra month (March - April) of the Hindu calendar in BC. Birthplace - Vaishali in present-day Bihar. ‘Kaivalya’ or omniscience - Age of 42. Moksha (liberation from the cycle of birth and death) - Age of 72 in 468 BC (Pavapuri near modern Rajgir in Bihar). The first tirthankara - Rishabhanatha.

questions.question: The Jain temple at Pattadakal was built by ________.
questions.explanation: Rashtrakuta. Other temples made by Rashtrakutas - The Kailasanatha Temple in Ellora, the Navalinga Temples in Pattadakal.

questions.question: Name the holy city recognized as the birthplace of the first and fourth Jain Tirthankaras.
questions.explanation: Ayodhya is recognized as the birthplace of the first (Rishabhdev) and fourth (Abhinandannath) Jain Tirthankaras.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the Medhi part in Buddhist structure?

options.a: The circular terrace between the railing and dome
options.b: Ceremonial gateways in front of stupas
options.c: A low wall to enclose the structure
options.d: The umbrella-shaped structure placed at the top of the structure

questions.explanation: All forms of Buddhist architecture include three primary structures: vihara, stupa, and chaitya-griha.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct in context of Buddhist architecture? i. The Uddeshika stupa was created as a memorial. ii. Paribhogika stupa contained the buried bodily remains of Buddh. iii. Bharhut stupa is situated in Uttar Pradesh.
questions.explanation: Only i and ii. Bharhut stupa (Madhya Pradesh) is known for its early Buddhist reliefs and carvings.

questions.question: During which of the following rules did Buddhism get split into two schools - Hinayana and Mahayana in the fourth Buddhist council?
questions.explanation: Kushana. The Fourth Buddhist Council was held in 72 AD at Kundalvana, Kashmir, under the Kushan king Kanishka. It was led by Vasumitra, with Asvaghosa as his deputy, and marked the division of Buddhism into two sects: Mahayana and Hinayana.

questions.question: The Shailendra kings who had close contacts with the Indian rulers were followers of which of the following religions?
questions.explanation: Buddhism. The rulers of the Sailendra built many temples and monuments, including the Borobudur stupa, which is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Shailendra empire was based in Java and spread to other parts of Southeast Asia, including Sumatra, Bali, and parts of modern-day Malaysia and Thailand.

questions.question: Stupas are a symbol of which of the following religions ?
questions.explanation: Buddhism. Stupas were burial mounds prevalent in India from the vedic period. Stupas typically consist of several elements, including a circular base or platform, a hemispherical dome or Anda, a spire or Harmika, and a parasol or Chhatra. Sanchi Stupa in Madhya Pradesh is the most famous of the Ashokan stupas.

questions.question: The tall sculptures on the Bharhut Stupa are the depictions of ________
questions.explanation: Yakshas and Yakshinis. (nature spirits in Indian mythology linked to prosperity and fertility). These figures symbolize the connection between the spiritual and natural worlds and showcase the integration of local traditions into Buddhist art.

questions.question: The location of ‘Dhamek Stupa’ is:
questions.explanation: Sarnath. The Dhamek Stupa was built in 500 CE to replace an earlier structure commissioned by the great Mauryan king Ashoka in 249 BCE.

questions.question: Which of the following Indo-Greek kings was mentioned in the Buddhist text Milindapanho as Milinda?
questions.explanation: Menander I. The Milinda Panha is a dialogue between the Indian Buddhist sage Nagasena and the 2nd-century BC Indo-Greek king Menander I.

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT statement from among the following

options.a: ‘Sanchi Stupa’ is situated in Madhya Pradesh.
options.b: ‘Bavikonda Stupa’ is situated in Andhra Pradesh.
options.c: ‘Dhamek Stupa’ is situated in Uttar Pradesh.

questions.explanation: Piprahwa Stupa is located in Uttar Pradesh near the town of Piprahwa, close to the India-Nepal border, this site is renowned for its archaeological significance. Q.63. Which of the following is the largest Stupa in India? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Kesariya Stupa (b) Shanti Stupa (c) Sanchi Stupa (d) Maha Stupa Sol.63.(a) Kesariya Stupa (Bihar): It was discovered in 1958 during an excavation led by K.K Muhammed. Shanti Stupa (Leh): It was built in 1991 by Japanese Buddhist Bhikshu Gyomyo Nakamura.

questions.question: Who among the following has written the biography of Buddha, Buddhacharita ?
questions.explanation: Ashvaghosha. He was the court poet of king Kanishka. Other writers and books: Nagarjuna - Mulamadhyamakakarika. Vasumitra - Mahavibhasa. Charaka - Charaka Samhita.

questions.question: Which is the oldest Stupa of the Buddhist Period?
questions.explanation: Sanchi Stupa was built by the Mauryan emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BC in Madhya Pradesh. It was declared a world heritage site by UNESCO in 1989.

questions.question: _______ was the first woman to be ordained as a bhikkhuni in Buddhism.
questions.explanation: Mahapajapati Gotami. Sanghamitta was an Indian Buddhist nun and the eldest daughter of Ashoka. Sujata fed Gautama Buddha a bowl of kheera, a milk-rice pudding, ending his six years of asceticism. Venerable Dhammananda Bhikkhuni is the first fully ordained Theravadin nun in Thailand. Q.67. With reference to Buddhist architecture, what does chaitya mean? SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Buddha Relics (b) Temple entrance (c) Prayer Hall (d) Residence/Monastery Sol.67.(c) Prayer Hall. It is a rectangular hall with a semi-circular apse at one end, which contains a stupa or relic chamber. Other types of architecture : Stupa - It contained the Buddha's ashes. Vihara - Residence hall for the monks.

questions.question: The rules made for the Buddhist "Sangha” were written down in a book called ________ .
questions.explanation: Vinaya Pitaka. Buddhist teachings were divided into Three Pitakas at the First Buddhist Council in 483 BC. Vinaya Pitaka: It consists of rules of conduct and discipline applicable to the monastic life of the monks and the nuns. It was compiled by Upali, and was written in Pali language.

questions.question: In Buddhist architecture, which among the following are meditation cells and living quarters for the monks?
