questions.explanation: Viharas were dwelling places used by wandering monks during the rainy season. Important Buddhist viharas - Ajanta, Ellora. Nasik, Karle, Kanheri, Bagh.

questions.question: Buddha meditated for days on end under a peepal tree at _____ where he attained enlightenment.
questions.explanation: Bodh Gaya. Gautam Buddha (Siddharta, Sakyamuni & Tathagata). Father: Suddhodana, Mother: Mayadevi. Birth Place (563 B.C.): Lumbini (Nepal), Capital of Sakya republic. Teachers: Alarakalama and UdrakaRamputra. Enlightenment : At age of 35 under the Peepal tree at Uruvela (Bodhgaya) on banks of river Niranjana (Falgu). Mahaparinirvana (483 B.C.): At Kushinagar at age of 80. Sign:- Lotus and Bull - Birth, Horse - Renunciation, Bodhi Tree - Enlightenment, Dhammachakra Pravartana (Sarnath) - First sermon.

questions.question: What was the pedestrian path for devotees to wave in homage to Stupa called in Buddhist architecture?
questions.explanation: Medhi. Features of Stupa - Medhi (A circular terrace), Toranas (wall with decorated gateways), Anda (hemispherical mound), Chattra (A central pillar supporting a triple-umbrella form), and Harmika (A square railing).

questions.question: Ramabhar Stupa, which marks the site where Lord Buddha was cremated, is situated in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Uttar Pradesh. Important places related to Lord Buddha (Founder of Buddhism): Mahabodhi Temple, Bodh Gaya (He attained enlightenment); Dhamekh Stupa, Sarnath (He gave his first sermon to his five disciples post-enlightenment).

questions.question: The Lion Capital was built to commemorate the historical event of _________ of Buddha.
questions.explanation: First sermon.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct? I. Gautama Buddha belonged to a small gana known as the Sakya gana and was a Kshatriya. II. Gautama Buddha passed away at Kusinara.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Important places related to the life of Buddha are - Birth (Lumbini); Enlightenment (Bodh Gaya at Bihar); His first Sermon also known as Dharma-Chakra-Pravartana (Sarnath); His death or Mahaparinirvana in Kushinagara (Pali: Kusinārā), Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: The earliest Buddhist texts were written in:
questions.explanation: Pali. Pali canon, also called Tipitaka (Pali: “Triple Basket”), is the complete canon, first recorded in Pali, of the Theravada (“Way of the Elders”) branch of Buddhism.

questions.question: The ‘Gandhara’ School of Art was influenced by the art from which of the following European countries?
questions.explanation: Greece. Gandhara School of Art : Features - Grey-sandstone is used, Mainly Buddhist images are found, Patron - Kushanas, Found in north-west India.

questions.question: When did the second urbanisation in Ganga Valley take place ?
questions.explanation: 6th Century BCE. This era witnessed the development of kingdoms and Mahajanapadas like Magadha, Kosala, and Vatsa, alongside advancements in agriculture, trade, and administration. The First urbanisation in India took place during the Harappan civilization.

questions.question: What was the name of the first dynasty that ruled over Magadh kingdom ?
questions.explanation: Haryanka dynasty : The capital of this dynasty was Rajagriha. Bimbisara was the first king of Magadha, starting the Haryanka dynasty, which lasted from 544 BC to 412 BC.

questions.question: How many Mahajanapadas were there during the age of Buddha?
questions.explanation: 16. The references of 16 Mahajanapadas are found in Anguttara Nikaya (Buddhist literature) and Bhagwati Sutra (Jain texts). The list of the 16 Mahajanapadas includes: Anga (Champa), Magadh (Rajgriha/Girivraja, later Pataliputra), Kasi (Kasi), Vatsa (Kausambi), Kosala (Sravasti), Saurasena (Mathura), Panchala (Ahichchhatra), Kuru (Indraprastha), Matsya (Viratnagar), Chedi (Sothivati/Banda), Avanti (Ujjain/Mahishmati), Gandhara (Taxila, Purushapura), Kamboj (Rajapura), Asmaka (Paithan/Pratisthan), Vajji (Vaishali), Malla (Kusinara).

questions.question: Kosala Mahajanapada (6th century BCE) is a part of modern day:
questions.explanation: Uttar Pradesh. Modern day names of other Mahajanapadas: Munger and Bhagalpur (Anga), Gaya and Patna (Magadha), Banaras (Kashi), Prayagraj (Vatsa), Malwa and Madhya Pradesh (Avanti), Rawalpindi (Gandhara), North Bihar (Vajji), Jaipur (Matsya), Meerut and Haryana (Kuru), Western Uttar Pradesh (Shurasena and Panchala), Bundelkhand region (Chedi), Rajouri, Hajra and North -West Frontier Province (Kamboja), Banks of Godavari (Asmaka or Assaka), Deoria and Uttar Pradesh (Malla).

questions.question: Iron mines in Jharkhand attributed to the rise of which of the following kingdoms in ancient India?
questions.explanation: Magadha.

questions.question: Magadha Mahajanapada was surrounded by the rivers______.
questions.explanation: Ganga and Son. Magadha became the most powerful among the mahajanapadas in 6th Century AD due to these rivers and fertility of land. Now Magadha is a part of Bihar region. Q.83. Rulers of Mahajanapadas in ancient India collected taxes on crops at the rate of _____ of what was produced. SSC MTS 05/07/2022 (Evening) (a) 1/3rd (b) 1/5th (c) 1/6th (d) 1/4th Sol.83.(c) 1/6th. Rulers of mahajanapadas in ancient India collected a tax called 'Bhaga' from the Farmers in their region.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of ‘Name of Ruler – Empire’ is correctly matched? I. Mahapadma Nanda – Magadha Empire II. Ajatasatru – Maurya Empire
questions.explanation: Only I. Mahapadma Nanda established the Nanda dynasty in Eastern Magadha. He established Pataliputra (Patna, Bihar) as his kingdom's capital. Mauryan Dynasty Q.85. With reference to the city administration of Mauryan Empire, consider the following statements. A) Megasthenes put light on the Mauryan city administration. B) The city council was divided into six committees. C) City administration was well planned. Which of the above statements is/are correct? SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Afternoon) (a) B, C (b) A, B (c) A, B, (d) C, A Sol.85.(c) A, B, C. The Mauryan Empire, founded by Chandragupta Maurya in 321 BCE, was the first major empire in India. It stretched from the Oxus Valley to the Kaveri Delta, covering most of the subcontinent, with its capital at Pataliputra, a city fortified with 64 gates and 570 towers. Megasthenes, a Greek historian, documented India in his work Indica.

questions.question: Which of the following edicts of King Ashoka describes the Kalinga war?
questions.explanation: Rock edict XIII. The Edicts of Ashoka, issued during his reign (268–232 BCE), are inscriptions on pillars, boulders, and caves. Key edicts include Pillar Edict I, emphasizing protection of people, and Pillar Edict II, defining Dhamma as compassion and truthfulness. Pillar Edict VII, Ashoka describes all sect's desire for self-control and purity of mind. The Rummindei Inscription marks his visit to Buddha's birthplace, Lumbini, while the Kandahar Greek Edicts, written in Greek and Prakrit, were found in 1963.

questions.question: The name ‘Piyadassi’ is associated with whom among the following Mauryan kings?
questions.explanation: Ashoka. "Piyadasi" is an honorific epithet that means "He who regards others with kindness", "Humane", or "He who glances amiably". Q.88. Deimachus, who was a Greek ambassador, came to India during the reign of the Mauryan king, _________. SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Shatadhanvan (b) Bindusara (c) Ashoka (d) Chandragupta Maurya Sol.88.(b) Bindusara also known as "Amitrochates" or "Amitragata" by the Greeks, was the son of Chandragupta Maurya. Bindusara patronized the Ajivikas and was taught by the Ajivika Brahmin Pingalavatsa.

questions.question: In which of the following Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka is the Kalinga war mentioned?
questions.explanation: XIII. Major Rock Edict XIII of Ashoka discusses the Kalinga War, expressing remorse for the loss of life and suffering it caused. It announces his conversion to Buddhism and commitment to non-violence, highlighting the importance of Dharma (righteous living). Major Rock Edict XII: Deals with Ashoka's tolerance and respect for other religions. Major Rock Edict X : Discusses Ashoka's duties as a ruler and his commitment to Dharma. Major Rock Edict XI : Explains the principles of Dharma and moral conduct.

questions.question: Who among the following generally used to head the provincial administration under the Mauryas?
questions.explanation: Kumara. The 18 Tirthas were key officials in ancient administration, History including roles like Mantrin (Chief Minister), Purohita (Priest), Senapati (Army Commander), Yuvaraja (Prince), Dauvarika (Chief of Palace Attendants), Antarvamsika (Chief of the King’s Guards), Prasasta (Magistrate), Samahata (Collector General), Samnidhata (Chief Treasurer), and Pradesta (Commissioner). Other roles included Nayak (Town Guard), Paur (Town Chief), Karmanta (Mines Superintendent), Dandpala (Army Officer), and Durgapala (Fort Guardian).

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT one of the basic attributes of Ashokas' Dhamma?
questions.explanation: Celibacy. Ashoka's Dhamma, as outlined in his Edicts, emphasized the following basic attributes: Ahimsa (Non-violence), Secularism (Separation of religion and state), Political unification (Unity and harmony among subjects).

questions.question: Who among the following envoys was sent by Seleucus I to the court of Chandragupta Maurya?
questions.explanation: Megasthenes. He was an ancient Greek historian, diplomat, and ethnographer who authored the famous work “Indica”, providing valuable insights into the Mauryan Empire, including its administration, society, geography, and culture.

questions.question: Which of the following Ashokan rock edicts declares prohibition of animal sacrifice ?
questions.explanation: Major Rock Edict - I. There are 14 Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka in three languages (Prakrit, Aramaic and Greek) and two scripts (Brahmi and Kharosthi). Major Rock Edicts: II - It mentions social welfare under Dhamma. Major Rock Edict III - It declares that respect for parents and for all living things, including Brahmanas and Sramanas, is a virtue. Major Rock Edict IV - Consideration and non-violence to animals and courtesy to relations. Major Rock Edict XIII - It mentions Ashoka’s victory over Kalinga.

questions.question: Ashoka sent his son Mahendra and daughter Sanghmitra to spread the message of Dhamma to which of the following countries?
questions.explanation: Sri Lanka. Ashoka (272 BCE –232 BCE) was the third king of the Mauryan dynasty (Founder - Chandragupta Maurya).

questions.question: Bhabru-Bairat rock edicts mainly depicting Ashokas' conversion to Buddhism are found in ___________
questions.explanation: Rajasthan. Bhabru is the only inscription in the Boustrophedon script (bi-directional script from right to left and left to right in an alternate line).

questions.question: Who requested the Syrian king to send a Greek philosopher?
questions.explanation: Bindusara was the second Mauryan Empire, father of Ashoka, and son of Chandragupta (founder of Mauryan empire). Syrian King Antiochus-I sent his ambassador Deimachus to the court of Bindusara.

questions.question: Barabar Cave, famously known for depicting Ashokas' inscription, is situated at_______
questions.explanation: Gaya, Bihar. The Barabar Caves, located in the Makhdumpur region of Jehanabad district, Bihar, date back to the Mauryan period (3rd century BCE) and were built by Emperor Ashoka for Ajivaka ascetics. The caves include Karan Chaupar, Lomas Rishi, Sudama, and Visvakarma Caves.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers was defeated in the battle for Pataliputra by Chandragupta Maurya ?
questions.explanation: Dhana Nanda. He was the last ruler of the Nanda dynasty, and his defeat marked the establishment of the Mauryan Empire in India.

questions.question: Who among the following Mauryan rulers was the first, who tried to convey his messages to his subjects concerning the idea and practice of dhamma through inscriptions?
questions.explanation: Ashoka was the third emperor of the Mauryan Dynasty. To propagate the policy of dhamma, he used the medium of edicts. These edicts were used to communicate between the King (Ashoka) and his subjects. Few inscriptions were addressed to the Buddhist Samgha.

questions.question: Which of the following was a Ceylonese chronicle that acted as an important literary source of the Mauryan empire?
questions.explanation: Mahavamsa - It was written by Mahanama in Pali language. Literary Sources of Mauryan Period: "Arthashastra” (Kautilya), “Indica” (Megasthenes). Q.101. Who among the following Mauryan kings fasted to death and died at Shravanabelagola? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening) (a) Bindusara (b) Dasharatha (c) Ashoka (d) Chandragupta Maurya Sol.101.(d) Chandragupta Maurya: His Greek name was Sandrocottos. He was the founder of the Mauryan Empire. He occupied Patliputra (Magadh Empire) in 322 B.C by defeating Dhanananda of Nanda Empire. During his tenure Megasthenese (Greek Historian) visited India. He used to follow Jainism.

questions.question: What was the function of an officer called Samaharta?
questions.explanation: Tax assessment. Officers during the Mauryan administration: Shulkadhyaksha (Officer-in-charge of royal income), Koshadhyaksha (Treasury officer), Lakshanadhyaksha (Coin minting), Rajjukas (Land measurer), Yukta (Subordinate revenue officer), Sannidata (Treasury head), History Panyadhyaksha (Office of commerce department). Q.103. Emperor Ashoka conquered Kalinga after how many years of his coronation? SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) 5 years (b) 8 years (c) 11 years (d) 15 years Sol.103.(b) 8 years. Ashoka fought the Kalinga War in 261 BC. King Ashoka (268 - 232 BC) was the third king of the Mauryan Empire. Q.104. How many classes of Indian society are mentioned in Megasthenes book Indica? SSC CGL 24/07/2023 ( 3rd shift) (a) 12 (b) 10 (c) 5 (d) 7 Sol.104.(d) 7. They were Brahmins (upper class), Philosophers, Farmers, Herders, Artisans, Military, Overseers, Councillors and Assessors. Q.105. According to Kautilya's Arthashastra, the Commanding Officer of the cavalry in the Mauryan administration was known as: SSC CGL 24/07/2023( 4th shift) (a) Rathadhyaksha (b) Hastyadhyaksha (c) Ashwadhyaksha (d) Patyadhyaksha Sol.105.(c) Ashwadhyaksha. Officers in Mauryan Empire: Mantrin (Chief Minister), Senapati (Commander-in -Chief), Yuvraj (Crown prince), Shulkadhyaksha (Officer in-charge of royal income), Prashasti (Prison head), Koshadhyaksha (Treasury officer), Vyabharika (Chief Judge), Dandapala (Head of Police), Annapala (Head of food grains department), Pradeshika (District administrator), Hastyadhyaksha (Chief Commander of Elephant Corps), Rathadhyaksha (Chief Commander of Chariot Corps) and Nayaka (City security officer).

questions.question: The Mauryan pillar capital found at _______ is popularly known as the Lion Capital.
questions.explanation: Sarnath Lion Capital - Erected by Ashoka (Around 250 BCE) in commemoration of Dhammachakra pravartana or the first sermon of Buddha. The Lion Capital of Ashoka at Sarnath is the Indian National Emblem.

questions.question: Which of the following texts lays down minute details of the administrative and military organisation during the Mauryan empire?
questions.explanation: Arthashastra - It focused primarily on principles and practice of statecraft, Written in the Sanskrit language by Kautilya (Chanakya /Vishnugupta), who was the Prime Minister under Chandragupta Maurya’s reign.

questions.question: Nagarjuni Caves were donated to which of the following sects by Mauryans?
questions.explanation: Ajivika - It was founded by Goshala Maskariputra. It is based on the philosophy that the affairs of the entire universe were ordered by a cosmic force called Niyati that determined all events, including an individual’s fate. The seven caves were created by Mauryan time for the Ajivika Sect.

questions.question: As per the contents mentioned in Asokan inscriptions, how many major political centres were there in the Mauryan empire?
questions.explanation: Five. The five major political centres of the Mauryan empire were located at Pataliputra, Taxila, Ujjain, Tosali and Suvarnagiri.

questions.question: Which Mauryan ruler was called Amitrochates by the Greeks?
questions.explanation: Bindusara. He was the son of Chandragupta Maurya and was the second Mauryan emperor of India whose reign from 297 - 273 BCE.

questions.question: There were several cities in the Mauryan empire. Which of the following cities was located on the southernmost side?
questions.explanation: Brahmagiri. The Maurya Empire: Founder - Chandragupta Maurya, Capital - Pataliputra (modern Patna). Three important rulers of the Mauryan Empire - Chandragupta, his son Bindusara, and Bindusara’s son, Ashoka.

questions.question: Which of the following places does not contain the major inscription of Ashoka ?
questions.explanation: Sanchi. It is a famous Buddhist site with several stupas and monasteries. Language used in Ashoka’s inscriptions - Prakrit. Ashoka's name is only used in four of these locations: Maski, Brahmagiri (Karnataka), Gujjara (Madhya Pradesh) and Nettur (Andhra Pradesh).

questions.question: What was the purpose behind the Pillars of Ashoka?
questions.explanation: To spread the dharma of policies. Pillars are inscribed with edicts by the 3rd Mauryan Emperor Ashoka the Great (c. 268 to 232 BCE). There are seven pillar edicts. The Seventh Pillar Edict mentions Dhamma Mahamattas and it is the longest pillar almost of all.

questions.question: Which caves are considered as the oldest surviving rock-cut caves in India dating back to the Maurya period?
questions.explanation: Barabar and Nagarjuni caves - Located in Jehanabad district of Bihar, Constructed by Emperor Ashoka for the benefit of Ajivika ascetics. They were cut from a single solid granite block.

questions.question: Somewhat before the time of the Mauryan empire, about _______ years ago, emperors in China began building the Great Wall.
questions.explanation: 2400. Emperor Qin Shi Huang ordered construction of the Great Wall around 221 B.C. It was meant to protect the northern frontier of the empire from pastoral people. Q.116. Pushyamitra, who was the commander of Brihadratha, the last Mauryan emperor, killed the king and established a new dynasty. Which of the following was his dynasty? SSC CGL Tier II (06/03/2023) (a) Shunga (b) Kanva (c) Satavahana (d) Chedi History Sol.116.(a) Shunga Dynasty Founder - Pushyamitra Sunga. Ruled - From 185 BCE to 73 BCE. Last Ruler - Devabhuti. Kanva Dynasty Founder - Vasudeva Kanva. Ruled - From 73 BCE to 28 BCE. Last Ruler - Susarma. Satavahana Dynasty Founder - Simuka . Famous Ruler - Gautamiputra Satakarni.

questions.question: Ashoka appointed ______ to solve the social problems in his region.
questions.explanation: Dhamma Mahamatta. Tirthas: The highest category of officials in the administration. There were 18 Tirthas. Amatyas: High ranking officials almost like present-day secretaries. The important officials in the revenue department are Sannidhata: Chief treasury, Samaharta: collector general of revenue. Yuktas: Subordinate officers responsible for the Empire’s revenue. Rajjukas: Officers in charge of land measurement and boundary-fixing. Q.118. Which of the following statements is correct? I. Most of Ashoka’s inscriptions were written in Brahmi script. II. Many of Chanakya’s ideas were written down in a book called the Arthashastra. SSC MTS 08/07/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Only II (b) Only I (c) Neither I nor II (d) Both I and II Sol.118.(d) Both I and II. Brahmi Script was deciphered by James Prinsep.

questions.question: Ashokan Minor Rock Edicts are found in different parts of India. Which of the following is NOT a find spot of Ashokan Minor Rock Edicts in Karnataka?
questions.explanation: Rupnath. Minor rock edicts of Ashoka - Kandahar (Afghanistan), Lampaka (Afghanistan), Bahapur (Delhi), Bairat (Rajasthan), Bhabru (Rajasthan), Gujarra (Madhya Pradesh), Rupnath (Madhya Pradesh), Panguraria (Madhya Pradesh), Sasaram (Bihar), Barabar Caves (Bihar), Rajula-Mandagiri, Andhra Pradesh, Suvarna Giri (Andhra Pradesh), Brahmagiri (Karnataka), Jatina- Rameshwara, Karnataka, Siddapur (Karnataka), Maski (Karnataka), Nittur (Karnataka), Udegolam (Karnataka), Palkigundu and Gavimath (Karnataka).

questions.question: A type of court called 'Kantakasodhana' was prevalent in the ______ Empire.
questions.explanation: Mauryan Empire. It literally means ‘removal of the thorns’ and was used in reference to criminal justice in ancient India. Kautilya also mentioned the cases that are subject to Kantaka Shodhana in his book Arthashastra. Q.121. Who among the following published a set of Ashokan inscriptions in 1877 ? SSC CGL 20/08/2021 (Afternoon) (a) DC Sircar (b) MS Vats (c) Alexander Cunningham (d) Colin Mackenzie Sol.121.(c) Alexander Cunningham. He was the founder of the Archaeological Survey of India.

questions.question: Rudrasena II of which of the following dynasties married Prabhavatigupta, the daughter of Chandragupta II of the Gupta dynasty?
questions.explanation: Vakataka. The Vakataka dynasty: Founded by Vindhyashakti around 250-270 CE. The Vakatakas ruled over Central and Western India.

questions.question: The ________ were tributary chiefs of the Gupta dynasty. They established an independent kingdom in western India. Dhruvasena II was the most important ruler of this kingdom.
questions.explanation: Maitrakas established Valabhi as their capital and ruled until the middle of the eighth century. Dhruvasena II was a contemporary of Harshavardhana and was married to his daughter. Hsuan Tsang tells us that Dhruvasena II attended Harsha’s assembly at Prayaga (Allahabad). Maukharies ruled over Kannauj, a city in western Uttar Pradesh, they were also the subordinate rulers of the Guptas and used the title of samanta.

questions.question: Who among the following was the author of 'Brihat Katha Kosh'?
questions.explanation: Harisena. He was a Sanskrit writer and poet in the court of Samudragupta. "Brihat Katha Kosh" is a collection of ancient Indian folk tales and legends. Bhavabhuti is believed to be the court poet of King Yashovarman of Kannauj. His famous plays are Mahaviracharita, Malatimadhava.

questions.question: Kalidasa was a famous poet in the court of________.
questions.explanation: Chandragupta II, also known as Vikramaditya, ruled from 380 to 415 CE and was a renowned patron of arts and literature. Kalidasa's notable works, such as "Abhijnanasakuntalam", "Meghaduta", and "Raghuvamsa", showcase his mastery of Sanskrit literature.

questions.question: Harisena, the author of Prayag Prashasti, was the court poet of which of the following Gupta emperors ?
questions.explanation: Samudragupta. He was the son and successor of Chandragupta I and was the greatest ruler of the Gupta dynasty. The Allahabad Pillar inscription, also called Prayag Prashasti, was composed by Harishena.

questions.question: Gupta emperor Chandragupta I was the first ruler to adopt which of the following titles?
questions.explanation: Maharajadhiraja. Chandragupta I, the son of Gupta king Ghatotkacha and grandson of the dynasty's founder Sri Gupta, is referred to as Maharaja in the Allahabad Pillar inscription, while his successor, Kumaragupta, adopted the title "Mahendraditya."

questions.question: The Chinese Buddhist pilgrim Fa Hien visited India during the reign of which of the following Gupta emperors?
questions.explanation: Chandragupta II, also known History as Vikramaditya, was the third ruler of the Gupta Empire. He is often identified with King Chandra from the Delhi iron pillar inscription. Notable Travellers and Their Visits - Abdul Razzak (Iran): Deva Raya II. Francois Bernier (France): Shah Jahan, Ibn Batuta (Morocco): Mohammed Bin Tughlaq, Megasthenes (Greece): Chandragupta Maurya, Thomas Roe and William Hawkins (Britain): Jahangir, Hwien Tsang (China): Harsha Vardhana.

questions.question: The paintings in the Bagh caves belong to which of the following periods?
questions.explanation: Gupta. Bagh Caves are located in Gwalior (Madhya Pradesh). These are a group of nine rock-cut monuments. These caves were founded by the Buddhist monk Dataka. Caves in India - Undavalli caves (Andhra Pradesh), Barabar Caves (Bihar), Badami Cave Temples (Karnataka), Udaygiri Caves (Madhya Pradesh), Ajanta Caves and Ellora Caves (Maharashtra). Q.130. The Vakataka dynasty was directly related to which Gupta emperor? SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (4th shift) (a) Chandra Gupta I (b) Shree Gupta (c) Samudra Gupta (d) Chandra Gupta II Sol.130.(d) Chandra Gupta II. Vakataka dynasty : Founded by Vindhyashakti in 250 CE. Ajanta caves (numbers ⅩⅥ, ⅩⅦ, ⅩⅨ) are the best examples of Vakataka excellence in the field of painting. Q.131. In which period is the first inscriptional example of the practice of Sati found? SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th shift) (a) Maukhari (b) Vardhana (c) Satavahana (d) Gupta Sol.131.(d) Gupta. Practice of Sati has been found in the Eran Pillar Inscription of Bhanugupta, Madhya Pradesh. Sati Movement : Raja Ram Mohan Roy described ‘Sati’ as ‘murder’ according to every shastra. By his efforts, Bengal Sati Regulation Act was passed to criminalize the practice of Sati in 1829.

questions.question: The famous source of the Gupta empire, the Prayaga Prashasti is also known as the ________
questions.explanation: Allahabad pillar inscription composed in Sanskrit by Harishena, the court poet of Samudragupta. Q.133. Who was the court poet of Harshavardhana? SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Hema Saraswati (b) Parmanand (c) Banabhatta (d) Sri Ponna Sol.133.(c) Banabhatta - His teacher's name was Bhatsu or Bharvu. Banabhatta's three works are famous - “Harshacharita”, “Kadambari” and “Chandishtak”. Harshvardhan was the ruler of the Pushyabhuti dynasty of Thaneshwar. Q.134. Who among the following Navratnas from Chandragupta II court wrote 'Mantrashastra’ ? SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Morning) (a) Kalidasa (b) Ghatakarapara (c) Vetala Bhatta (d) Amarasimha Sol.134.(c) Vetala Bhatta. Nine jewels (Navratna) of Chandragupta II - Amarasimha, Dhanvantari, Harisena, Kalidasa, Kshapanaka, Shanku, Varahamihira, Varuchi, Vetala-Bhatta.

questions.question: The reign of Kumaragupta I the son and successor of _____ was one of peace and relative inactivity.
questions.explanation: Chandragupta II (successor of Samudragupta). Kumaragupta I : He was also known as Shakraditya and Mahendraditya. He founded Nalanda Mahavihara in 5th century CE. His successor - Skandagupta.

questions.question: Which king was shown on his coins as a Veena player?
questions.explanation: Samudragupta - He was a ruler of the Gupta dynasty. On several of his coins, he was depicted as seated on a sofa and playing a Veena. He is known as the Napoleon of India. He was given the title of Kaviraj.

questions.question: After the victory over Sakas, who among the following adopted the title of 'Vikramaditya"?
questions.explanation: Chandragupta II - He was the son of Samudragupta and Datta Devi. He ruled the Gupta Empire from 380 to 415 AD during the Golden Age of India. He established the Mehrauli iron pillar. Q.138. Who among the following succeeded Ghatotkacha, the Gupta ruler? SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Evening) (a) Kumaragupta I (b) Chandragupta I (c) Chandragupta II (d) Skandagupta Sol.138.(b) Chandragupta I. Founder - Sri Gupta, Next Successors - Ghatotkacha, Chandragupta I, Samudragupta, Chandragupta II, Kumaragupta I (founded Nalanda University).

questions.question: Ruler of which dynasty built the famous Iron pillar in Delhi?
questions.explanation: Gupta dynasty. In Mehrauli (Delhi) an iron pillar was constructed by the famous king Chandragupta II, India, notable for the rust-resistant composition of the metal used in its construction. The inscription on the pillar is in Sanskrit, about Gupta emperor Chandragupta II.

questions.question: Which of the following offices was NOT held by the poet Harishena?
questions.explanation: Nagara-shreshthi (Chief banker or merchant). Offices held by Poet Harishena: Maha-danda-Nayaka (Chief Judicial Officer), Kumar-amatya (Important minister) and a sandhi - vigrahika (Minister of War and Peace). Q.141. Fa Xian began his journey back home from which of the following Indian state? SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (1st Shift) (a) Bihar (b) Maharashtra (c) Bengal (d) Odisha Sol.141.(c) Bengal. Fa-Xian (Chinese traveller) started his journey back home from Bengal by boarding a merchant ship. He traveled from China to India on foot to acquire Buddhist texts. He came to India, under the reign of Chandragupta II, and arrived at Pataliputra from the northwest.

questions.question: Samudragupta's mother belonged to which of the following gana?
questions.explanation: Licchavi. Samudragupta (335 -375 CE, Kaviraja) was the son of Chandragupta I and Queen Kumaradevi (Licchavi clan). He is called ‘Napoleon of India’ by V.A. Smith. Q.143. In the context of Gupta administration, the term 'vithi' referred to a/an: SSC MTS 05/10/2021 (Evening) (a) elephantry unit (b) administrative unit (c) personal guard of the king (d) soldier Sol.143.(b) Administrative unit. In Gupta's period, there was a hierarchy of administrative divisions from top to bottom. The empire was called by various names such as Rajya, Rashtra, Desha, Mandala, Prithvi, and Avani. It was divided into provinces, which were further divided into Vishayas. A Vishayapati administered the Vishaya. A part of the Vishaya was called Vithi.

questions.question: Who among the following Gupta rulers married a girl from the Lichchhavi clan?
questions.explanation: Chandragupta-I. The Lichchhavi clan was headquartered at Vaishali in present-day Bihar during the time of Gautama Buddha.

questions.question: Which of the following plays was NOT written by Harshavardhana ?
questions.explanation: Vikramorvasiyam is a romantic play written by Kalidasa, based on the legend of King Pururava and an Apsara named Urvashi. Kalidasa's works include: Abhijnanasakuntalam, Malavikagnimitram, Kumarasambhavam.

questions.question: Pulakeshin II assumed the title of ‘Dakshinapatheshvara’ (lord of the south) after defeating which of the following rulers of north India?
questions.explanation: Harshavardhana (606-647 AD) belonged to the Pushyabhuti dynasty, also known as the Vardhana dynasty. He wanted to extend his power in the Deccan but he was defeated by Pulakesin II, the Chalukya ruler, on the bank of river Narmada. The river thus became the southern boundary of his kingdom. Vardhana dynasty: Founder - Pushyabhuti. Capital: Thanesar (Thaneshwar), later Kannauj (Kanyakubja). Q.147. Pushyabhuti dynasty, after Prabhakarvardhana, strengthened its position in the regions of Punjab and Haryana after defeating which of the following dynasties? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Maukharis (b) Hunas (c) Chalukyas (d) Maitrakas Sol.147.(b) Hunas. The Pushyabhuti dynasty (Vardhana dynasty) ruled northern India during the 6th and 7th centuries, emerging after the Gupta Empire's decline. Its core territory was in present-day Haryana, with Sthanishvara (Thaneshwar) as the capital. The dynasty reached its peak under Harsha Vardhana, who reigned from 606 to 647 AD.

questions.question: Thaneswar where the Vardhana dynasty ruled around the present-day state of _______.
questions.explanation: Haryana. Q.149. According to which of the following foreign travellers did Dhruvasena II attend Harsha’s assembly at Prayag (Allahabad)? SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023 (a) Marco Polo (b) Hiuen Tsang (c) Fa-Hien (d) I-tsing Sol.149.(b) Hiuen Tsang (Xuanzang) - Chinese Buddhist monk who travelled from China to India to study Buddhism and obtain Buddhist scriptures during the reign of King Harsha Vardhan. Assembly of Prayag (Maha Moksha Parishad) - Harsha Vardhan gave all his belongings in charity for the welfare of the public.

questions.question: Who sent an envoy to the Chinese court in 641 AD?
questions.explanation: Harsha Vardhan. In 641 AD Harshavardhan sent an envoy to Taizong (Tai-Tsung), the Tang emperor of China and in return, the Chinese ruler sent three embassies to Harsha court. Q.151. After about years of Harshavardhana's death ______ rose to power in Kannauj. SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening) (a) Yashovarman (b) Yadagiri (c) Mahendravarman (d) Pulakeshin II Sol.151.(a) Yashovarman. He was the founder of the Varman dynasty of Kanauj and surrounding areas during the 8th and the 9th centuries. Q.152. What was the period of Harshavardhana's reign? SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (3rd shift) (a) 647 CE to 700 CE (b) 570 CE to 610 CE (c) 606 CE to 647 CE (d) 545 CE to 570 CE Sol.152.(c) CE to CE. Harshavardhana - Last ruler of the Vardhana Empire (Pushyabhuti dynasty); Undisputed ruler of Thaneshwar (modern -day Haryana). He was author of three Sanskrit plays - Nagananda, Ratnavali, Priyadarshika.

questions.question: King Shashanka, against whom Harshvardhana declared war, was a ruler of the ______ kingdom.
questions.explanation: Gauda. Karnasubarna was the capital of Gauda Kingdom during the reign of Shashanka, the first important king of ancient Bengal who ruled in the 7th century. Chola Dynasty Q.154. With reference to medieval history, consider the following statements. 1. The founder of the Chola dynasty called the ‘Imperial Cholas’ was Vijayalaya (9th century AD). 2. One of the important dynasties which ruled in northern India was Gurjara-Pratiharas. 3. Palas ruled in western India and Rashtrakutas ruled in southern India in the early years (750 -1000). Which of the given statement(s) is/are correct? SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (1st Shift) (a) 1 and 2 only (b) 1 and 3 only (c) 2 only (d) 1 only History Sol.154.(a) 1 and 2 only. The successors of Vijayalaya expanded the Chola kingdom by annexing Pandyan and Pallava territories. Rajaraja I, who became king in 985, strengthened and reorganized the empire. His son, Rajendra I, further extended the Chola influence with expeditions to the Ganga valley, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia, supported by a powerful navy. Palas ruled in eastern India and Rashtrakutas ruled in the Deccan region.

questions.question: One of the greatest of Chola rulers, Rajaraja I ruled from 985 AD to ______.
questions.explanation: 1014 AD. The Chola Empire was founded by Vijayalaya. Rajaraja I was known for his conquests of South India and parts of Sri Lanka. He built the great Brihadisvara Temple at the Chola capital Thanjavur.

questions.question: Which of the following animals was the emblem of the Chola dynasty?
questions.explanation: Tiger. Three dynasties ruled during the Sangam Age. Cheras: Modern-Day City (Kerala), Ancient Capital (Vanji), Important Ports (Musiri, Tondi), Emblem (Bow and Arrow). Cholas: Modern-Day City (Tamil Nadu), Ancient Capital (Uraiyur, Puhar), Important Ports (Kaveripattinam). Pandyas: Modern-Day City (Tamil Nadu), Ancient Capital (Madurai), Important Ports {Muziris (Muchiri), Korkai, Kaveri}, Emblem (Carp).

questions.question: Brihadiswara Temple of Tanjore was built by which of the following Chola emperors?
questions.explanation: Raja Raja Chola. The Brihadisvara Temple (Dravidian-style) also known as Raja Rajeswara Temple is dedicated to Shiva. It was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987.

questions.question: Which among the following Chola emperors defeated the Pandya king Maravarman Rajsimha II in the battle of Vellore?
questions.explanation: Parantaka I. Rajaraja I, the son of Parantaka II, is the most celebrated of the Chola kings and ascended the throne in 985 AD. Rajendra I, the son of Rajaraja I, became the first Chola king to venture to the banks of the Ganges, earning the title "Victor of the Ganges."

questions.question: Name the Chola inscription that provided details of the way in which the sabha was organised in the local administration in the Chola empire.
questions.explanation: Uttaramerur inscription. It dated 919 CE and 921 CE of the Chola king Parantaka I provides evidence of India's long history of democratic government.

questions.question: In the 11th century, the army of which of the following Cholas reached upto Ganga to invade Bengal?
questions.explanation: Rajendra I (1014 and 1044 CE) - He was also known as Gangaikonda Chola. He defeated Mahipala, the Pala king of Bengal and Bihar.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers invaded Malaya to liberate their trade with China?
questions.explanation: Chola dynasty.

questions.question: Sabha and Ur, two kinds of village assemblies are referred to in which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: Chola. Ur - Assembly of common villagers. Sabha - Assembly in the villages which were inhabited predominantly by the Brahmanas. Nagaram - Assembly of merchants, traders and artisans.

questions.question: "Brahmadeya", a type of land during the Chola Period was the ________.
questions.explanation: Land gifted to Brahmans. There were five types of 'land gifts' that Chola kings gave to their people on the basis of Chola inscriptions : Vellanvagai - For non-Brahmana, peasant proprietors. Shalabhoga - For the maintenance of a school. Devadana or Tirunamattukkani - Land gifted to temples. Pallichchhandam - Land donated to Jaina institutions. Q.164. The Airavatesvara Temple in Tamil Nadu was built by _________ . SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Rajaraja Chola II (b) Rajaraja Chola I (c) Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II (d) Maharaja Pratap Singh Sol.164.(a) Rajaraja Chola II. Airavatesvara Temple is a Hindu temple built in the Dravidian style of architecture. Dedicated to - Lord Shiva.

questions.question: The term "Vetti" in Chola empire is related to ___________
questions.explanation: Forced labour. Some types of taxes in Cholas empire: Kadmai or Irai - Tax on land; Pattam and ayam - Taxes imposed on non-agricultural professions like artisans and merchants; Nirvilai or nirkkirai - Water tax; Ulku and sungam - Toll tax; Tattar-pattam - A tax levied on gold -smiths; Sangam - Export and import taxes; Kannala Kanam - Marriage tax; Poorvi - War tax.

questions.question: Sultan Mahmud of Ghazni was a contemporary of which Chola king?
questions.explanation: Rajendra I who ruled from 1014 to 1044 CE. Ghazni invaded India seventeen times. In 1018 he plundered the holy city of Mathura and also attacked Kannauj.

questions.question: In the early eleventh century, the Chola king Rajendra I built a Shiva temple and filled it with a Sun-pedestal seized from the ______.
questions.explanation: Chalukyas. Chola king Rajendra-I (reigned between 1014 and 1044 CE) built a Shiva temple in his capital, Gangaikondacholapuram (north Tamil Nadu) and filled it with prized statues seized from defeated rulers such History as Sun-pedestal (Chalukyas), a Ganesha statue and several statues of Durga, a Nandi statue, an image of Bhairava and Bhairavi (Kalingas of Orissa), and a Kali statue (Palas of Bengal). Q.168. Who among the following belonged to the ancient chiefly family of the Cholas from Uraiyur, captured the Kaveri delta from the Muttaraiyar in the middle of the ninth century ? SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (1st Shift) (a) Gandaraditya (b) Vijayalaya (c) Parantaka I (d) Aditya I Sol.168.(b) Vijayalaya founded the Chola Empire and captured Thanjavur (Capital of Chola Empire) in CE. He constructed a temple for the goddess Nishumbhasudini in Thanjavur.

questions.question: Which of the following towns was grown as a temple town during the Chola dynasty?
questions.explanation: Bhillasvamin. Famous Chola dynasty temples: Moovar Koil (Kodumbalur), Koranganatha (Musiri), Valisvara Temple, Kampaheswarar Temple (Thirubuvanam). All temples mentioned above are in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which of the following territories to the south and north were made part of the Chola kingdom by the successors of the ruler Vijayalaya?
questions.explanation: Pandaya and Pallava. The Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE, Capital - Kanchipuram) ruled in Deccan (Tondaimandalam). Pandya (Capital - Madurai). The Cheras (Capital - Vanji), Greatest ruler of Cheras - Senguttuvan, also known as Red Chera.

questions.question: Which dynasty bronze statues were made using the "lost wax" technique?
questions.explanation: Chola. Bronze is an alloy of copper and tin. The lost wax technique is a method of metal casting in which molten metal is poured into a mold that has been created by means of a wax model. Examples: Nataraja Bronze Casting, Shiva and Parvati (Sivagami, 1012 CE), etc.

questions.question: Puhar or Kaveripattinam, was the port of which of the following dynasty?
questions.explanation: Cholas (8th-12th century AD) was founded by Vijayalaya in the 8th century. Rajaraja Chola (greatest king of the Chola Empire) reigned between 985 and 1014 C.E.

questions.question: Who excavated the Chira Tope stupa at Taxila?
questions.explanation: John Marshall. Dharmarajika Stupa in Taxila, Pakistan is also known as Chir Tope, which means "Scarred hill". Q.181. Which among the following dynasties originated from the Yueh-chih tribe of China? SSC MTS 14/11/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Guptas (b) Satavahanas (c) Parthians (d) Kushanas Sol.181.(d) Kushanas. They migrated from China to Bactria, then to areas of Afghanistan and finally into India around the 1st century CE.

questions.question: Details about Sudarshana lake are given in a rock inscription at Girnar (Junagarh), which was composed to record the achievements of the Shaka ruler _________.
questions.explanation: Rudradaman I. Junagadh inscription is written in the Sanskrit​ language. It is located near Girnar hill near Junagadh in Gujarat. The Junagadh rock contains inscriptions of Ashoka (one of the fourteen Major Rock Edicts of Ashoka), Rudradaman I and Skandagupta. Q.183. Silappathikaram (the Jewelled Anklet), the earliest epic poem in Tamil was written in the 5th - 6th Century CE by _________. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Tolkappiyar (b) Ilango Adigal (c) Sittalai Sattanar (d) Tirumalisai Alwar Sol.183.(b) Ilango Adigal. Ancient Tamil literature is known as Sangama Literature. The Sangam literature includes Tolkappiyam, Ettutogai, Pattuppattu, Pathinenkilkanakku, and two epics named – Silappathikaram, and Manimegalai (Written by Sittalai Sattanar). The earliest known work in ancient Tamil is Agastyam.

questions.question: In the 7th Century AD, a new religion called Islam was born in _______ .
questions.explanation: Arabia. Prophet Muhammad established Islam. He was born around AD in Mecca. In AD, he completed the Hegira, his migration from Mecca to Medina, to escape persecution. Q.185. Gautamiputra Satakarni titled Rajaraja and Maharaja is related to which of the following dynasties? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Shunga (b) Pandya (c) Satavahana (d) Shaka Sol.185.(c) The Satavahana Dynasty, founded by Simuk, primarily encompassed present-day Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Telangana, along with portions of Gujarat, Karnataka, and Madhya Pradesh. Q.186. Valabhi, a city of ancient India was the capital of the __________ dynasty from the 5th to 8th Century CE. SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Maitraka (b) Chalukya (c) Pallava (d) Vakataka Sol.186.(a) Maitraka. The Maitraka dynasty was founded by Senapati Bhatarka. The decline of the Gupta Empire led to the rise of various ruling dynasties across northern India. Among the most notable were the Pushyabhutis of Thanesar, the Maukhari of Kanauj, and the Maitrakas of Valabhi.

questions.question: Vasudeva I who issued coins in gold (dinars and quarter dinars) and copper (single denomination) was a ________ king.
questions.explanation: Kushana. Vasudeva I was the last of the "Great Kushans." He ruled in Northern India and Central Asia, where he minted coins in the city of Balkh. The Kushana dynasty was founded by Kujula Kadphises.

questions.question: Who among the following is the hero of the Sanskrit historical poem, the 'Ramacharita' written by Sandhyakar Nandi?
questions.explanation: Ramapala was the successor to the Pala king Shurapala II in the Bengal region of the Indian subcontinent, and 15th ruler of the Pala line. Sandhyakar Nandi was patronaged by Madanapala, ruler of Pala Dynasty.

questions.question: Vindhyashakti was the founder of which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: Vakataka dynasty originated from the Deccan in the mid-3rd century CE. Vakatakas were the most important successors of the Satavahanas in the Deccan and coexistent with the Guptas in northern India. Q.190. An inscription, Takht-i-Bahi recovered from Mardan near Peshawar, indicates the rule of which of the following dynasties in north-western area of present Pakistan? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Bactrian (b) Sakas (c) Indo-Greek (d) Parthians Sol.190.(d) Parthians (247 BC - 224 AD). It was founded by Arsaces I of Parthia when he rebelled against the Seleucid Empire. They replaced the Sakas in North-Western India. The Takht-i-Bahi inscription, dated in 45 AD, refers to Gondophernes as a Parthian ruler.

questions.question: The Maukharis ruled over which of the following cities in western Uttar Pradesh that over the time replaced Pataliputra as a political centre of north India?
questions.explanation: Kannauj. The Maukharis, initially vassals of the Guptas and titled Samantas, gained independence in the mid-6th century as the Gupta Empire declined.

questions.question: Under which of the following Pala king's patronage the Vikramshila university in 8th century India was founded?
questions.explanation: Dharmapala, the second ruler of the Pala Dynasty, ascended the throne around AD after Gopala and expanded the empire significantly. He defeated Indrayudha of Kanauj, installing Chakrayudha as his nominee, but later faced defeat by Rashtrakuta king Dhruva near Monghyr, Bihar.

questions.question: Three Poets Pampa, Ponna and Ranna are called as the ‘Three Jewels’ of:
questions.explanation: Kannada Literature. Pampa, also known as Adi Pampa, is renowned for his literary works, including "Vikramarjuna Vijaya" and "Adi Purana." Ponna, often referred to as Ponna Kavishwara, served as a court poet for Rashtrakuta king Krishna III and is best known for his epic "Shantipurana." Ranna was a court poet of the Western Chalukya Empire, and his most celebrated work is "Gadayuddha."

questions.question: Which of the following kingdoms was divided into subdivisions called Aharas or Rashtras that meant districts?
questions.explanation: Satavahana : Period : 60 BC - 225 AD; Capital - Pratishthana (Paithan) and Amravati; Founder - Simuka. The lowest level of administration was a grama which was under the charge of a Gramika. There were also officers called amatyas who were perhaps ministers or advisors of the king. Revenue was collected both in cash and kind. It majorly comprised present Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Maharashtra.

questions.question: ______, authored by Tolkappiyar is the earliest Tamil literature.
questions.explanation: Tolkappiyam. Tamil has a literary tradition that goes back to the period of the Sangams. The most well-known surviving works from this period are the Tolkappiyam (a book of grammar attributed to Tolkappiyar), Ettu Togai (Eight Anthologies), Pattu Pattu (Ten Idylls).

questions.question: The Pandya Kingdom was first mentioned by Megasthenes, who said that their kingdom was famous for pearls. Their capital was :
questions.explanation: Madurai. Megasthenes: A Greek diplomat and historian who mentioned the Pandya Kingdom in his book Indica around 300 BCE. The Pandya Kingdom was an ancient Tamil kingdom that ruled parts of southern India, especially Tamil Nadu, from the 6th century BCE to the 15th century CE.

questions.question: In peninsular India, which of the following kingdoms was the local power that ruled over northern Maharashtra and Vidarbha?
questions.explanation: Vakatakas. Vindhyashakti founded the Vakataka dynasty in the third century. Their history is mainly known through land grant charters issued to Brahmanas. The Maukhari dynasty ruled over (modern day) Uttar Pradesh and parts of Bihar.

questions.question: In 10th century India, Queen Didda became the ruler of which of the following regions of north India?
questions.explanation: Kashmir. Didda was the ruler of Kashmir from 980 CE to 1003 CE. Most knowledge relating to Didda is obtained from the Rajatarangini. Ashish Kaul's novel Didda: The Warrior Queen of Kashmir is based on Didda's life.

questions.question: Mahendravarman I who wrote Mattavilasa-prahasana is related to which of the following ruling dynasties?
questions.explanation: Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE) - They ruled a significant portion of the Deccan, also known as Tondaimandalam, which covered parts of present-day Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. Founder - Simha Vishnu (Avanisimha).

questions.question: The Pratiharas who first had their capital at Bhinmal gained prominence during the rule of:
questions.explanation: Nagabhatta I (Reign : 730 - AD) laid the foundation of the Pratihara dynasty's power. He is best known for defeating the Arabs during their expansion and building an empire that stretched from Gujarat to Gwalior, stopping further Arab invasions in eastern Sindh. Q.201. According to the inscriptions, Pushyamitra Shunga was a devotee of which of the following Gods? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Rama (b) Shiva (c) Krishna (d) Indra Sol.201.(c) Krishna. Pushyamitra Shunga founded the Shunga Empire after assassinating the last Mauryan emperor, Brihadratha Maurya. He ruled from 184 BC to 75 BC, driving out the Greeks through the Shunga-Greek war. The capital of the Shunga Empire was Pataliputra.

questions.question: Who among the following Pallava kings occupied Vatapi (Badami) and defeated the Chalukyas?
questions.explanation: Narasimhavarman. Pulakesin II, a ruler of the Chalukya dynasty, reigned from 610 CE to 642 CE, expanding his empire across much of the Deccan region. However, in 642-643 CE, Pallava king Narasimha Varman I defeated Pulakesin II when his general, Shiruttondar Paranjoti, captured the Chalukya capital, Vatapi. Simhavishnu is regarded as the founder of the Pallava dynasty, a Tamil dynasty that ruled parts of South India from the 3rd to the 9th century.

questions.question: In the context of Mathura school of Art, during which of the following periods were a number of sculptures of Brahmanical deities, such as Kartikeya, Vishnu and Kubera carved?
questions.explanation: The Kushan Empire was a syncretic empire established by the Yuezhi in the Bactrian territories in the early 1st century. The Mathura School of Art flourished under the Kushana emperor Kanishka during the first century AD.

questions.question: Which power were the Badami (or Vatapi) Chalukyas originally subjects of ?
questions.explanation: The Kadambas ruled from Banavasi in present-day Karnataka, marking a significant period in the early medieval history of the Deccan region. Badami was the capital of the early Chalukyan dynasty, which governed the area from 543 to 598 CE. With the decline of the Vakataka rule, the Chalukyas established their dominance in the Deccan. Q.205. Which of the following statements about the Pala Dynasty of eastern India is INCORRECT? History SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Devapala was the grandson of Gopala. (b) Dharmapala founded the Valabhi university. (c) The Pala kings were the followers of Buddhism. (d) The Pala dynasty was founded by Gopala. Sol.205.(b) The Vallabhi University was founded by Bhattarka, the king of the Maitraka Empire, not Dharmapala. Pala Dynasty: The Pala dynasty was founded by Gopala, probably around 750 AD. Dharmapala was the second ruler of the Pala Empire.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers was a part of the Tripartite Struggle for the possession of Kannauj?
questions.explanation: Dharmapala. The Tripartite Struggle, also known as the Kannauj Triangle Wars, took place in the 8th and 9th centuries, between the three dynasties - The Palas of Bengal, The Pratiharas of Central India and The Rashtrakutas of Deccan. Q.207. The founder of the Pallava dynasty was: SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift) (a) Balasimha (b) Simharaj (c) Singhamvishnu (d) Simhavishnu Sol.207.(d) Simhavishnu (575-590 AD). He was the first Pallava monarch whose domain extended beyond Kanchipuram (Kanchi) in the South. Rise : Defeating Kalabhras inaugurated the rule of imperial Pallavas. Royal Titles: Avanisimha (lion of the Earth). His court poet Bharavi - Wrote Kiratarjuniya.

questions.question: Bilhan was a court poet in which of the following kingdoms ?
questions.explanation: Vikramaditya VI. The Chalukya dynasty was established by Pulakeshin I in 543. He took Vatapi (modern Badami in Bagalkot district, Karnataka) under his control and made it his capital. He and his descendants are referred to as "Chalukyas of Badami".

questions.question: Which of the following was the port-city of the Pandyan Kingdom?
questions.explanation: Korkai. Pandya dynasty (4th century BCE to the 17th century CE): Capital - Madurai, Founder - Mudathirumaran.

questions.question: Dantivarman or Dantidurga was the founder of which of the following dynasties ?
questions.explanation: Rashtrakuta. Manyakheta was the capital of the Rashtrakuta kingdom. The Elichpur clan, initially a feudatory of the Badami Chalukyas, rose to power under Dantidurga by overthrowing Chalukya ruler Kirtivarman II and establishing an empire in the Gulbarga region. This clan became known as the Rashtrakutas of Manyakheta, who emerged as a significant power in Maharashtra-Karnataka region.

questions.question: Krishna III of Rashtrakuta dynasty established a victory pillar and a temple at which of the following cities of south India after defeating the Chola ruler Parantaka I ?
questions.explanation: Rameswaram. Krishna III whose Kannada name was Kannara (939 – 967 C.E.) was the last great warrior and able monarch of the Rashtrakuta dynasty {Founder: Dantivarman}. Its Capital - Manyakheta. Parantaka I was known as the destroyer of Madurai (the capital city of the Pandyas).

questions.question: In Andhra region, who among the following translated a few portions of Mahabharata in Telugu?
questions.explanation: Nanniah (Nannayya) is regarded as the first poet of Telugu literature and is part of the famous "Trinity of Poets" (comprising Nannaya, Tikkana and Erra Pragada) in Telugu literature. He began the translation of the Mahabharata from Sanskrit into Telugu during the 11th century under the patronage of the Eastern Chalukya king, Rajaraja Narendra.

questions.question: Manyakheta or Malkhed was the capital of which of the following kingdoms?
questions.explanation: Rashtrakuta. Dantidurga was the founder of the Rashtrakuta empire who fixed his capital at Manyakheta or Malkhed near modern Sholapur.

questions.question: During the reign of which of the Pallava kings was the shore temple at Mahabalipuram built ?
questions.explanation: Narasimhavarman II, also known as Rajasimha, ruled the Pallava dynasty from 700 to 728 CE. He also constructed the Kailasanatha Temple in Kanchipuram.

questions.question: Rajataranagini, the book authored by Kalhana in 12th Century was originally written in which of the following languages?
questions.explanation: Sanskrit. The word "Rajatarangini" means "River of Kings." This book chronicles the history of the northwestern Indian subcontinent, specifically the kings of Kashmir. It contains 7,826 verses divided into eight sections known as Tarangas (waves).

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of the Gurjara-Pratihara dynasty in the region of Malwa in the eighth century?
questions.explanation: Nagabhatta I. The Gurjara - Pratiharas Dynasty (8th-11th Century A.D.) ruled over northern and western India. Nagabhatta I established an empire extending from Gujarat to Gwalior and defied the Arab invasions towards further east of Sindh. Q.217. Which of the following statements are true regarding the Ravana Phadi cave at Aihole. 1. Nataraja is the important structure at this site. 2. This Nataraja image is surrounded on the right by four large saptamatrikas and on the left by three large ones. 3. The figures have slim, graceful bodies with long oval faces. 4. The temple shows a distinct feature of Pandya architecture of mixing and incorporation of several styles. Higher Secondary 21/06/2024 (Shift - 2) History (a) 1, 2 and 4 (b) 2, 3 and 4 (c) 1, 3 and 4 (d) 1, 2 and 3 Sol.217.(d) 1, 2 and 3. The Ravan Phadi cave, located in Aihole, Karnataka, is an example of early Chalukyan architecture. The First capital of the Chalukya Dynasty was Aihole which is clear from the inscriptions found in the caves of Aihole. The bronze sculpture of Nataraja was cast during the period of the Cholas dynasty. Q.218. Consider the following statements regarding Kailashnath Temple, Ellora. 1. It is built completely in the Dravidian style. 2. Its main deity is Lord Shiva. 3. This temple was carved out of a portion of a hill. 4. It was built during the Chola phase at Ellora. Which of the given statements is correct ? Graduate Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Only 2, 3 and 4 (b) Only 1, 2 and 3 (c) Only 1, 2 and 4 (d) Only 1, 3 and 4 Sol.218.(b) Only 1, 2 and 3. The Kailasa temple at Ellora was built by the Rashtrakuta king Krishna I in the 8th century. Located in Cave 16, it is dedicated to Lord Shiva and was carved from a single rock. Named after Mount Kailash, it is the largest of the 34 Buddhist, Jain, and Hindu cave temples at Ellora and was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983. Q.219. Who among the following Kushana kings was the founder of the Kushana dynasty? Graduate Level 24/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Vasudeva I (b) Vima Kadphises (c) Huvishka (d) Kujula Kadphises Sol.219.(d) Kujula Kadphises. Kushan Dynasty (First-Third Century) : Kanishka - He administered the territory from two capitals : Purushapura (now Peshawar in northern Pakistan) and Mathura. Vasudeva I - Last Kushana Ruler.

questions.question: Kathasaritasagara, a collection of stories, was written in which of the following languages?
questions.explanation: Sanskrit. The Kathasaritsagara (Ocean of Story) written in the 11th century by Somadeva. Other Sanskrit Literature: Buddhacarita - Ashvaghosa; Malavikagnimitram - Kalidasa; Harshacharita - Banabhatta. Q.221. Which of the following statements about the Kushana dynasty is INCORRECT? Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) The Kushanas were a major ruling group in the post-Mauryan period. (b) Many Kushana rulers also adopted the title ‘devaputra’, or ‘son of god’. (c) The First Buddhist Council was organised by Kanishka. (d) Asvaghosha, the author of the Buddhacharita, was the court poet of Kanishka. Sol.221.(c) The First Buddhist Council was held during the reign of King Ajatashatru of the Haryanka Dynasty in Rajgriha. Kanishka belonged to the Kushan dynasty, which was founded by Kujula Kadphises. The Fourth Buddhist Council was held under the patronage of Kanishka in Kashmir.

questions.question: Which of the following rulers is considered as the greatest king of Satavahana dynasty and is described as the destroyer of the Sakas, Yavanas and Pahlavas?
questions.explanation: Gautamiputra Satakarni. He is renowned for his military conquests and is described in the Nasik inscription as the "destroyer of the Sakas, Yavanas, and Pahlavas." He also used the title of 'Ekabrahaman,' which means the Peerless Brahman. Simuka was the founder of the Satavahana dynasty. Hala was the seventeenth king of the Satavahana Dynasty. Q.223. Who was the author of “Mahabhashya”? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning) (a) Bana (b) Panini (c) Patanjali (d) Kautilya Sol.223.(c) Patanjali. “The Yoga Sutra” was also written by Patanjali. Authors and their books: Kalhana - “Rajatarangini”. Vatsayana - “Kamasutra”. Vishnu Sharma - “Panchatantra”. Kautilya - “Arthasastra”. Panini - “Ashtadhyayi”. Megasthenes - “Indica”. Jayadeva - “Gitagovinda”. Sri Harsha - “Naishadha Charita”. Banabhatta - “Harshacharita”, “Kadambari”.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties succeeded the Palas of Bengal ?
questions.explanation: Senas Dynasty: A hindu dynasty that ruled over eastern Bengal and western Bihar for about two centuries. Important Rulers - Vijaya Sena, Ballal Sena, Lakshmana Sena. Deva dynasty - Ruled over eastern Bengal after the Sena dynasty.

questions.question: Who had Sialkot as his capital ?
questions.explanation: Menander: A Greek king who ruled over the Indo-Greek kingdom. Demetrios (Greek king): His capital was Takshashila. Eucratides: Expanded the Indo-Greek territories into Bactria and the northern regions of India. Pushyamitra Sunga - An Indian king who ruled over the Sunga dynasty. His capital was Pataliputra. Q.226. To which of the following dynasties were the Vatapi Chalukyas tributary princes? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening) (a) Kalyani Chalukyas (b) Cholas (c) Pallavas (d) Kadambas Sol.226.(d) Kadamba dynasty (Founder - Mayurasharma) was an ancient Indian dynasty that ruled over parts of South India, particularly the present-day Karnataka region, from the 4th to the 6th centuries CE.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of locations are famous for Buddhist railings and gateways?
questions.explanation: Bharhut and Amravati. Bharhut Stupa is located in Satna, Madhya Pradesh. It was discovered in a ruined state by Alexander Cunningham and his team. The discovered railing and gateway are now on display at the Indian Museum (Kolkata). Amravati Stupa was discovered by Colin Mackenzie (1797).

questions.question: Which of the following is the oldest dated fort in India ?
questions.explanation: Kangra Fort (Nagarkot Fort). This fort was built by Susharm Chand History (Katoch Dynasty). Mohammed Ghazni in 1009 A.D plundered the Shahi treasury at Kangra, Himachal Pradesh. The Katoch dynasty traces its origins to the ancient Trigarta Kingdom, mentioned in the Mahabharata epic. Forts in India: Golconda Fort - Hyderabad, Mehrangarh Fort - Jodhpur (Rajasthan), Srirangapatna Fort - Karnataka, Panhala Fort - Maharashtra, Daulatabad Fort - Aurangabad (Maharashtra).

questions.question: Brihat Samhita was the treatise of which of the following subjects ?
questions.explanation: Astronomy. Brihat Samhita - It is the noted work of Varahamihira. It is an important encyclopedic text in Sanskrit. Other Samhitas - Jaya Samhita (Mahabharat), Charak Samhita (Medicinal Science), Sushruta Samhita (Book on Surgeries and related science).

questions.question: Which ruler of the Chahamana dynasty made Ajmer his capital?
questions.explanation: Ajayaraja. Chahamanas or Chauhans dynasty: Chauhans of Delhi and Ajmer, also known as the Chahamanas of Shakambhari, ruled over part of modern-day Rajasthan. Important Kings : Vasudeva, Ajayaraja, Arnoraja, Vigraharaja IV, Prithviraj Chauhan III, and Hariraja.

questions.question: Prithviraj Raso, an epic poem about the life of the 12th century Indian king, Prithviraj Chauhan, was written by:
questions.explanation: Chand Bardai. Indian Epics and writers - Mahabharata (Sage Ved Vyasa), Ramayana (Valmiki), Raghuvamsa (Kalidasa), Buddhacharita (Asvogosha), Silapadikaram (Ilango Adigal in Tamil), Ramcharitmanas (Tulsidas in Awadhi), Kumarasambava (Kalidasa in Sanskrit). Banabhatta wrote Harshacharita and Bharavi wrote Kiratarjuniya.

questions.question: Siddheshwar Mahadev Temple in Bengal depicts the architecture of which dynasty.?
questions.explanation: Pala Dynasty. Temples and their associated Dynasty: Khajuraho Temple (Madhya Pradesh) - Bundelas or Chandelas; Kailash Temple (Maharashtra) - Rashtrakutas; Thousand Pillared Temple, Ramappa Temple (Telangana) - Kakatiyas; Brihadeeswara Temple (Tamil Nadu) - Cholas; Kailashnath Temple, Shore Temple (Tamil Nadu) - Pallavas; Dilwara Temple (Rajasthan) - Solankies; Virupaksha Temple (Karnataka) - Chalukyas; Sun Temple (Gujarat) - Solankis.

questions.question: Malavikagnimitra, a drama of the 5th century CE, was written by
questions.explanation: Kalidasa. He was a court poet of Chandragupta-II (Vikramaditya). Other Books: Meghaduta, Kumarasambhava, Raghuvaṃsa, and Vikramorvasiya. Harisena - Court poet of Samudragupta and composed Prayag pillar inscription in Sanskrit. Bhavabhuti - A great playwright, best known for his play Uttara-Ramacharitam (latter part of Rama's life). Pingala - Ancient Indian poet and mathematician, and the author of the Chandaḥsastra.

questions.question: The star-shaped temples were built during the reign of:
questions.explanation: Hoysala. Hoysala Architecture Temples: Aralaguppe is the temple dedicated to Lord Channakeshava (Vishnu). The temple was built during the rule of the Hoysala Empire King Vira Someshwara.

questions.question: Which of the following was the capital of the Hindu Shahi Kingdom?
questions.explanation: Waihind. Hindu Shahi kingdom was founded by Kallar. It ruled over Kabul and the old province of Gandhara from the decline of the Kushan empire. This kingdom was known as the Kabul Shahi dynasty. Q.236. The Gahadavalas ruled over which region of India ? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (3rd shift) (a) Ajmer (b) Malwa (c) Kanauj (d) Patan Sol.236.(c) Kanauj. Gahadavalas or Rathors of Kanauj (1090-1194 AD): Founder - Chandradeva. After the failure of the Pratiharas, the Gahadavalas established themselves on the throne of Kanauj. Jai Chand - The last great ruler of this dynasty. He was killed in the Battle of Chandawar in 1194 AD by Mohammad Ghori. Q.237. Alvars were the devotees of which South Indian cult? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (1st shift) (a) Shaktism (b) Saivism (c) Jainism (d) Vaishnavism Sol.237.(d) Vaishnavism. Nayanars and Alvars saints belonged to South India. Some famous Vaishnava devotees : Ramanuja, Madhvacharya, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, Nimbarkacharya. Jainism - Devotees of Jainism are called Jains such as Rishabhadeva, Parshvanath, Bhadrabahu. Shaktism - Devotees of Shaktism are called Shaktas. Famous Shaktas: Adi Shankaracharya, Sarada Devi, Paramahansa Yogananda.

questions.question: In the middle of which century did the Arab traveller Sulaiman visit India?
questions.explanation: 9th. Travellers Who Visited India: Hiuen Tsang (China) - During the reign of Harshavardhana. Al Biruni {Khwarizm (present-day Uzbekistan)} - In 11th century. During the reign of Sultan of Mahmood Ghaznavi. Ibn Battuta (Morocco) - During the reign of Muhammad Bin Tughlaq, Marco Polo (Italy) - During the reign of Pandya Kingdom. Megasthenes (Greece) - During the reign of Chandragupta Maurya. Abdur Razzaq (Persia) - During the reign of Deva Raya II (Sangama dynasty). Fa Hien (China) - During the reign of Chandragupta II. Al Masudi (Arab) - In 10th century AD. Q.239. The rulers of which of the following Rajput dynasties patronised Jainism and one of them is reported to have accepted Jainism under the influence of a Jain scholar Hemachandra? SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift) (a) Pratihara (b) Parmara (c) Chalukya (d) Chahman Sol.239.(c) Chalukya. Pratihara dynasty - Nagabhatta I was the founder. The Pratiharas who ruled over Kannauj for a long time are also called Gurjara- Pratiharas. Parmar dynasty - Founded by Upendra or Krishnaraja. Capital: Ujjain, Later - Dharan Nagari (Dhar).

questions.question: Alha and Udal, who gave stiff resistance to the enemy, belonged to which of the following Rajput States?
questions.explanation: Chandella (Founder - Nannuk). They were originally vassals of the Gurjara - Pratiharas. The Chandelas initially ruled as feudatories of the Gurjara-Pratiharas of Kanyakubja (Kannauj). Original capital - Khajuraho. The last King of this dynasty - Paradidev (Parmadi). His generals - Alha and Udal. Battle of Mahoba: Fought between Paradidev and Prithviraj Chauhan-III in 1182 AD.

questions.question: The Pala Dynasty rulers were primarily patrons of which religion?
questions.explanation: Buddhist. Pala Dynasty - Founded by Gopala, in 750 AD. They were staunch supporters of Mahayana Buddhism. They were in a tripartite struggle between the Palas, the Pratiharas and the Rashtrakutas for the control of Kanauj and North India.

questions.question: Who among the following was the author of the play 'Mrichchhakatika'?
questions.explanation: Shudraka. Mrichchhakatika play was translated into English by Arthur W. Ryder in 1905 as “The Little Clay Cart”. Other Sanskrit plays of Shudraka: “Vinavasavadatta”, “Padmaprabhritaka”, “a bhana” (short one -act monologue).

questions.question: The Ashtadhyayi of Panini is a renowned work on ______.
questions.explanation: Sanskrit Grammar. Ancient Authors and books : (Kautilya) Chanakya's work - “Arthashastra” (on statecraft, political science, economic policy and military strategy). Maharshi Charak - “Charaka Samhita” (a famous text of ayurveda) - Ayurveda. “Sushruta Samhita” - A comprehensive textbook on medicine and surgery.

questions.question: Who was the last king of the Shunga dynasty?
questions.explanation: Devabhuti. He was assassinated by his minister (Vasudeva Kanva). Other Kings of Shunga Dynasty: Pushyamitra Shunga (Founder of Shunga Dynasty), Agnimitra, Vasujyeshtha, Vasumitra, Bhagabhadra. Shashanka: The first king of ancient Bengal, governed the Gauda Kingdom from 600 to 625 AD. Bhavabhuti: A famous Sanskrit playwright who wrote famous plays like Mahaviracharita, Malatimadhava etc. Q.245. Of which of the following Pratihara kings was Rajashekhara, the famous poet and dramatist, the court poet? SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 2nd shift) (a) Rajapala (b) Devapala (c) Ramabhadra (d) Mahendrapala Sol.245.(d) Mahendrapala (885-910 AD). Works of Rajshekhara: Viddhashalabhanjika, Balabharata, Karpuramanjari, Balaramayana, Kavyamimamsa. Gurjara Pratihara dynasty (8th to 11th century): Founder - Harichandra. Mihira Bhoja (836-885 AD) - Most powerful Partihara king. Yashpala (1024- 1036) - last ruler of the Gurjara Pratihara dynasty.

questions.question: Who were the first to make land grants to Brahmins?
questions.explanation: Satavahanas (1st Century BC to 3rd Century AD): Simuka was the founder. Sakas (2nd century BCE to the 4th century CE) - The most famous Shaka ruler in India was Rudradaman (130 A.D to 150 A.D.), came to an end with the defeat of the last Shaka ruler, Rudrasimha III by Chandragupta-II (Gupta dynasty). Kushans (First – Third Centuries) - Founded by Kujula Kadphises.

questions.question: During the reign of which of the following Pallavas, Hiuen Tsang visited the Pallava capital Kanchi?
questions.explanation: Narasimhavarman I. He was also known as Mahamalla or Mamalla, which means "great wrestler”. He took the title Vatapikonda (the conqueror of Vatapi).

questions.question: The Rampurva bull that was part of a Mauryan pillar found in Rampurwa, Bihar is now placed at _______.
questions.explanation: Rashtrapati Bhawan. The Pillars of Ashoka are the most famous examples of Mauryan art. The Rashtrapati Bhavan houses the imposing 3rd century BC Ashoka pillar of sandstone known as the Rampurva bull. It got its name from the place of its discovery, Rampurwa in Bihar.

questions.question: Who among the following was the last Pallava king?
questions.explanation: Aparajitavarman. Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE) - Also known as Tondaimandalam. Founder - Simha Vishnu (Avanisimha). Mahendravarman - He defeated the Kalabhras and re-established the Pallava kingdom. Narashimhavarman-1 - Son of Mahendravarman.

questions.question: The Kandariya Mahadeva Temple was constructed in 999 A.D. by the king Dhangadeva of ______ dynasty.
questions.explanation: Chandela. Kandariya Mahadeva temple - built at Khajuraho (Madhya Pradesh), made up of sandstone. Its first mention is found in ‘al Biruni’ And ‘Ibn Battuta’ work. It follows the Nagara Style of architecture and was recognized by UNESCO as a world heritage site in 1986. Other temples built by Chandela dynasty (Founder - Nanuka): Devi Jagdamba Temple, Chitragupta Temple, Laxmana Temple. Q.251. In the mid-eighth century, Dantidurga, a Rashtrakuta chief, overthrew his Chalukya overlord and performed a ritual literally called a ______. SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Prarthna sabha (b) Golden womb (c) Horse ride (d) Subsidiary alliance Sol.251.(b) Golden womb (Hiranyagarbha). This ritual was performed with the help of Brahmanas, it was thought to lead to the “rebirth” of the sacrificer as a Kshatriya, even if he was History not one by birth. The first known ruler of the dynasty was Dantidurga who conquered Badami in 752 A.D., defeating the Chalukyas.

questions.question: The emblem of the Chera Dynasty that controlled the central and northern parts of Kerala and the Kongu region of Tamil Nadu was _________ .
questions.explanation: Bow and Arrow Gan. The symbol also appears on the coins the dynasty minted. The dynasty controlled the central and northern parts of Kerala and the Kongu region of Tamil Nadu. Their capital was Vanji, Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of six schools of Indian Philosophy?
questions.explanation: Dravida. Samkhya: Founded by - Kapila (Book - Samkhya sutra) : It holds that reality is constituted of two principles of one female (Prakriti) and the other male (Purusha). Yoga - Union of the two principal entities. Nyaya: A technique of logical thinking. Author of the Nyaya Sutras - Gautama.

questions.question: The Amaravati School of art was developed under the patronage of _____ .
questions.explanation: Satavahanas. Different School of arts: Gandhara School of Art (Kushana) - It developed in the North West Frontier, in the modern-day Kandahar region. Mathura School of Art (Kushana) - It developed around Mathura.

questions.question: Who among the following was a famous ruler of the Pandya dynasty of South India?
questions.explanation: Nedunjeliyan II. He was made ‘Pandya supreme in the south’. He defeated a confederacy of the Cholas and Cheras at Talaiyalanganam near Tiruvarur. His deeds have been described in the Maduraikkanci. Pandya Empire - Established by King Kadungon in the 6th century AD. Capital - Korkai, Madurai.

questions.question: Sangam poems mention a Tamil word 'Muvendar' which means ________.
questions.explanation: Three chiefs. It is a reference to the three ruling families of Tamil Nadu during the Sangam period: the Cholas, the Cheras, and the Pandyas.

questions.question: The term 'Kammakaras' in ancient times is related to ________.
questions.explanation: Landless agricultural labourers. Terminologies related in ancient times - Shrenis: In ancient times, crafts persons and merchants formed associations. Samaharta and Sanidata - Tax collecting officers in ancient times. Sonalika is a Sanskrit word that refers to a goldsmith. Grihapatis- independent farmers. An agrahara was land granted to a Brahmana.

questions.question: Who among the following gave up his traditional professions and took to arms, successfully established a kingdom in Karnataka?
questions.explanation: Kadamba Mayurasharman was a Brahmana. The Kadamba Mayurasharman (345–365 C.E.) was the founder of the Kadamba Kingdom of Banavasi (Karnataka). Kadimi Chettu (story of Mayur Sharma) was written by Visawanatha Satyanarayana {Padma Bhushan (1970), Jnanpith Award (1971)}.

questions.question: Ravikirti was the court poet of which of the following dynasty rulers ?
questions.explanation: Chalukya dynasty. The Jain poet Ravikirti was the court poet of 'Pulakeshin II' (610 to 642 CE), the first sovereign ruler of the Chalukya dynasty of Vatapi (modern Badami). Ravikirti's Aihole inscription (a nineteen-line Sanskrit inscription), in honour of his patron king, is found in the Meguti Jain temple at Aihole, Karnataka. Chalukya dynasty (between 6th and 12th centuries). Pallava dynasty (275 CE to 897 CE). Chera dynasty (in the Sangam period and before). Chola dynasty (300 BCE to 1279 CE).

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of the Kanva dynasty?
questions.explanation: Vasudeva Kanva (73-63 BCE) founded the Kanva dynasty (72–28 BCE, Kanvayanas). Rulers of the Kanva dynasty - Bhumimitra (64-50 BCE), Narayana (50-38 BCE), Susarman (38-28 BCE). Capital: Patliputra . Devabhuti - the last ruler of the Sunga Dynasty. Q.261. The rulers of which of the following dynasties built the Khajuraho temples between 950 to 1050 A.D in central India? SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning) (a) Gurjara-Pratihara Dynasty (b) Rashtrakuta Dynasty (c) Pala Dynasty (d) Chandela Dynasty Sol.261.(d) Chandela Dynasty. The Khajuraho Group of Monuments are a group of Hindu and Jain temples in Chhatarpur district, Madhya Pradesh, Known for its Erotic Sculpture. The Pratiharas, also known as the Gurjara -Pratiharag (Founder - Harichandra). The most well-known king of this dynasty was Bhoja or Mihira Bhoja. Q.262. In which of the following languages did Amoghavarsha write Kavirajamarga? SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Tamil (b) Sanskrit (c) Kannada (d) Telugu Sol.262.(c) Kannada. Amoghavarsha (Rashtrakuta ruler) also wrote ‘Prasnottara Ratna Malika’ (Sanskrit). He patronized many Indian scholars including mathematician Mahaviracharya , who wrote Ganita -sara- samgraha, Jinasena, Virasena, Shakatayan, and Sri Vijaya (a Kannada language theorist). He held titles such as Nrupathunga, Atishadhavala, Veeranarayana, Rattamarthanda , and Srivallabha during his reign. Historian Panchamukhi called him the ‘Ashoka of South’.

questions.question: Which king of the Pala dynasty defeated Indrayudh and made Chakrayudha as the ruler of Kannauj?
questions.explanation: Dharampala (770-810) founded the Vikramshila University (Bhagalpur, Bihar) and built Somapuri monastery, Bihar. In 750 AD, Gopala History founded the Pala dynasty. Capital: Muddagiri/ Munger (Bihar). Q.264. Mukteshwara Temple is a 10th-century Hindu temple dedicated to Shiva, located in _______. SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Assam (b) Odisha (c) Maharashtra (d) Gujarat Sol.264.(b) Odisha (Bhubaneswar). Ancient temples - Virupaksha Temple, Hampi (Built by Lakkan Dandesha, a chieftain under the ruler Deva Raya II), Ellora Kailashanatha Temple (Krishna I of Rashtrakuta), Sun Temple Konark (Eastern Ganga King Narsimhadeva-1).

questions.question: Queen Rudramadevi belonged to which dynasty of India?
questions.explanation: Kakatiya. Marco Polo mentioned her in his writings. Rudradeva I was the first independent ruler of this kingdom of Warangal. Their capital was Orugallu, now known as Warangal. In 1323 Prince Jaunakhan (Muhammad bin Tughlaq) defeated Prataparudra Deva (the last ruler of this kingdom) and annexed their kingdom Q.266. Which place had a water harvesting system channeling the flood water of the Ganga river in the first century B.C ? SSC MTS 06/10/2021 (Evening) (a) Kanpur (b) Gorakhpur (c) Mirzapur (d) Sringaverapura Sol.266.(d) Sringaverapura (near Allahabad in Uttar Pradesh). Water harvesting in India - Dholavira in Harappan civilization, Bhopal Lake (built by the Paramara Raja Bhoj in 11th century), Iltutmish constructed a tank in Hauz Khas for supplying water to the Siri Fort (14th century).

questions.question: Which state of India was ruled by the Ningthouja dynasty?
questions.explanation: Manipur . It has extended families. It was apparently founded by King Nongda Lairen Pakhangba in 33 CE. Q.268. The Caves of Elephanta are predominantly dedicated to which of the following deities? SSC MTS 26/10/2021 (Afternoon) (a) Lord Shiva (b) Lord Krishna (c) Lord Rama (d) Lord Ganesha Sol.268.(a) Lord Shiva. The caves of Elephanta were built by the Rashtrakuta rulers. They are on Elephanta Island, or Gharapuri, in Mumbai Harbour. There are about 34 caves. These are declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1987.

questions.question: In which of the following temples will you find Gopurams?
