questions.explanation: Shiva Temple, Chidambaram. A gopuram or gopura is a monumental tower, usually ornate, at the entrance of any temple, especially in Southern India. They are a prominent feature of koils, Hindu temples built in the Dravidian style. They are topped by the kalasam, a bulbous stone finial. Nataraja temple in Chidambaram, Tamil Nadu is one of the famous examples of Gopuram.

questions.question: Who among the following wrote the basic text of Vaisheshika philosophy?
questions.explanation: Kanada. It is an ancient Sanskrit text at the foundation of the Vaisheshika school of Hindu philosophy. Vaisheshika is one of the six classical schools of Indian philosophy, often referred to as "Darshanas."

questions.question: Yashovigraha, Mahichandra and Chandradeva were the first three rulers of ______ dynasty.
questions.explanation: Gahadavala. Yashovigraha was the founder of the Gahadavala dynasty. The majority of the Gahadavala epigraphic records were discovered in Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: In which of the following caves is the painting named ‘Padmapani Bodhisattva’ found?
questions.explanation: Ajanta Cave No. 1. The iconic Ajanta paintings Padmapani and Vajrapani glorify the walls of the Cave 1 of Ajanta. Cave 1 of Ajanta was built in the second phase of excavation under the patronage of King Harisena of the Vakataka dynasty. Q.273. Kolathunadu, Valluvanad and Thekkumkoor were ancient small-time kingdoms in which state of India? SSC CGL 03/03/2020 (Morning) (a) Gujarat (b) Karnataka (c) Kerala (d) Bihar Sol.273.(c) Kerala. Kolathunadu - land lying between Perumba river in the north and Putupattanam river in the south. Valluvanad (Founder - Ilayi Raja) - Region between Meenachil and Pamban rivers. Thekkumkoor - The region between the Nila river and Panthaloor Hills. Medieval History

questions.question: Mameluke style of architecture belongs to which dynasty?
questions.explanation: Slave dynasty (1206 - 1290) - It is also known as the Mamluk Dynasty. Established by - Qutbuddin Aibak (1206 - 1210). Capitals - Lahore . Famous buildings built by rulers of the slave dynasty: Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, Qutub Minar, Adhai Din ka Jhonpra, Tomb of Nasir-ud-Din Mohammed, Tomb of Shams-ud-Din Iltutmish.

questions.question: The Delhi sultan, who succumbed to injuries as a result of his fall from horse, was __________ .
questions.explanation: Qutubuddin Aibak (Known as Lakh Baksh). He was the slave of Muhammad Ghori and was the first sultan of Delhi Sultanate. He established the slave dynasty (Mamluk dynasty). Famous Ruler of Slave Dynasty (1206 AD-1290 AD): Qutbuddin Aibak (1206-1210), Shamsuddin Iltutmish (1210-1236), Raziya Sultan (1236-1240), Balban (1266-1287).

questions.question: The Tomb of Iltutmish was built in which year?
questions.explanation: 1235 AD. Iltutmish (Reign 1210 - 1236 AD) introduced silver coin (Tanka) and copper coin (Jital), and completed the construction of Qutub Minar. He also constructed a large reservoir Hauz-i-Sultani just outside Dehli-i-Kuhna. Q.303. Who started the practice of celebrating Nauroz during the Delhi Sultanate period? SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (3rd shift) (a) Sikandar Sur (b) Shamsuddin Iltutmish (c) Ghiyasuddin Balban (d) Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq Sol.303.(c) Ghiyasuddin Balban. Nowruz is the Iranian New Year, also known as the Persian New Year.

questions.question: Balban served as naib to which of the following sultans of Delhi?
questions.explanation: Nasiruddin Mahmud (1246-1266 AD) - Eighth ruler of Slave dynasty (Mamluk dynasty). Minhaj -i-Siraj was his court historian. Balban (1266-1287 AD) : He pursued the policy of ‘blood and iron’. Razia Sultan (1236-1240 AD) : First muslim woman to rule over Delhi sultanate. Q.305. Who among the following revolted against Balban, Sultan of Delhi, and declared himself as an independent ruler of Bengal in 1279? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Muhammad Khan (b) Tughril Beg (c) Bughra Khan (d) Nasir-ud-din Mahmud Sol.305.(b) Tughril Beg. Balban (Mamluk dynasty or Slave Dynasty) - Ghiyas-ud-Din Balban appointed his own son Bughra khan as governor of Bengal. Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq also known as Nasiruddin, was the last sultan of the Tughlaq dynasty. Q.306. Who occupied Badaun (A.D. 1197-98) and appointed Iltutmish as its first Muslim Governor? SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Evening) (a) Prithviraj Chauhan (b) Maharana Pratap (c) Muhammad Ghori (d) Qutbuddin Aibak Sol.306.(d) Qutbuddin Aibak {1206- (First ruler of Slave Dynasty /Mamluk Dynasty)}: He established the first Muslim dynasty and was also known as Lakh Baksh. He died in Lahore, Pakistan after falling from a horse ride.

questions.question: Qutub Minar is an example of ______ architecture.
questions.explanation: Indo - Islamic. Indo-Islamic architecture is the architecture of the Indian subcontinent produced for Islamic patrons and purposes. Famous Examples - City of Mandu (Madhya Pradesh), Taj Mahal (Agra), Gol Gumbaz (Karnataka), Jama Masjid (Delhi) etc.

questions.question: Who had assumed the title of Balban?
questions.explanation: Ulugh Kha, whose original name was Ghiyas ud din Balban, was initially a slave who rose to become the Sultan of Delhi, ruling from 1266 to 1287 CE. He was known for his theory of kingship and strong centralized administration.

questions.question: Quwwat al-Islam mosque and minaret, built during the last decade of the ______ century.
questions.explanation: Twelfth. Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque (1192-1198) built by Qutubuddin Aibak. Other Monuments of Qutub complex - Alai Darwaza (by Ala-ud-din Khalji in 1311 AD). Tomb of Iltutmish (1235). Tomb of Imam Zamin (1537).

questions.question: What is the approximate height (in metres) of the Qutub Minar situated in Delhi ?
questions.explanation: 73 (239.5 ft. approx). Qutub Minar has five storeys. It was started in 1199 by Qutb ud-Din Aibak, completed in by his son-in-law Iltutmish. UNESCO (1993). Other Important Minars - Charminar, Hyderabad (1591) by Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah, height is 48.7 m (160 ft).

questions.question: Who among the following was the Wazir of Sultan Iltutmish?
questions.explanation: Nizam ul-Mulk Junaidi. Iltutmish is known as the real founder of Delhi Sultanate who occupied the throne in 1210 AD after KIlling Aram Bakshsh. He shifted his capital from Lahore to Delhi.

questions.question: Ghiyasuddin Balban, ruler of the Slave dynasty, took up the title of _______.
questions.explanation: Zil-i-Ilahi (shadow of God). Ghiyas ud din Balban - Abolished Chahalghani (Council of nobles), Introduced Persian customs as sizdah (prostration), paibos (kissing feet of sultan), established Diwan-i-Ariz (defence department).

questions.question: In which of the following forts was Razia Sultan imprisoned by Malik Ikhtiyar-ud-din Altunia?
questions.explanation: Qila Mubarak in Bathinda, built by Raja Dab. Jaigarh fort in Jaipur was built in 1726 AD by Jai Singh II. Golconda fort in Golconda was built by Qutb Shahi dynasty. Mehrangarh fort in Jodhpur was built by Rao Jodha.

questions.question: Which officer under Alauddin Khilji was required to maintain a register of merchants to ensure an adequate supply of goods?
questions.explanation: Shahna-i-Mandi. Alauddin set up three markets at Delhi - First for food-grains, the second for cloth, sugar, ghee, oil, dry fruits and the third for horses, slaves and cattle.

questions.question: How many types of taxes were in the reign of the ruler Alauddin Khalji?
questions.explanation: 3 types of taxes: Jaziya (religious tax on Hindu community), Ghari tax (tax on Houses), and Chari tax (tax on cattles).

questions.question: Who among the following was the Maharana of Mewar and composed a book on music called 'Sangeet Raj' ?
questions.explanation: Maharana Kumbha (1433-1468 AD) belonged to the Sisodia clan of Rajputs. Titles of Maharana Kumbha: Abhinav Bhattacharya, Rajguru, Daanguru, Halguru, Rano Raso.

questions.question: Name the Bhakti Saint from South India who was initially a Jaina and a minister in the court of a Chalukya king in the twelfth century.
questions.explanation: Basavanna - Founder of Lingayatism; Prime minister of Kalachurya king Bijjala (1157-1167); Founded the Anubhava Mantapa.

questions.question: The eleventh century structure of Bhojshala in the state of Madhya Pradesh was constructed under the patronage of which dynasty?
questions.explanation: Paramara. 'Bhojshala' is an ancient and the only temple of Mata Saraswati. It is located in Dhar district of Madhya Pradesh. The Paramara dynasty (Rajput) ruled Malwa and the adjacent regions in west-central India from the 9th century to the 14th century. Founder - Upendra or Krishnaraja.

questions.question: In which of the following places is the Tomb of Ahmad Shah Al Wali Bahmani built ?
questions.explanation: Ashtoor. Ahmed Shah Al Wali Bahamani (1422 to 1436, Bahmani Sultanate) - Ashtoor is an important center of Indo-Saracenic monuments. Twelve imposing mausoleums are located at Ashtur east of Bidar.

questions.question: The Hoysaleshvara temple was built with which of the following stones by a Hoysala king in 1150?
questions.explanation: Dark Schist Stone. The temples were known for its pillared hall and stellate plan. Capital of Hoysala - Dorasamudra (Dwarasamudra).

questions.question: Udaipur was founded by _________ after the fall of Chittor to Akbar in 1568.
questions.explanation: Rana Udai Singh. Udaipur is known as 'Venice of the East' and the city of lakes.

questions.question: Which architectural style of India was distinguished by the use of overhanging balconies and arched cornices?
questions.explanation: Rajput. The Rajput fort ‘Hawa Mahal’ (Jaipur) is an example of Rajput Architecture. Hawa Mahal was built by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh in Jaipur. Sikh Style - The Harimandir Sahib (Golden Temple). Mughal Style - Taj Mahal, Humayun’s Tomb, Agra Fort.

questions.question: Ananga Pala was a ruler of which dynasty ?
questions.explanation: Rajput Dynasty - It was founded by Simharaj, who is famously known as the founder of the city of Ajmer. Ananga Pala - He was a king of the Tomara dynasty, who ruled over areas of Delhi in India.

questions.question: The Ahom Kingdom in India was located in the _______.
questions.explanation: Brahmaputra valley. Chaolung Sukapha founded the Ahom kingdom (13th century) that ruled Assam for six centuries. It was annexed by British India in 1826 with the signing of the Treaty of Yandaboo. Lachit Borphukan (military general of Ahom kingdom) defeated mughal forces in the Battle of Saraighat 1671. Q.506. What did the medieval term "Raqs" mean ? SSC MTS 15/06/2023 (Evening) (a) Dancing (b) Singing (c) Chanting (d) Ritual Sol.506.(a) Dancing. Medieval Terms and Meaning: Amils (Revenue), Bargir (Cavalrymen), Daam (Coin), Dhimmis (Non-Muslims people), Din (Religion), Diwan (Function of finance), Wilayat (The spiritual territory of a Sufi). Q.507. Bhakti saints, Nayanars were devotees of which of the following gods? SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Morning) (a) Murugan (b) Shiva (c) Vishnu (d) Indra Sol.507.(b) Shiva. The Nayanars were a group of 63 saints devoted to Lord Shiva who lived during the 6th to 8th centuries CE. The Alwars were Tamil poet-saints of South India who espoused devotion to Lord Vishnu.

questions.question: Which among the following forts was principal capital of Qutb Shahi dynasty in Hyderabad?
questions.explanation: Golconda Fort - It was built by the Kakatiya Dynasty. It was the principal capital of the Qutb Shahi dynasty in Hyderabad. Rajgad Fort - Pune ( Maharashtra). Chhatrapati Shivaji renovated this fort and made it his capital in 1674 AD. Chiktan Fort - Kargil (Ladakh).

questions.question: Which of the following books was written by the Roman writer Pliny the elder?
questions.explanation: Natural History. Important Books and Authors: “Gathasaptashati” - Hala, “Indica” - Megasthenes, “Geographica” - Strabo, “Periplus of the Erythraean Sea:” - William H Schoff, “Kathasaritsagara” - Somadeva, “Mudrarakshasa” - Vishakhadatta, “Rajtarangini” - Kalhana.

questions.question: Which of the following cities became the capital of Bengal in 1704 ?
questions.explanation: Murshidabad. Murshid Quli Khan (Zamin Ali Quli) transferred his capital to the then Mukhsusabad later came to be known after Murshid Quli Khan as Murshidabad in A.D. Murshidabad (West Bengal) on the banks History of the Bhagirathi became the center of silk. Murshid Quli Khan (1717-1727) was the first Nawab of Bengal.

questions.question: Which of the following statement is correct with respect to the Prashastis and land grants? I. Prashastis were composed by learned Brahmanas. II. Kings often rewarded Brahmanas by grants of land which were recorded on copper plates.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Prashastis (metal plates) were written by Brahmans in Sanskrit or any regional language. They have been written in the 1st millennium and onwards in the form of prose or poetry. Example: Allahabad Pillar Inscription Sanskrit poem (by Harishena in praise of King Samudragupta). Agrahara (Agraharam, Ghatoka, Boya) refers to the land, village, or fields that were given to Brahmans.

questions.question: The craftspersons of Bidar were so famed for their inlay work in ______.
questions.explanation: Copper and Silver. Work of Bidar (Karnataka) craftsperson called BIdri. Bidar was the capital of Bahmani Kingdom in the 14th century. Bidar fort was built by Ahmad Shah Wali Bahman. Bidar is also considered one of the holiest places for Sikh pilgrimage.

questions.question: In 1342, one of the nobles, Haji Ilyas Khan united Bengal and became its ruler under the title of __________and laid the foundation of the Ilyas Shah dynasty.
questions.explanation: Shams-ud-din Ilyas Shah {(founder of Bengal Sultanate and Ilyas Shahi dynasty (First dynasty of Bengal)}. Dynasties of Bengal Sultanate - Ilyas Shahi (1342-1415), Ganesha (1414 -1435), Restorer of Ilyas Dynasty (Nasiruddin Mahmud Shah-I, -1487), Habshi rule (Shahzada Barbak, 1487-1494) and Hussain Shahi dynasty (Alauddin Hussain Shah - 1494-1519).

questions.question: Who was the architect of the famous Mysore Palace in Karnataka?
questions.explanation: Henry Irwin. Mysore Palace (also known as Amba Villas) is a historical palace at Mysore in Karnataka. It was the official residence of the Wadiyar dynasty. Mysore Palace was constructed in Indo-Saracenic style architecture.

questions.question: The Vimana in the Dravidian style of temple architecture is usually in which shape?
questions.explanation: Pyramidal. Gopuram (entrance gateway in the center of the front wall). Antarala (vestibular tunnel), garbhagriha (the innermost sanctuary of a Hindu and Jain temple). Famous Dravidian Temples - Rajarajeswara or Brihadeshwara temple (Rajaraja Chola at Thanjavur), Gangaikondacholapuram temple (Rajendra I), Annamalaiyar Temple (Tiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu), Meenakshi Temple (Tamil Nadu), Airavatesvara Temple (Tamil Nadu) etc. Q.516. Consider the following statements about a fort: 1. It was originally known as Mankal. 2. It was built on a hilltop in 1143. In the above mentioned sentences, forts is being talked about? SSC MTS 05/07/2022 (Evening) (a) Chitradurg Fort (b) Daulatabad Fort (c) Fort Aguada (d) Golconda Fort Sol.516.(d) Golconda fort (Hyderabad; Built by the Qutb shahi dynasty). Chitradurga fort (Karnataka; built by the Chalukyas and Hoysalas, later the Nayakas of Chitradurga of the Vijayanagar Empire. Daulatabad fort (Maharashtra; built by Yadava dynasty), and Aguada Fort (Goa; built by Portuguese).

questions.question: The ancient Neemrana Baori is located in which of the following districts of Rajasthan?
questions.explanation: Alwar. Famous Baori in India - Chand Baori (Rajasthan), Agrasen Ki Baoli (New Delhi), Rani ki Vav (Gujarat), Pushkarani (Karnataka), Baoli Ghaus Ali Shah (Haryana), Mata Bhavani ni Vav (Gujarat), Rajon ki Baoli (New Delhi), Surya Kund (Gujarat).

questions.question: Who among the following was given the title of ‘Uttarapatha Swamin’ ?
questions.explanation: Dharmapala assumed the title of Uttarapatha Swamin, Parama Bhattaraka, Paramesvara, and Maharajadhiraja. He was the successor of Gopala (founder of the Pala empire). He was a pious Buddhist. He founded Vikramshila University in Bhagalpur, Bihar.

questions.question: Who was the ruler of Mysore in 1761 ?
questions.explanation: Hyder Ali. In 1769, he defeated the British forces several times and reached the Madras walls. In the second Anglo-Mysore War, he died in 1782 and was succeeded by his son Tipu.

questions.question: In 1590, the Govind Deva temple of Vrindavan, near Mathura was constructed from ______ sandstone.
questions.explanation: Red. The Govind Deva temple was built by the king of Jaipur, Man Singh, in 1590 in Vrindavan in Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: The book ‘Man Kautuhal’ was compiled by which of the following kings of Medieval India?
questions.explanation: Raja Mansingh Tomar. He was the ruler of Gwalior. He was a patron of the Dhrupad genre from Hindustani Classical Music. He built Gwalior fort (Gujari Mahal and Man Mandir Palace). The founder of the Tomar dynasty in India was Anangapala I.

questions.question: King Lalitaditya Muktapida ruled over ______.
questions.explanation: Kashmir. Aḥmad Shah I was the first independent sultan of Gujarat, who founded Ahmedabad (1411).The Chogyal (king who governs with righteousness) Palden Namgyal Thodup History was crushed in 1975 and Sikkim merged with India as its 22nd state. King Mahabali ruled over Kerala.

questions.question: Chandannagar was established as a French colony in 1673, obtaining permission from______ the then Nawab of Bengal, to establish a trading post on the right bank of the river Hooghly.
questions.explanation: Ibrahim Khan. French Colonies In India- Pondicherry, Karaikal, Yanam (Andhra Pradesh) on the Coromandel Coast, Mahe on the Malabar Coast and Chandernagor in Bengal. Q.524. Hafiz (Hafez) was a ______ century poet whose collection of poems is known as 'Diwan' or 'Diwan-e-Hafiz'. SSC MTS 05/10/2021 (Morning) (a) 14th (b) 15th (c) 16th (d) 17th Sol.524.(a) 14th-century '. Hafez was an Iranian poet. His collection of poems ‘Diwan’ is in Persian language. Most of the parts of ‘Diwan’ are Ghazals.

questions.question: In the context of Sufi traditions, what is the meaning of the word 'sama'?
questions.explanation: recitation of sacred songs. Sufism (tasawwuf) is a mystic sect of Islam that emphasizes introspection and spiritual closeness with God.

questions.question: ______ was one of the first Indian rulers to lead an armed rebellion against the British East India Company in 1824 against the implementation of the Doctrine of Lapse.
questions.explanation: Kittur Chennamma was one of the first Indian rulers to lead an armed rebellion against the British East India Company in against the implementation of the Doctrine of Lapse.

questions.question: 'Rang Ghar', one of Asia's oldest amphitheatres, was built by the king of the ___dynasty.
questions.explanation: Ahom Dynasty. Rang Ghar, constructed by the Ahom King Swargadeo Promotta Singha.

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of the Bhakti sect named 'Pushtimarg'?
questions.explanation: Vallabhacharya founded the Krishna-centered PushtiMarg sect of Vaishnavism in the Braj region of India, and the philosophy of Shuddha advaita (Pure Nondualism). Pushtimarg is a form of Krishna worship for adoration.

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of the Suryavamsi Gajapati dynasty that ruled parts of Orissa and Andhra Pradesh in the 15th century?
questions.explanation: Kapilendra Deva was the founder of the Suryavamsi Gajapati dynasty that ruled parts of Orissa and Andhra Pradesh in the 15th century (1434–66 CE).

questions.question: Who among the following was the Nizam of Hyderabad in 1947?
questions.explanation: Osman Ali. He was the last Nizam (ruler) of the Princely State of Hyderabad. He ruled the Kingdom of Hyderabad between 1911 and 1948.

questions.question: Which of the following is the meaning of ‘Pishtaq’ in the context of medieval Indo-Islamic Architecture?
questions.explanation: tall gateway. Pishtaq is a Persian/Farsi word that means ‘front of arch’. It is a rectangular frame around an arched opening of a building like mosques and palaces.

questions.question: Prophet Muhammad founded the faith of Islam in the ______ century.
questions.explanation: Seventh century. Islam is the 2nd largest religion in the world. Largest religion - Christianity.

questions.question: Who among the following was appointed as the curator of ancient monuments in 1880?
questions.explanation: HH Cole. He was a British civil servant and inventor who facilitated many innovations in commerce and Education.

questions.question: Who among the following was a Portuguese writer who wrote about the trade and society in South India?
questions.explanation: Duarte Barbosa was the Portuguese writer who visited India during (1500-1516) and wrote about the trade and society in South India in his manuscript, ‘The Book of Duarte Barbosa’.

questions.question: Who among the following was the first Portuguese viceroy of India?
questions.explanation: Francisco de Almeida was the first Portuguese viceroy of India in 1505. He was given the credit of Portuguese possession in India. His policy was to maintain a strong naval army over the Indian ocean. Portuguese Governor Afonso de Albuquerque captured Goa from the Adil Shahis in 1510 AD. Modern History The Revolt of 1857

questions.question: With reference to Sepoy Mutiny of 1857, on which of the following dates did the soldiers at Meerut start their journey to Delhi?
questions.explanation: 10 May. The Revolt of 1857, the first major rebellion against the British East India Company, began in Meerut. The immediate cause of this revolt was the introduction of the Enfield rifle and its greased cartridges. In March 1857, Mangal Pandey, a sepoy in Barrackpore, refused to use the new cartridges because of the rumor that they were greased with pork and beef fat, History which violated their religious beliefs, and he attacked his officers, which led to his execution on April 8. On 9th May, 85 soldiers in Meerut refused the new rifles and were imprisoned. Lord Canning was the British viceroy during the revolt.

questions.question: The revolution of 1857 started in May from which of the following cantonments in India?
questions.explanation: Meerut. The 1857 Revolution, also known as the Indian Mutiny, began in Meerut on May 10 and spread to Delhi, Agra, Kanpur, and Lucknow. It was suppressed after the rebels were defeated in Gwalior on June 20, 1858. Q.538. When did the first War of Indian Independence (Sepoy Mutiny) start? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift) (a) 1839 (b) 1857 (c) 1887 (d) 1819 Sol.538.(b) 1857. The revolt began on May 10, 1857, at Meerut as a sepoy mutiny. It occurred during the reign of Governor-General Lord Canning. Q.539. Which military officer led the British forces in the Battle of Chinhat fought in 1857? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Robert Maclagan (b) Charles Ellice (c) Henry Lawrence (d) James George Smith Sol.539.(c) Henry Lawrence. The Battle of Chinhat took place on the morning of June 30, 1857, near the village of Chinhat in Awadh (now Uttar Pradesh), specifically at Ismailganj, where British forces clashed with Indian rebels during the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Q.540. Post revolt, the Peel commission was set up to give recommendations on____ reorganisation of British India. Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) military (b) land revenue (c) telecom (d) trade Sol.540.(a) Military. Reforms After 1857: The Peel Commission was established to recommend changes in the organization of the colonial armed forces. The proportion of Europeans in the British Indian Army was increased, and artillery was placed exclusively under the command of British officers. Additionally, the Arms Act of 1878 was enacted to restrict the possession of weapons by 'unlawful' elements.

questions.question: Who among the following leaders led the Revolt of 1857 in Bihar?
questions.explanation: Kunwar Singh.

questions.question: Nana Sahib, a rebel at Kanpur was the son of which of the following Peshwas?
questions.explanation: Bajirao II (10 January 1775 – 28 January 1851) was the last Peshwa of the Maratha Empire.

questions.question: Which Mughal ruler contributed to the revolt of 1857 ?
questions.explanation: Bahadur Shah II (Bahadur Shah Zafar). He was the twentieth and last Mughal Emperor of India. In 1857 Bahadur Shah II was deposed by the British and exiled to Rangoon.

questions.question: The sepoys of Meerut arrived at the Gates of Red Fort to meet the Mughal emperor, Bahadur Shah on _____________.
questions.explanation: 11 May, 1857. Q.545. Whose proclamation of November 1, declared that thereafter India would be governed by and in the name of the British Monarch through a Secretary of State? SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Morning) (a) King Louis’ (b) King Philips’ (c) Queen Victoria’s (d) Queen Elizabeth’s Sol.545.(c) Queen Victoria’s. Governors and Viceroys Q.546. The Permanent Settlement introduced by Cornwallis was NOT prevalent in which of the following regions of India? SSC MTS 14/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Bengal (b) Bihar (c) Odisha (d) Punjab Sol.546.(d) Punjab. The Permanent Settlement, introduced by Lord Cornwallis in 1793, established the zamindars as the primary landowners and fixed the amount of land revenue they had to pay to the East India Company, making the revenue payable to the company a permanent, unchanging sum.

questions.question: Who among the following devised the system of ‘Subsidiary Alliance’?
questions.explanation: Lord Wellesley : He devised the Subsidiary Alliance as a system in 1798. Under this system, Indian rulers were required to maintain British forces within their territory and adhere to British political advice. States that accepted the alliance included Hyderabad (1798), Mysore (1799), Awadh (1801), Peshwa (1802), Bhosle and Scindia (1803).

questions.question: Which Governor-General of British India helped Raja Ram Mohan Roy legally abolish the Sati practice?
questions.explanation: Lord William Bentinck. He was appointed Governor of Madras in and assumed the office of Governor-General in 1828. He passed the Bengal Sati Regulation on December 4, 1829, which banned the practice of Sati throughout British India.

questions.question: The Doctrine of Lapse was an annexation policy devised by which of the following Governor-Generals of India?
questions.explanation: Lord Dalhousie. The Doctrine of Lapse was an annexation policy used by the British East India Company to expand its empire in India. Under this policy, if a ruler of a dependent state died without a male heir, the state would be annexed by the British. States annexed under the policy: Satara (1848), Jaitpur and Sambalpur (1849), Baghat (1850), Udaipur (1852), Jhansi (1854), Nagpur (1854), Tanjore, and Arcot (1855).

questions.question: Who asked James Rennel to prepare the map of Hindustan?
questions.explanation: Robert Clive served twice as Governor of Bengal (1758-60 and History 1764-67) and also led the Battle of Plassey on behalf of the British East India Company in 1757. James Rennel was the first Surveyor General of Bengal (1767-1777) and conducted the first comprehensive geographical survey of much of India. He is best known for his "Bengal Atlas" (1779) and "Memoir of a Map of Hindoostan" (1782).

questions.question: The Daroga system in 1792 was introduced by whom among the following Governor- Generals in India?
questions.explanation: Lord Cornwallis (1786-93): The system of Daroga as part of Police reforms. Police of each district were placed under District Judge. Each district was divided into Thanas/Police circles which were headed by Daroga. He also abolished District Faujdari Courts and set up circuit courts in Calcutta, Dacca, Murshidabad, and Patna. During his tenure, the Third Mysore War (1790-92) and Treaty of Seringapatam (1792).

questions.question: Who is called the father of Local Self - Government in India?
questions.explanation: Lord Ripon. During Lord Ripon’s tenure (1880-84), key reforms included the repeal of the Vernacular Press Act (1881) and a resolution on local self-government (1882). His period also saw the Ilbert Bill controversy (1883) and the formation of the Hunter Commission on Education (1882). Q.553. Which of the following Governor-Generals of British India was in favour of free press and repealed the press regulations of 1823? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Lord Ellenborough (b) Lord Lytton (c) Lord Ripon (d) Lord Metcalfe Sol.553.(d) Lord Metcalfe (1835-36) is also known as the Liberator of Indian Press. Licensing Regulation ordinance was brought out by acting Governor-General John Adams. Other Governor generals: Lord Ellenborough (1842–1844) abolished the slavery act in India in 1843.

questions.question: In which year did Lord Dalhousie introduce the railway line in British India ?
questions.explanation: 1853. Lord Dalhousie (1848-1856), known as the father of Indian Railways, played a key role in the establishment of the railway network. The first railway line in India covered 21 miles (34km), from Bombay to Thane. The first railway line in South India was opened in 1856. The first railway minister of India was John Mathai.

questions.question: In the context of British rule in India, who among the following Governor - Generals created a professional cadre of company servants making provisions for them for generous salaries?
questions.explanation: Lord Cornwallis (1786 - 1793). He is also regarded as the 'Father of Civil Service in India' for his role in shaping the civil service system. Lord Mayo, Viceroy of India from 1869 to 1872, is known for introducing the first regular census in 1872.

questions.question: Whom did Lord Curzon entrust as architect for Victoria Memorial Hall?
questions.explanation: William Emerson. The Victoria Memorial, built between 1906 and 1921 in Kolkata, West Bengal, was conceptualized by Viceroy George Curzon to commemorate Queen Victoria's 25-year reign in India. The foundation stone was laid by the Prince of Wales, later King George V, in 1906, and it was opened to the public in 1921.

questions.question: Who among the following was the Viceroy of British India when the Shimla conference was held in 1945?
questions.explanation: Lord Wavell (1944 to 1947). The Shimla Conference was held from June 25 to July 14, 1945, at Viceregal Lodge in Shimla, India.

questions.question: Match List-I with List-II. List-I (Governor General) List-II (Period) A. Warren Hasting 1. 1772-1785 B. Lord Cornwallis 2. 1786-1793 C. Sir John Shore 3. 1793-1798 D. Lord Wellesley 4. 1798-1805
questions.explanation: A – 1, B – 2, C – 3, D – 4. The first Governor of Bengal - Robert Clive. The first Governor General of Bengal in - Warren Hastings (1772-1785). The first Governor General of India - William Bentinck. The first Viceroy of India - Lord Canning. Q.559. Identify the INCORRECTLY matched pair(s) of the British Governor - Generals of India and the events with which they are associated. i) Lord Dalhousie - Revolt of 1857 ii) Lord Auckland - First Afghan War iii) Lord Canning - Wood’s Despatch 1854 SSC CGL Tier II 26/10/2023 (a) Only (ii) and (iii) (b) Only (ii) (c) Only (i) and (iii) (d) Only (i) Sol.559.(c) Only (i) and (iii). Governor general and the related events: Lord Dalhousie (1848-1856) - Doctrine of Lapse policy, Wood’s Despatch 1854. Lord Cornwallis (1786 - 1793) - Introduction of the Charter Act of 1793, the Third Anglo-Mysore War began and ended with the Treaty of Seringapatam. Warren Hastings (1772 - 1785) - Introduction of the Regulating Act of 1773 by the British Parliament, First Anglo-Maratha War began (ended with the Treaty of Salbai). Lord Wellesley (1798–1805) - The Second Anglo - Maratha War began and ended with multiple treaties.

questions.question: English as the official language of India for higher education was incorporated in the resolution formulation by _______.
questions.explanation: Lord Macaulay - Considered to be the founder of the British education system in India. He was also the chairman of the first Law Commission of pre - independent India.

questions.question: The Vernacular Press Act was enacted during the regime of which viceroy of India?
questions.explanation: Lord Lytton (1876-1880). Vernacular Press Act (The gagging Act) 1878. The act allows the government to confiscate the assets of newspaper in History case of publishing anything “objectionable”

questions.question: Who among the following signed a Tripartite treaty on behalf of the British Government to interfere in the affairs of Afghanistan?
questions.explanation: Lord Auckland (1836 - 42).Tripartite treaty (1838): It was signed between Governor - General Lord Auckland (British), Maharaja Ranjit Singh (Sikhs), and Shah Shuja (who had been deposed from the Afghan throne in 1809 and had been living since then as a British pensioner at Ludhiana). Lord Mayo (1869 - 1872) - He ordered the first census of India in 1871. Q.563. Which of the following Commissions was appointed by Lord Curzon to enquire into the working of the police administration? SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (3rd shift) (a) Kitchener Commission (b) Hunter Commission (c) Frazer Commission (d) MacDonnell Commission Sol.563.(c) Frazer Commission (The Indian Police Commission of 1902-03) - Established by the British. Headed by - Sir Andrew Frazer and Lord Curzon.

questions.question: Who among the following has been accused of committing the judicial murder of Raja Nand Kumar?
questions.explanation: Warren Hastings. Raja Nand Kumar (Nuncomar) was an Indian tax collector and he was the first Indian to be executed by hanging.

questions.question: _______ announced the bifurcation of the British Indian Empire into a secular India and Islamic Pakistan.
questions.explanation: Lord Louis Mountbatten (last Viceroy of India).

questions.question: Elphinstone was the Governor of which province of India during 1819-27 ?
questions.explanation: Bombay. Elphinstone: Known for the compilation of the Elphinstone code (a uniform scheme of criminal law). In 1808 he was sent to negotiate an alliance with the Afghan ruler Shah Shoja to prevent a Napoleonic advance upon India. Q.567. The Viceroy who took keen interest in the restoration and protection of historical monuments was . SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 1st shift) (a) Lord Ellenborough (b) Lord Auckland (c) Lord Lytton (d) Lord Curzon Sol.567.(d) Lord Curzon (1899-1905): Passed the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act in 1904. Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) - Founded in 1861 by Alexander Cunningham; Headquarters: New Delhi. Lord Ellenborough (1842-1844) - Annexation Of Sindh (1843). Lord Auckland (1836 - 1842) - The first Anglo-Afghan war occurred during his reign. Lord Lytton (1876-1880) - The Great Indian Famine of 1876-1878.

questions.question: The policy of dual system of government of Bengal was the brainchild of which Governor-General?
questions.explanation: Lord Clive (First governor of Bengal in 1765). Dual system - The administration of Bengal was divided into two parts : Diwani - The right to collect revenue was given to the company, and Nizamat - Administrative rights were given to Nawab. Warren Hastings abolished this system in Bengal in 1772.

questions.question: Governor general Lord Dalhousie described the Kingdom of _______"as a cherry that will drop into our mouth one day".
questions.explanation: Awadh. Lord Dalhousie said this in 1851. Awadh Kingdom was formally annexed to the British Empire in 1856. The doctrine declared that if an Indian ruler died without a male heir his kingdom would “lapse”, that is, become part of Company territory

questions.question: Under ________ (Governor General from 1813 to 1823) a new policy of "paramountcy" was initiated. Now the Company claimed that its authority was paramount or supreme, hence its power was greater than that of Indian states.
questions.explanation: Lord Hastings (Anglo-Nepal War took place between 1814 and 1816).

questions.question: “A History of British India” is a work published by ______.
questions.explanation: James Mill in 1817, a Scottish economist and political philosopher, published a massive three-volume work "The History of British India". In his book history was divided into three periods: Hindu, Muslim, and British.

questions.question: In 1856, Governor-General ______ decided that Bahadur Shah Zafar would be the last Mughal king and after his death none of his descendants would be recognised as kings – they would just be called princes.
questions.explanation: Lord Canning (1856-1862) - (Last Governor-General and first viceroy of India) - introduced Indian Penal Code (IPC), withdrew Doctrine of Lapse.

questions.question: Who among the following was the Viceroy of India during the formation of the Indian National Congress?
questions.explanation: Lord Dufferin (1884-1888).

questions.question: Which of the following Viceroys of British India took the first step to separate provincial finance from central finance and introduced financial decentralisation in India in 1870?
questions.explanation: Lord Mayo’s Resolution of on Financial Decentralisation visualised the development of local self-government institutions. Q.575. Which of the following statements is correct? I. Robert Clive had come to Madras from England in 1743 at the age of 18. II. After the battle of Buxar, the East India Company appointed Residents in Indian History states. SSC MTS 08/07/2022 (Evening) (a) Only I (b) Neither I nor II (c) Only II (d) Both I and II Sol.575.(d) Both I and II. Robert Clive was a soldier and first British administrator of Bengal, who was one of the creators of British power in India.

questions.question: Which of the following British officers issued the infamous ‘crawling order’ whereby Indians had to crawl on all fours to pass an alley?
questions.explanation: General Dyer. He was responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in Amritsar.

questions.question: Which of the following Viceroys of India addressed the Bengal famine of 1943 by ordering the army to distribute relief supplies to the starving rural Bengalis?
questions.explanation: Lord Linlithgow was the viceroy of India during the Bengal famine 1943. It is believed that the Bengal famine of 1943 which is estimated to have killed up to three million people was not caused by drought but instead was a result of a "complete policy failure" of the then-British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

questions.question: By which British statute were Indian representatives, for the first time, allocated seats for election in Indian Legislative Councils?
questions.explanation: Indian Councils Act, 1892. The act made a limited and indirect provision for the use of election in filling up some of the nonofficial seats both in the Central and provincial legislative councils.

questions.question: Which law was imposed in India during the command of General Dyer?
questions.explanation: Martial law. General Dyer enacted an Act on April 13, 1919, called martial law stating that no more than 2 people can form a group and meet at a place.

questions.question: In which year was the office of the first Accountant General established in India?
questions.explanation: In 1858 (the year the British took over administrative control of India from the East India Company) the office of the first Accountant General was established in India. Partition of Bengal and

questions.question: Which of the following battles is considered the formal beginning of the British Raj in India?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Plassey took place in Bengal on June 23, 1757. British East India Company troops, led by Robert Clive, confronted the forces of Siraj-ud-Daulah, the Nawab of Bengal, along with his French allies. The British East India Company won this battle.

questions.question: In which year was the battle of Buxar fought?
questions.explanation: 1764. Battle of Buxar : Fought between the British East India Company and the combined armies of Mir Qasim (Nawab of Bengal), Shuja-ud-Daulah (Nawab of Awadh), and the Mughal Emperor, Shah Alam II. The British East India Company was led by Hector Munro. The Britishers won this battle. The Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II - granted the Diwani of Bengal, Bihar and Orissa to the East India Company.

questions.question: Where was the first jute mill set up in India?
questions.explanation: Rishra (West Bengal, 1855). First Jute mill (Acland Mill) - Established by British entrepreneur George Acland and Bengali financier Babu By Sumber Sen in Bengal Presidency. Central Research Institute for Jute and Allied Fibers is located in West Bengal. National jute Board formed by National Jute board Act, 2008 under the Ministry of Textile. In 1854, the first modern cotton mill was established in Mumbai by Cowaszee Nanabhoy Davar.

questions.question: Which of the following modern industries were in operation in India during the British Rule ? a. Cotton b. Jute c. Iron and Steel

options.a: All of a, b and c

questions.explanation: All of a, b and c. British rulers never permitted modernization nor did they encourage the growth of industries. The unbalanced and lopsided growth structures were a legacy of British rule in India. The first iron and steel mill was established in 1907, in Jamshedpur by Tata Iron and Steel Company. Q.668. In the 18th century, the development of cotton industries in Britain resulted in _________ . SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Morning) (a) Increase in demand of Indian textile in Britain (b) Decline of textiles production in India (c) Increase in demand of Indian textile in India (d) Decline of British textiles industries in India Sol.668.(b) Reason for decline: Export of textiles to England became more and more difficult because the British Government imposed high duties on Indian textiles. Thorp Mill (1764) - The first water-powered cotton mill in the world was constructed at Royton, Lancashire (England). The first cotton textile mill (India) - Established at Fort Glastor near Kolkata (1818).

questions.question: In 1600, the East India company acquired a charter from_________.
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth I. By the Charter (1600 A.D), they got the sole right to trade with the East, without competition from other British traders. The Company's ships first arrived in India, at the port of Surat, in 1608.

questions.question: The first English factory was set up on the banks of the river _______ in 1651.
questions.explanation: Hugli. First English factory (Temporary) in India - Masulipattam (1611). First English factory (Permanent) in India - Surat (1613). First factory of other European Companies in India: Dutch - Masulipatnam (Andhra Pradesh) in 1605, Portuguese - Calicut (Kerala) in 1500, French - Surat (Gujarat) in 1668.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs is correct regarding the East India Company army? I. Sawar — Men on horses Il. Musket — A heavy gun used by infantry soldiers
questions.explanation: Both l and II.

questions.question: The British East India Company captured Pondicherry (Puducherry) from the French in the year ______.
questions.explanation: 1761. Pondicherry got its freedom from the French on 1st November 1954. The Union Territory of Puducherry comprises the erstwhile French colonies viz. Puducherry, Karaikal, Mahe and Yanam.

questions.question: Which monument was built in 1924 to welcome King George V and Queen Mary?
questions.explanation: Gateway of India. The Gateway of India is an Arch-Monument built in the early 20th century in the city of Mumbai.

questions.question: In 1908 Khudiram Bose along with _________ was involved in throwing a bomb at a carriage believing it to be occupied by Kingsford, the then sitting judge of Muzaffarpur
questions.explanation: Prafulla Chaki was an Indian revolutionary associated with the Jugantar group of revolutionaries. Khudiram Bose was among the youngest martyrs of India's freedom struggle against the British. At just 15, he had joined Anushilan Samiti and took part in several revolutionary activities against the British Raj. He was executed on August 11, 1908, in Muzaffarpur jail in Bihar.

questions.question: During British rule in India, who among the following unfurled the flag of India in Germany in 1907?
questions.explanation: Madam Bhikaji Cama. She founded the ‘Paris Indian Society’. Annie Besant (British socialist) - Founded Home rule league in India and she was first woman president of Indian National Congress (INC). Sarojini Naidu - First Indian woman president of the INC. Sucheta Kriplani holds the distinction of being India's first female Chief Minister, serving the state of Uttar Pradesh. Q.688. Who among the following revolutionaries was one of the co-founders of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA) which got established in 1928 at Ferozeshah Kotla in Delhi? Graduate Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Gopal Krishna Gokhale (b) Aurobindo Ghosh (c) Bhagat Singh (d) Mahatma Gandhi Sol.688.(c) Bhagat Singh. The Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA), formerly known as the Hindustan Republican Army (HRA) was founded by Ram Prasad Bismil, Sachindra Nath Bakshi, Sachindranath Sanyal, and Jogesh Chandra Chatterjee. HRA was established in October 1924 in Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, by revolutionaries including Ram Prasad Bismil, Jogesh Chatterjee, Chandrashekhar Azad, Yogendra Shukla, and Sachindranath Sanyal. HRA took to socialist ideas, under Chandrashekhar Azad leadership, in 1928. Q.689. Who among the following founded the Khudai Khidmatgars or the Red Shirts, a powerful non-violent movement? Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan (b) BR Ambedkar (c) Subhas Chandra Bose (d) Mahatma Gandhi Sol.689.(a) Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan, also known as 'Frontier Gandhi' and 'Bacha Khan', was a prominent freedom fighter and advocate of non-violence. He became the first non-Indian to receive Bharat Ratna in 1987. B.R. Ambedkar was the first Law Minister of India and the architect of the Indian Constitution. Subhas Chandra Bose was an Indian nationalist and the founder of the All India Forward Bloc. Mahatma Gandhi was an Indian lawyer and anti-colonial nationalist, renowned for his principles of non-violence.

questions.question: The 'Servants of India Society' was the brainchild of which of the following leaders ?
questions.explanation: Gopal Krishna Gokhale founded - Ranade Institute of Economics (1908). He started an English weekly newspaper, The Hitavada (The people's paper). Servants of India Society was founded in 1905. Chitranjan Das is popularly known as Deshbandhu. Lala Lajpat Rai - Punjab National bank.

questions.question: ‘Mitra Mela’ was a revolutionary organisation founded by:
questions.explanation: Vinayak Savarkar. Mitra Mela was founded in the year 1899 in Nashik. He and his brother Ganesh Damodar established the society (later renamed Abhinav Bharat Society or the Young India Society). It believed in the concept of Armed rebellion to overthrow the British.

questions.question: On 8th April 1929, who among the following two revolutionists threw a bomb in the Central Legislative Assembly?

options.b: Bhagat Singh and Ram Prasad Bismil

questions.explanation: Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt. They threw bomb against the passage of the Public Safety Bill and the Trade Disputes Bill which would reduce the civil liberties of citizens. They were members of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association. On 23rd March, Bhagat Singh was hanged in the Lahore jail at the age of 23.

questions.question: Who is regarded as the 'Mother of Indian Revolution' ?
questions.explanation: Madame Cama : She is famous for hosting the precursor to the Indian National Flag on foreign soil (Stuttgart in Germany).

questions.question: Which great leader died due to his injuries in the Anti-Simon Commission Protest of 1928?
questions.explanation: Lala Lajpat Rai (Freedom fighters). He was also called ‘Punjab Kesari’ and 'Lion of Punjab'. Bal Gangadhar Tilak - Founded the Home Rule League in 1916. Simon Commission - Indian Statutory Commission, group of seven Members, not a single Indian member in it, Headed by Sir John Simon. Simon Commission came to India in 1928.

questions.question: Who among the following, along with her close associates, started the secret congress radio during the Quit India Movement?
questions.explanation: Usha Mehta. Awards - Padma Vibhushan (1998).

questions.question: The statement- "We shall die to awaken the nation" was made by.
questions.explanation: Bagha Jatin (Jatindranath Mukherjee) - Born on 7th December 1879 in Kayagram (Nadia district) present-day Bangladesh. He acquired the moniker History ‘Bagha Jatin’ when he single-handedly killed a Bengal tiger in 1906. Bir Tikendrajit Singh - He was a prince of the independent Kingdom of Manipur. Q.697. Which freedom fighter was involved in the Kakori Train Action in 1925, for which the British government condemned him to death? SSC MTS 15/06/2023 (Morning) (a) Ram Prasad Bismil (b) Lala Hardayal (c) Vinayak Damodar Savarkar (d) Mahatma Gandhi Sol.697.(a) Ram Prasad Bismil. Kakori Train Action - It was a train robbery (part of Kakori Conspiracy) that took place on 9 August 1925, near Lucknow. It was organised by the Hindustan Republican Association (HRA). Ram Prasad Bismil, Ashfaqulla Khan, and Roshan Singh were hanged on 19 December 1927. Rajendra Nath Lahiri hanged on December 17, 1927.

questions.question: The Revolutionary Socialist Party was established in ________.
questions.explanation: 19 March 1940 by Tridib Chaudhuri. It has its roots in the Bengali liberation movement Anushilan Samiti and the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association . The first general secretary of the party was Jogesh Chandra Chatterjee.

questions.question: Who said the following words? “Sarfaroshi ki tamanna ab hamare dil me hai, dekhna hai zor kitna baazu-e-qaatil mein hai”
questions.explanation: Ramprasad Bismil (poet, writer, freedom fighter) - He participated in the Mainpuri Conspiracy of 1918, and the Kakori Conspiracy of 1925. Subhash Chandra Bose - “Jai Hind” & “Tum Mujhe Khoon Do, Mai Tumhe Azadi Dunga”. Mahatma Gandhi - “Karo ya Maro”. Muhammad Iqbal - “Sare Jahan Se Achha Hindustan Hamara”. Bankim Chandra Chatterjee - “Vande Mataram”. Pandit Madan Mohan Malviya - “Satyameva Jayate”. Q.700. Which of the following revolutionaries stated during his trial that "he did not wish to glorify the cult of the bomb and pistol but wanted a revolution in society"? SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (1st Shift) (a) Bhagat Singh (b) Surya Sen (c) Sachindra Nath Sanyal (d) Barindra Kumar Ghosh Sol.700.(a) Bhagat Singh and Batukeshwar Dutt threw a bomb in the Central Legislative Assembly on 8 April 1929. Sachindra Nath Sanyal was co-founder of the Hindustan Republican Association (HRA) in 1924. Barindra Kumar Ghosh (younger brother of Sri Aurobindo) published the Bengali weekly Jugantar patrika (1906). Q.701. Who among the following revolutionaries was associated with Swadesh Bandhav Samiti? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (2nd Shift) (a) Chandrasekhar Azad (b) Bhagat Singh (c) Rajguru (d) Ashwini Kumar Dutta Sol.701.(d) Ashwini Kumar Dutta founded the Swadesh Bandhab Samiti on 6th August in Barisal district (Bangladesh). Weekly paper: Barisal Hitaishi. He was responsible for the creation of the Cooperative Hindustan Bank in 1908. Q.702. Who among the following organized the armed rebellion against the British Raj in 1879 in Maharashtra? SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Vasudev Balwant Phadke (b) Birsa Munda (c) Buddhu Bhagat (d) Tikendrajit Singh Sol.702.(a) Vasudev Balwant Phadke - Known as the First Revolutionary and also the ‘Father of militant nationalism in India.’ Birsa Munda also known as Dharti Aaba (Father of Earth), belonged to the Munda tribe in the Chotanagpur Plateau area.

questions.question: The Communist Party of India was founded at ________ in October 1920.
questions.explanation: Tashkent. M.N. Roy (Manabendra Nath Roy), Abani Mukherji, founded the Communist Party of India (CPI) in 1920 in Tashkent (now the capital of Uzbekistan). The Communist Party of India was officially formed (1925) in Kanpur. Its founders included M. N. Roy, his wife Evelyn Trent, Abani Mukherji, and M. P. T. Acharya (Mandayam Parthasarathi Tirumal Acharya).

questions.question: The Koraput Revolution occurred in ______ during the Quit India Movement
questions.explanation: Odisha. Koraput revolution {On August 25, 1942, 19 people died on the spot in police firing at Paparandi in Nabarangpur (Odisha). More than a thousand were jailed in Koraput district (Odisha). Veer Lakhan Nayak (Gandhi of Odisha) was hanged}. Quit India movement (8 August 1942 - 1944) - led by Mahatma Gandhi. Q.705. Which of the following statements about Bharat Naujawan Sabha is INCORRECT? Graduate Level 05/08/2022 (Shift - 3) (a) It was founded in Punjab (b) Bhagat Singh became its founding secretary (c) It was established in 1927 (d) It started political work among the youth, peasants, and workers Sol.705.(c) Bharat Naujawan Sabha was founded in Lahore (1926) by Bhagat Singh.

questions.question: Who among the following led the famous Indigo Revolt in Bengal?

options.b: Bishnu Charan Biswas and Digambar Biswas

questions.explanation: Digambar Biswas and Bishnu Biswas of Nadia district Bengal led the Indigo revolt. This Revolt began as a nonviolent strike in March 1859, as the ryots of a village in Bengal's Nadia district all agreed to refuse to grow any more indigo. Q.707. Which of the following revolutionaries was arrested by the British as an accused in the Alipore Bomb Conspiracy Case? SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Kanailal Dutta (b) Rajendra Lahiri (c) Roshan Singh (d) Ashfaq Ullah Khan Sol.707.(a) Kanailal Dutta was among the 33 revolutionaries who got arrested in the Emperor vs Aurobindo Ghosh (Alipore Bomb Case). The Alipore Bomb case was a historic trial in which the British Government tried to implicate Sri Aurobindo in various revolutionary activities.

questions.question: At which of the following jails was Khudiram Bose sent to the gallows?
questions.explanation: Muzaffarpur. Khudiram Bose was arrested for trying to assassinate British judge Douglas Kingsford, he was executed on August 11, 1908, in Muzaffarpur jail in Bihar. Q.709. Who among the following persons was associated with the Chittagong Armoury Raid? SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Evening) (a) Vishnu Sharan Dublish (b) Sachindra Nath Bakshi (c) Manmath Nath Gupta (d) Ardhendu Dastidar Sol.709.(d) Ardhendu Dastidar.

questions.question: Who among the following killed Michael O'Dwyer, the British officer responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
questions.explanation: Udham Singh. O'Dwyer, was shot dead at a joint meeting of the East India Association and the Central Asian Society in Caxton Hall, in retaliation for the massacre in Jallianwala Bagh Amritsar. Q.711. Who among the following assassinated Sir William Hutt Curzon Wyllie in London? SSC CGL 13/08/2021 (Afternoon) (a) Surya Sen (b) Madan Lal Dhingra (c) Sukhdev Thapar (d) Khudiram Bose Sol.711.(b) Madan Lal Dhingra was an Indian revolutionary independence activist. While studying in England, he assassinated Sir William Hutt Curzon Wyllie, a British official, cited as one of the first acts of revolution in the Indian independence movement in the 20th century.

questions.question: Veer Surendra Sai was a freedom fighter from:
questions.explanation: Odisha. Veer Surendra Sai started his revolt against British rule long before 1857 and continued his guerrilla war against the British authority from till long after the struggle led by the Rani of Jhansi, Tantia Tope, Kunwar Singh and others had subsided. Q.713. Who was the first general secretary of the All India Farmer’s Congress? SSC CGL 17/08/2021(Afternoon) (a) Acharya Narendra Dev (b) Swami Sahjanand Saraswati (c) Sardar Vallabhai Patel (d) N.G. Ranga Sol.713.(d) NG Ranga. He was a freedom fighter from Andhra Pradesh and also received Padma Vibhusan from the President of India for his contributions to the peasants' movement.

questions.question: Who among the following was a leader who led a revolt against British rule from North East India?
questions.explanation: Rani Gaidinliu was a Naga spiritual and political leader who led a revolt against British rule in India. At the age of 13, she joined the Heraka religious movement established by her cousin Haipou Jadonang in Manipur.

questions.question: Who among the following was NOT one of the founders of the Ahrar Movement in British India?
questions.explanation: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was an Indian independence activist, writer, and a senior leader of the Indian National Congress. After India’s independence, he became the first Minister of Education. The Ahrar Movement was started by Muslims who had lost faith in the Khilafat Movement. It was founded by Maulana Muhammad Ali, Hakim Ajmal Khan, Hasan Imam, Maulana Zafar Ali Khan, and Mazhar-ul-Haq . Q.745. Who among the following participated in the All-World Religious Conference (Parliament of Religions) held in 1893 in Chicago? SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024 (a) Swami Dayanand (b) Raja Ram Mohan Roy (c) Swami Shahjananda (d) Swami Vivekananda Sol.745.(d) Swami Vivekananda was a disciple of Ramakrishna. He gave his famous speech at the Parliament of World Religions in Chicago in 1893. He established the Belur Math in West Bengal, and Ramakrishna Mission in 1897. Q.746. Who founded the Prarthana Samaj in Mumbai in 1867? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Atmaram Pandurang (b) Gopal Krishna Gokhale (c) Shri Ram Bajpai (d) Ram Mohan Roy Sol.746.(a) Atmaram Pandurang. Prarthana Samaj was founded with an aim to make people believe in one God and worship only one God.

questions.question: When was a Madrasa opened in Kolkata to promote the study of Arabic, Persian and Islamic law?
questions.explanation: 1781 C.E. It was set up by Warren Hastings of the first Governor General of East India Company. Other universities and colleges: Aligarh Muslim University, originally as the Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental College (1875), Jamia Millia Islamia (1920), Darul Uloom Deoband (1866), Osmania University (1918).

questions.question: Which of the following social reformers of 19th century India was the author of 'Stree Purush Tulana'?
questions.explanation: Tarabai Shinde (1850-1910) : She was a pioneering Indian social reformer and writer who advocated for women's rights. Her notable work, "Stree Purush Tulana" (A Comparison Between Women and Men), published in 1882, critiqued the patriarchal society and argued for gender equality. Swarnakumari Devi : She was the first Indian Woman editor (the editor of the women’s journal Bharati). Usha Mehta wrote the book “Mahatma Gandhi and Humanism”. Pandita Ramabai : She wrote the High Caste Hindu Women, Stree Dharma Neeti, American Encounter.

questions.question: Samata Sainik Dal was formed in 1927 by whom among the following personalities?
questions.explanation: BR Ambedkar. He founded ‘Bahishkrit Hitakarini Sabha' in 1924 to promote and uplift the education of untouchables. Mahatma Gandhi founded - Harijan Sevak Sangh in 1932. Narayana Guru founded the Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam (SNDP) in 1903. Q.750. Who among the following founded the Atmiya Sabha in 1814? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Keshab Chandra Sen (b) Raja Rammohun Roy (c) Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar (d) Debendranath Tagore Sol.750.(b) Raja Rammohun Roy, known as "the Father of Indian Renaissance," was an Indian reformer and writer who co-founded the Brahmo Sabha in 1828, leading to the formation of the Brahmo Samaj, a significant socio-religious reform movement. Honored with the title of Raja by Mughal emperor Akbar II, his influence marked the beginning of modern thought in Kolkata, particularly with the establishment of the Atmiya Sabha in 1814. Q.751. Which of the following Sikh reform movements was started in 1873 in Amritsar? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Babbar Akali Movement (b) Akali Movement (c) Singh Sabha Movement (d) Gurudwara Movement Sol.751.(c) Singh Sabha Movement. It was a reform organization for Sikhs, with the first Sabhas established in Amritsar in 1873 and Lahore in 1879. The Babbar Akali Movement: It was founded at the Sikh Educational Conference in Hoshiarpur in 1921. The Gurudwara Reform Movement (Akali Movement) was started in Amritsar in 1920.

questions.question: Who founded the Arya Samaj in Mumbai in 1875 ?
questions.explanation: Swami Dayanand Saraswati, an Indian philosopher, is known for his work Satyarth Prakash and the slogan “Go Back to the Vedas.” He also initiated the Shuddhi Movement. Debendranath Tagore founded the Tattvabodhini Sabha in 1839 and joined the Brahmo Samaj (founded by Raja Rammohan Roy in 1828) in 1842. The Ramakrishna Mission was established by Swami Vivekananda in May 1897 at Belur Math, West Bengal.

questions.question: With reference to Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar, consider the following statements. i) He protested child marriage and polygamy. ii) Due to his efforts, the first Hindu Widow Remarriage Act, 1856, was introduced. iii) He was primarily known for his scholarship in Persian language. Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation: i, ii. Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar's efforts led to the passage of the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act (Act XV) on July 16, 1856, legalizing widow remarriage in India under East India Company rule. Drafted by Lord Dalhousie and enacted by Lord Canning, the law took effect on July 26, 1856.

questions.question: Guru Ghasidas led which of the following movements to improve the social condition of leather workers in British India?
questions.explanation: Satnami Movement. Guru Ghasidas, the Guru of Satnam Dharma, was a Satnami saint and renowned scholar from Chhattisgarh in the early 19th century. He began preaching in the deep forests of Chhattisgarh, spreading his teachings. The Satnami movement, also known as Satnampanth or Sadhanpanth, was a social and religious movement in India that challenged the caste system and the prevailing political and religious authorities. Q.755. Which was the first socio-religious organisation established in Bombay in 1840 to work for the annihilation of caste? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd shift) (a) Dharma Sabha (b) Satyashodhak Samaj (c) Paramhans Mandali (d) Vishwa Jain Sangathan Sol.755.(c) Paramhans Mandali : Founder - Durgaram Mehtaji. Dharma Sabha was formed in 1830 in Calcutta by Radhakanta Deb, primarily for the defense of Hindu orthodoxy.

questions.question: Which organisation was started in the Pune district of Maharashtra in the 1870s with the aim of promoting education and social rights among the underprivileged group of the society?
questions.explanation: Satyashodhak Samaj was founded by Jyotiba Phule in 1873, It is also known as the Society of Seekers of Truth. Its aim was to access social rights and civil liberties for people of lower castes, underprivileged and women. Jyotiba Phule (a social activist) - Established the first school for girls in India in Pune in 1848. Dalit term was first used by him.

questions.question: Who among the following was the pioneer of widow remarriages in Maharashtra and also started a girls' school in Poona along with his wife?
questions.explanation: Jyotirao Govindrao Phule. He was a prominent social reformer from Maharashtra who dedicated his life to eradicating untouchability and caste discrimination. Together with his wife, Savitribai, he played a key role in promoting women's education in India, founding the first girls' school in 1848 at Bhidewada, Pune. Major Publications: Tritiya Ratna, Gulamgiri, and Shetkarayacha Aasud.

questions.question: Match the following movements with their respective founders: a. Faraizi Movement I. Sayyid Ahmad of Rae Bareli b. Mohammedan Literary Society II. Sir Syed Ahmad Khan c. Indian Patriotic Association III. Nawab Abdul Latif d. Wahabi Movement IV. Haji Shariatullah

options.a: a - IV, b - III, c - Il, d - I
options.b: a - III, b - IV, c - II, d - I
options.c: a - Il, b - I, c - IV, D - III
options.d: a - I, b - II, c - III, d - IV

questions.explanation: a - IV, b - III, c - Il, d - I. Other Movement/Organisation and their Founders: Bhoodan movement - Acharya Vinobha Bhave, Servants of India Society - GK Gokhale, Khudai Khidmatgar - Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan, Arya Samaj - Dayanand Saraswati, Self-respect Movement - EV Ramaswamy Naicker, Tattvabodhini Sabha - Debendranath Tagore, Abhinav Bharat - Vir Savarkar, and Narmada Bachao - Medha Patkar. Q.759. Who among the following founded the Muhammedan Anglo-Oriental College in Aligarh for the spread of Western education? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Sir Syed Ahmed Khan (b) Badrudeen Tyabji (c) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad (d) Syed Ameer Ali Sol.759.(a) Sir Syed Ahmed Khan. In 1875, he founded the Muhammadan Anglo Oriental College on the pattern of Oxford and Cambridge universities. The college later grew into Aligarh Muslim University. He started the Aligarh movement to promote western education among muslims. He established the Scientific Society in 1864.

questions.question: Henry Louis Vivian Derozio, a teacher at Hindu College, Calcutta, in the 1820s, promoted radical ideas and encouraged his pupils to question all authority. Referred to as the _________ his students attacked tradition and custom, demanded education for women and campaigned for the freedom of thought and expression
questions.explanation: Young Bengal Movement. Other Reform Organisations and its Founders : The Brahmo Samaj (1828) - Raja Ram Mohan Roy, The Veda Samaj (1864) - Keshab Chandra Sen and K. Sridharalu Naidu, The Prarthana Samaj (1867) - Atmaram Pandurang. Q.761. In which of the following years, was the Self-Respect movement started in Tamil Nadu region? Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 4) (a) 1925 (b) 1916 (c) 1910 (d) 1930 Sol.761.(a) 1925. The Self-Respect Movement was a social and political movement in South India that sought to achieve equality and social justice for people oppressed by the caste system. The movement was initiated by E. V. Ramasamy (also known as Periyar). Q.762. Who among the following is associated with the Theosophical Society? Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) Annie Besant (b) Tarabai Shinde (c) Sarojini Naidu (d) Savitri Bai Phule Sol.762.(a) Annie Besant had come to India in 1893. She laid the foundation of the Central Hindu College in Benaras in 1898. The Theosophical Society: Theosophy represents the wisdom at the core of all religions when stripped of superstitions and excesses. It was founded by Madame H. P. Blavatsky and Colonel Olcott in New York (United States) in 1875. In 1882, they shifted their headquarters to Adyar (Madras Presidency).

questions.question: Who among the following is NOT associated with the Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha?
questions.explanation: Syed Ahmed Khan. The Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha was a social reform organization founded in 1851 by Parsis in Bombay (now Mumbai) to promote reform in the ancient Zoroastrian religion. It was composed of Dadabhai Naoroji, J.B. Wacha, S.S History Bengalee and Naoroji Furdonji, with the funding from K.N. Kama. Q.764. Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about Prarthana Samaj? A. Prarthana Samaj or ‘Prayer Society’ in Sanskrit, was a movement for religious and social reforms. B. Prarthana Samaj was founded in 1863 by Dadoba Pandurang and his brother Atmaram Pandurang. SSC CHSL Tier II 10/01/2024 (a) Neither A nor B (b) Only A (c) Both A and B (d) Only B Sol.764.(b) Only A. The Prarthana Samaj was established in Bombay by Dr. Atma Ram Pandurang in 1867. Aim - To remove caste restriction, abolish child marriage, encourage women education and promotes widow remarriages. Members - R.C. Bhandarkar and Justice Mahadev Govind Ranade.

questions.question: Sree Narayana Guru considered the differences based on caste and religion as meaningless and advocated the principle of ‘One Caste, one Religion and one God’ for all. He belonged to which of the following organisations?

questions.question: Who received the title Pandita from the faculty of Calcutta University for her knowledge of Sanskrit?

questions.question: Rani Gaidinliu is associated with which of the following movements?

SSC CHSL 06/08/2021 (Morning) (a) Mahadev Govind Ranade (b) Ram Manohar Lohia (c) Bal Gangadhar Tilak (d) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad Sol.841.(d) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad. questions.question: Who was the President of the Indian National Congress when India won its freedom in the year 1947 ?

The All-India Muslim League was formed during the tenure of Lord Minto II, who served as the Viceroy of India from 1905 to 1910. The League was founded in Dhaka, British India (Bangladesh), in 1906 and supported the partition of Bengal. It sought separate electorates for Muslims, a demand that was conceded by the government in 1909.

questions.question: The Lucknow Pact was signed in ____________ by Congress and the Muslim League to work in alliance for representative government.

questions.question: Muslim League observed ______ as ‘Direct Action Day’.
questions.explanation: August 1946. Muhammad Ali Jinnah declared August as 'Direct Action Day' and called for Muslims all over the country to 'suspend all business'. Direct Action Day, also known as the 1946 Calcutta Killings.

questions.question: In which of the following battles did Muhammad of Ghor defeat Jayachandra of Gahadavala dynasty in 1194 AD?
questions.explanation: Battle of Chandawar. Mu'izz ad-Din Muhammad, also known as Muhammad Ghori, was the Sultan of the Ghurid Empire. In 1018 he plundered the holy city of Mathura and also attacked Kannauj. In 1019 and 1029 he undertook two raids on Gangetic valley. In 1025 he attacked Somnath (a town on the coast of Kathiawar).

questions.question: In which year Timur's invasion of Delhi took place?
questions.explanation: 1398. Timur invaded India in 1398 during the reign of Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq of the Tughlaq Dynasty. After the invasion, Timur appointed Khizr Khan as the ruler of Punjab. Khizr Khan later founded the Sayyid Dynasty (1414–1451).

questions.question: The famous Arabic scholar Al Biruni came into contact with India through _____ in the eleventh century A.D.

Genghis Khan (original name Temujin) was a Mongolian warrior-ruler, one of the most famous conquerors of history, who consolidated tribes into a unified Mongolia and then extended his empire across Asia to the Adriatic Sea. His last campaign against the Western Xia.

questions.question: Who among the following was the best-known Chahamana ruler?

Vigraharaja II {(971-998), Chahamana dynasty}. Prithviraj I {(1090 -1110), Chahamana dynasty}. Vasudeva {(73 BCE to 28 BCE), founder of Kanvas Dynasty}. Delhi Sultanate (1206 AD to 1526 AD)

questions.question: Which was the first dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Mamluk dynasty: Also known as the Slave Dynasty, founded by Qutb-ud-din Aibak, who became the first Sultan of Delhi in 1206. The dynasty ruled Delhi from 1206 to 1290. Khilji Dynasty: The second dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1290 to 1320. Tughlaq Dynasty: The third dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1320 to 1414. Lodi Dynasty: The last dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1451 to 1526.

questions.question: Ibn Battuta, who visited India during Delhi Sultanate, originally belonged to which country?

Other notable foreign travelers : Hiuen Tsang (China) - Harshavardhana's court; Al-Beruni (Persia) - Came with Mahmud of Ghazni; Francois Bernier (France) - Shahjahan and Aurangzeb's court. Q.282. In reference to the Delhi Sultanate, what was the ‘Group of Forty’? Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) They were mostly powerful Turkish slaves of Iltutmish, who took power in the interregnum following Sultana Raziyya’s killing. (b) They were forty military archers who distinguished themselves by their bravery in the Delhi Sultanate. (c) They were forty banjara leaders who transferred military supplies in times of war. (d) They were forty Rajput nobles who planned a coup to dethrone Qutb ud Din Aibak in 1210. Sol.282.(a) The 'Group of Forty' (Chalisa) in the Delhi Sultanate was a council of powerful Turkish slaves, formed by Iltutmish to assist in governance.

questions.question: Who was the Sultan of Delhi at the time of the establishment of Vijayanagara Empire?
questions.explanation: Mohammad bin Tughlaq . Vijaynagar Empire: Established - 1336 by Harihara and Bukka. Capital - Hampi. The Empire stretched from Krishna river in the north to extreme south of the peninsula. Dynasties with first and last rulers - Sangama Dynasty (Harihara I, Rajasekhara), Saluva Dynasty (Saluva Narasimha, Sadasiva), Tuluva Dynasty (Rama, Venkata), Aravidu Dynasty (Tirumala Raya, Sriranga III).

questions.question: Which of the following systems of the Delhi sultanate had a influence on the Bahmani and Vijayanagar kingdoms?
questions.explanation: Iqtadari System:- Introduced by Shamsuddin IIltutmish (3rd Sultan of Delhi). Provision - Under this system, the land of the empire was divided into several large and small tracts called Iqta and assigned these Iqtas to his soldiers, officers and nobles. Administrative Terms used in Sultanate Period: Dabir (Secretary), Faujdar (Commander of army), Sipahsalar (Commander), Amil (Revenue officer), Diwan (Office: the central secretariat).

questions.question: During the Sultanate of Delhi, the term "Ulema" was associated with ______.
questions.explanation: Learned theologians and Jurists. Officers in Delhi Sultanate - State Level: Amil (Revenue Officer), Barid (Intelligence agents), Khwaja (Accounts Officer), Kotwal (Head of city law and order), Muhatasib (Head of municipality law and order), Muftis (Expounder of law).

questions.question: Who among the following was the daughter of Iltumish, a ruler of Slave Mamluk dynasty?
questions.explanation: Razia Sultan. In 1236, Razia Sultan (Mamluk dynasty), succeeded her father to the Sultanate of Delhi. She sent an expedition against Ranthambore to control the Rajputs. Mamluk dynasty (1206 to 1290) - Founded by Qutbuddin Aibak (Lakh Baksh). Q.287. Under the Delhi Sultanate, a religious tax ________ was imposed on the wealthy and rich Muslims in India. SSC MTS 16/06/2023 (Evening) (a) Firuz (b) Mamluk (c) Zakat (d) Kismat Sol.287.(c) Zakat. Zakat tax was abolished by Sikander lodi. Firoz Shah Tughlaq introduced four types of taxes History based on the Quran. They were Kharaj (Land tax), Khams (Tax on booty captured in war), Jizya (Imposed on non muslim), and Zakat.

questions.question: Who composed Tabaqat-i-Nasiri in the Delhi Sultanate period?
questions.explanation: "Tabaqat-i-Nasiri'' (1260) was written by Minhaj-i-Siraj in Persian language. He was a chronicler during the rule of Sultan Iltutmish. Hasan Nizami (Persian language poet) wrote Tajul-Maasir (the first official history of the Delhi Sultanate). Sufi poet Amir Khusro was the court poet of Alauddin Khilji. His famous works: Tughluq Nama, Wast-ul-Hayat, Nuh Sipihr, Ashiqa, Khamsa, Baqia-Naqia. Ziauddin Barani (Muslim political thinker of Delhi Sultanate) wrote Tarikh-i-Firozshahi and Fatwa-i-Jahandari.

questions.question: Zafar khan was a famous General of which of the following rulers of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji’s Generals : Hizabruddin (Zafar Khan), Almas Beg (Ulugh Khan), Malik Kafur (Taj al-Din Izz al-Dawla), Nusrat Khan (Malik Nusrat Jalesari). Muhammad bin Tughlaq (Jauna Khan): Introduced token currency.

questions.question: Who among the following rulers ruled before Prithviraj Chauhan over Delhi?
questions.explanation: Ananga Pala Tomar - founded Delhi in 1052. An inscription of Vikram Samvat in the Delhi Museum confirms the founding of Delhi by the Tomars.

questions.question: Who was the author of Tarikh - i - Mubarak Shahi which is a Persian language chronicle of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Yahya bin Ahmad Sirhindi. Amir Khusrau (Books - ‘Tughlaq Nama’, ‘Nuh Sipihr’, ‘Khazain ul Futuh’ ). Q.292. Who was the ruler of Delhi sultanate when Ibn Batuta came to India? SSC CHSL 04/08/2021 (Afternoon) (a) Alauddin Khilji (b) Firuz Shah Tughlaq (c) Muhammad Bin Tughlaq (d) Ibrahim Lodi Sol.292.(c) Muhammad Bin Tughlaq was the ruler of the Delhi sultanate when Ibn Batuta came to India. Muhammad bin Tughluq was the Sultan of Delhi from 1324 to 1351 from the Tughlaq Dynasty. Slave Dynasty Q.293. Who was appointed as the governor of Bengal by Sultan Balban after the revolt and subsequent death of Tughril Beg? SSC MTS 05/11/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Zafar Khan (b) Bughra Khan (c) Khizr Khan (d) Mahmud Khan Sol.293.(b) Bughra Khan. After Nasir-ud-din Mahmud died in 1266, Ghiyasuddin Balban (1266-1287) ascended the throne. He was also the first muslim ruler to formulate the ‘theory of Kingship’. Balban introduced the practice of Sijda (prostration) and Paibos (kissing the feet of Monarch). Tughril Beg revolted against Balban, Sultan of Delhi, and declared himself as an independent ruler of Bengal in 1279. Q.294. Which of the following departments of Delhi Sultanate was reorganized by Balban? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Diwan-i-Ishtiaq (b) Diwan-i-Arz (c) Diwan-i-Risalat (d) Diwan-i-Mustakhraj Sol.294.(b) Diwan-i-Arz (Department of Military). Central Departments of Delhi Sultanates: ‘Diwan-i-Risalat’ - Department of Appeals, ‘Diwan-i-Bandagan’- Department of Slaves, ‘Diwan-i-Qaza-i-Mamalik’ - Department of Justice, ‘Diwan-i-Ishtiaq’ - Department of Pensions, ‘Diwan - i - Mustakhraj’- Departments of Arrears, ‘Diwan-i-Khairat’ - Department of Charity, ‘Diwan-i-Kohi’- Department of Agriculture, ‘Diwan -i-Wizarat’ - Head Wazir, ‘Diwan -i-Waqoof’ - Department of Revenue.

questions.question: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi primarily adopted a policy of consolidation rather than expansion?
questions.explanation: Balban. Ghiyasuddin Balban (Reigned : 1266–1287) was the ninth sultan of the Slave dynasty of Delhi. He belonged to the famous group of 40 Turkic slaves of Iltutmish. He was the first Muslim ruler to formulate the 'theory of kingship' similar to the 'theory of the divine right of the kings'. He established the military department “Diwan-i-Arz”.

questions.question: Raziya Sultan was the first and only female ruler of the Sultanate, who ascended the throne in:
questions.explanation: 1236 AD. Razia Sultana was the daughter of Iltutmish and served as the Sultan of Delhi from 1236 to 1240. She was married to Malik Altunia, the governor of Bathinda. She was buried in Kaithal, Haryana. She was imprisoned by Malik Ikhtiyar-ud-din Altunia in the Qila Mubarak Fort (Bathinda). The book "Razia Queen of India" was written by Rafiq Zakaria about her life. Q.297. Which of the following Delhi sultans introduced two coins, namely silver tanka and copper jital? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Qutbuddin Aibak (b) Bahlul Lodi (c) Ghiyasuddin Balban (d) Iltutmish Sol.297.(d) Iltutmish (1210 - 1236). He was a slave and son-in-law of Qutubuddin Aibak, considered the real founder of Delhi Sultanate.

questions.question: Balban followed the tradition of ‘Sijda and Pabos’ from which of following traditions?
questions.explanation: Persian. 'Sijda' refers to the act of prostration or bowing down, and 'Pabos' refers to the kissing of the monarch's feet.

questions.question: Who among the following Delhi Sultanate rulers took the policy of ‘blood and iron’ to deal with the Mewati community?
