questions.explanation: Balban. The policy of 'blood and iron' implied being ruthless to the enemies, use of sword, harshness and strictness and shedding blood. Ghiyas ud din Balban was the ninth sultan of the Mamluk/Slave dynasty of Delhi.

questions.question: To control the prices, which of the following Sultans of Delhi set up three different markets for different commodities in Delhi ?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji. Alauddin set up three different markets for different commodities in Delhi. These markets were the grain market (Mandi), cloth market (Sarai Adl) and the market for horses, slaves, cattle, etc. To ensure implementation, Alauddin appointed a superintendent (Shahna-i-Mandi) who was assisted by an intelligence officer.

questions.question: The first southern campaign of Alauddin Khilji in 1307-08 AD was led to which of the following regions?
questions.explanation: Devagiri (modern-day Daulatabad, Maharashtra). This campaign marked the beginning of the Delhi Sultanate's expansion into southern India. Alauddin Khilji (1296 -1316) was the second sultan of the Khilji dynasty. Campaigns of Alauddin Khilji: Gujarat (1299), Ranthambore (1301), Chittor (1303), Malwa (1305), Madurai (1311), Dwarasamudra (1310-1311).

questions.question: Who amongst the following Delhi Sultanate rulers sent his army under Malik Kafur’s command to conquer South India?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji. Malik Kafur - also known as 'Hazar Dinari’ was a slave of Ala-ud-din Khilji who led his army in the battle against Ramachandra of Devagiri. Administrative Reforms - implemented the system of "dagh Pratha ," branding horses, and "Huliya Pratha (a system of ranks)" keeping records of soldiers.

questions.question: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi set up the officers like Barid (intelligence officer) and Munhiyans (secret spies) to control the market?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji, ruler of the Delhi Sultanate, is known for implementing significant market reforms and establishing strict price controls and market regulations.

questions.question: Who among the following Sultans framed a series of regulations to weaken the power of nobles?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji (Khilji Dynasty 1290-1320): He made nobles pay land tax for their holdings. This curbed the excess of wealth owned by nobles. The nobles were also ordered not to have social gatherings or intermarriages without his permission. The group of nobles, called "The Forty". Q.319. Who among the following classical poets of the Sultanate period in India popularized Qawwali, a form of music which derived its name from the Arabic word ‘qaul’, meaning ‘to speak’? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening) (a) Jalal al-Din Muhammad Rumi (b) Amir Khusrau (c) Nizam al-Din Awliya (d) Shams al-Din Muhammad Hafiz Sol.319.(b) Amir Khusrau - He was also known as Tuti-e-Hind (Parrot of India). He was the court musician of Alauddin Khilji. He also lived in courts of different rulers such as Balban, Muhammad, Cakubad, Jalaluddin Khilji, Mubarak Shah Khaliji, and Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq . He was also a disciple of Nizammuddin Auliya.

questions.question: Which of the following Sultans of Delhi was appointed as Amir-i-Tuzuk (Master of Ceremonies) before becoming the Sultan?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji (1296 - 1316). He was the second ruler of Khilji dynasty after Jalaluddin Khilji (Founder - ‘Khalji Dynasty’). He was also appointed Arizi-i-Mumalik (Minister of War) during the reign of Jalaluddin Khilji and laid the foundation of his capital Siri in 1303 A.D.

questions.question: Who was the first to mention the incident of Jauhar in Persian ?
questions.explanation: Amir Khusrau. ‘Jauhar’ - The collective self-immolation by women in order to escape capture and forced into slavery by invaders in face of imminent defeat.

questions.question: During Alauddin Khilji's reign, the cloth market was known as______.
questions.explanation: Sarai-i-Adl (Place of justice). Alauddin Khilji, under his market policy, built three markets of foodgrain, precious clothes and slave cattle near Kushke Sabz (Hara Rajmahal) within the Badaun gate in Delhi. These were government - aided markets.

questions.question: Who was the first Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate to start military expeditions into southern India?
questions.explanation: Alauddin Khalji (1296-1316):- He was the second ruler of the Khilji dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

questions.question: Which monument of Khilji dynasty in Delhi has the utilization of red sandstone?
questions.explanation: Alai Darwaza. Built by Allaudin Khilji the Sultan of Delhi in 1311 AD. Moti Masjid - Aurangzeb (Delhi). Victoria memorial - George V (Kolkata). Charminar - Mohammed Quli Qutub Shah (Hyderabad).

questions.question: The Begumpuri mosque was built during the reign of which of the following rulers of the Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Muhammad Tuglaq . He was the eighteenth Sultan of Delhi, ruling from February 1324 to 1351. The eldest son of Ghiyath al-Din Tughluq, founder of the Tughlaq dynasty, he built the Begumpur Mosque (Jam'i Masjid of Jahanpanah) in the capital, Jahanpanah.

questions.question: Who among the following was the first sultan of Delhi Sultanate to visit the Ajmer shrine of Khwaja Muinuddin Chishti?
questions.explanation: Muhammad bin Tughlaq, originally known as Junakhan, ascended the throne in 1324. He is remembered for his efforts to maintain the administrative and political unity of India. In 1327 A.D., he successfully captured Warangal, a significant event in his reign. Q.329. To promote agriculture, Muhammad Tughlaq founded which of the following new ministries? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Diwan-i-Arz (b) Diwan-i Amir-i kohi (c) Diwan-i-Insha (d) Diwan-i-Risalat Sol.329.(b) Diwan-i Amir-i kohi. The Diwan-i-Kohi aimed to increase land under cultivation. Muhammad Tughlaq also promoted agriculture by abolishing or reducing agrarian cesses and introducing agricultural loans called Sondhar. Q.330. Which amongst the following Sultans shifted his capital from Delhi to Daulatabad? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (4th shift) (a) Feroz Shah Tughlaq (b) Ibrahim Lodhi (c) Sikandar Lodhi (d) Muhammad Bin Tughlaq Sol.330.(d) Muhammad Bin Tughlaq: He shifted his capital from Delhi to the more centrally located Devagiri in Maharashtra, which was renamed Daulatabad. His Five Disastrous Projects are: Taxation in the Doab, Transfer of Capital, Khurasan Expedition, Qarachil Expedition, Introduction of Token Currency.

questions.question: Who invaded India during the rule of Tughlaq Dynasty?
questions.explanation: Timur. During the reign of Nasir-ud-din Mahmud Tughlaq, Timur invaded India in 1398 A.D., leading to the decline of the Tughlaq dynasty.

questions.question: Which of the following cities of Delhi was founded by Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq ?
questions.explanation: Tughluqabad. Ghiyasuddin Tuglaq (reign period : 1320-1324) - Founder of Tughlaq dynasty (1320-1414 AD). Tughalq was the longest-ruling dynasty of Delhi sultanate. City and founder: Siri - Alauddin khilji; Jahanpanah - Muhammad bin Tughlaq; Qila-i-Rai Pithora - Prithviraj Chauhan.

questions.question: Who among the following was the successor of Muhammad-Bin Tughlaq to the throne?
questions.explanation: Firuz Shah Tughlaq (1351 - 1388). He was known as the father of the irrigation approach in India. Diwan -e-Khairat which was built for collecting money for charitable work. Q.334. Who amongst the following raised the banner of revolt against Nasiruddin Khusrau? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (4th shift) (a) Nasiruddin Tughlaq (b) Muhammad bin Tughlaq (c) Feroz Shah Tughlaq (d) Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq Sol.334.(d) Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq or Ghazi malik (1320-1324 AD) - He was the governor of Punjab during the reign of Allauddin khilji. He was the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty who fought against Mongols, and started Tughlaqabad Fort construction. Q.335. Who among the following appointed Aziz Khummar a wine distiller to high administrative post? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (3rd Shift) (a) Alauddin Khalji (b) Muhammad Tughluq (c) Jalaluddin Khalji (d) Firuz Shah Tughluq Sol.335.(b) Muhammad bin Tughluq (1324 -1351) - He was the eldest son of Ghiyasuddin Tughluq (founder of the Tughlaq dynasty). He appointed Firuz Hajjam - A barber, Mank a Tabbakh - a cook, and two gardeners - Ladha and Pira, to high administrative posts. He also decided to transfer his capital from Delhi to Devagiri (Daulatabad). Q.336. Ziyauddin Barani wrote his chronicle first in and another version _____ years later. SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (3rd Shift) (a) three (b) eight (c) two (d) five Sol.336.(c) Two. Ziauddin Barani (1285–1358 AD) was a prominent Muslim political thinker of the Delhi Sultanate during the reigns of Muhammad bin Tughlaq and Firoz Shah. Other Books: Tarikh-i-Firoz Shahi and Fatwa-i-Jahandari, Sana-i- Muhammadi, Tarikh-i-Barmaki, etc.

questions.question: The author of Tarikh-i-Mubarak Shahi, Yahya Sirhindi claims that the founder of ________ dynasty of Delhi sultanate was a descendant of Prophet Muhammad.
questions.explanation: Sayyid. Khizr Khan defeated Sultan Daulat Khan and occupied Delhi, and founded the Sayyid dynasty in 1414. Capital : Delhi. Tarikh-i-Mubarak Shahi contains the history of Muhammad Ghori and his rulers up to the third ruler of the Sayyid dynasty.

questions.question: Who was the first ruler of the Sayyid Dynasty?
questions.explanation: Khizr Khan (In 1414 A.D) - He captured the Delhi sultanate from the Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Shah Tughluq (Tughlaq dynasty) and founded the Sayyid Dynasty. He was succeeded by Mubarak Shah (first Sultan ruler to appoint Hindu nobles in the court of Delhi) and constructed “Mubarakbad” City.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate finally annexed Jaunpur into the empire of Delhi Sultanate?
questions.explanation: Lodi dynasty was founded by Bahlol Lodi, the last ruling dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate, ruling from 1451 to 1526. In AD 1476, Bahlol Lodi defeated the Sultan of Jaunpur and annexed it to the Delhi Sultanate. He also brought the ruler of Kalpi and Dholpur under the Suzerainty of Delhi.

questions.question: Who among the following was the last sultan of Delhi sultanate?
questions.explanation: Ibrahim Lodi was the last Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate (1206–1526), he became Sultan in 1517 after the death of his father Sikandar Khan Lodi. In 1526, he was defeated and killed in the Battle of Panipat by Babur, giving way to the emergence of the Mughal Empire in India.

questions.question: Which of the following dynasties of Delhi Sultanate founded Agra city?
questions.explanation: Lodi dynasty (1451 - 1526). It was founded by Bahlul Lodi (1451 to 1489 AD). Sultan Sikandar Lodi founded Agra in 1504. Famous Historic City and their Founder: Fatehpur Sikri (Uttar Pradesh) - Akbar, Hampi (Karnataka) - Harihara I and Bukka Raya I, Udaipur (Rajasthan) - Udai Singh II, Warangal (Telangana) - Kakatiya dynasty. Q.342. Which of the following mosques/masjids was built during the reign of Lodi dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Evening) (a) Begumpuri mosque, Delhi (b) Quwwat al-Islam, Delhi (c) Lal Masjid, Delhi (d) Moth ki Masjid, Delhi Sol.342.(d) Moth ki Masjid, Delhi. It was built in 1505 by Wazir Miya Bhoiya. Begumpuri mosque (Delhi) - It was constructed by Muhammad Tughluq . Q.343. “Double Dome” feature of Indo-Islamic architecture was introduced by which dynasty of Delhi Sultanate? SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Morning) (a) Slave Dynasty (b) Khilji Dynasty (c) Tughlaq Dynasty (d) Lodi Dynasty Sol.343.(d) Lodi Dynasty (1451-1526). Double dome - Built of two layers. There is one layer inside which provides a ceiling to the interior of the building. The other layer is the outer one which crowns the buildings. Example - Humayun's Tomb.

questions.question: Bahlol Lodi was succeeded by his son __________under the title of Sultan Sikandar Shah in 1489
questions.explanation: Nizam Khan {assumed the title Sikandar Shah,founded Agra in 1504, relocated the capital from Delhi to Agra, pen name Gulrukh}.

questions.question: The _____ sultanate is ruled by the Sharqi dynasty.
questions.explanation: The Jaunpur sultanate was ruled by the sharqi dynasty. It was founded by Khwajah-i-Jahan Malik Sarwar in 1394. In 1479, Sultan Hussain Khan was defeated by the forces of Afghan chieftain Bahlul Lodhi and this dynasty came to an end. Mughal Period Q.346. Consider the following statements in the context of the Mughal Rule. 1. The Mansabdari System was introduced by Akbar in 1571. 2. The Second Battle of Panipat was fought in 1556. 3. Maharana Pratap Singh of Mewar was a contemporary of Babur. Which of the statements given above is/are correct? SSC MTS 28/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Only 2 (b) Both 1 and 2 (c) Both 2 and 3 (d) 1, 2 and 3 Sol.346.(b) Both 1 and 2. Maharana Pratap Singh was a contemporary of the third Mughal emperor Akbar. He is notable for leading the Rajput resistance against Akbar's expansionist policies, including in the Battle of Haldighati (1576) and the Battle of Dewair (1582). The Second Battle of Panipat was fought between Akbar and Hemu. The mansabdari system was basically a grading system in order to rank the officers based on their ranks and salaries.

questions.question: Who among the following was the guru of Tansen?
questions.explanation: Swami Haridasa. The famous musician Tansen was one of the Navratnas (nine gems) in the court of Emperor Akbar, who bestowed the title 'Mian' upon him.

questions.question: Who among the following was given the charge of looking after the imperial household during the Mughal administration?
questions.explanation: Mir Saman. Mir Bahri (mir-i-bahr) - Responsible for the maintenance of the river and seaports. Mir Bakshi - Headed military department, nobility, information and intelligence agencies. Mir-e-aatish - Head of the ordinance department.

questions.question: Name the French jeweler who traveled to India at least six times during the Mughal period.
questions.explanation: Jean-Baptiste Tavernier. He came to India during the reign of Shah Jahan. Antonio Monserrate : A Spanish missionary, came during the reign of Akbar. Seydi Ali Reis : He was a Turkish traveler who visited India in the 16th century. Peter Mundy : A European philosopher and foreign traveler came to India during the reign of Shah Jahan.

questions.question: Who built the Pathar Ki Masjid in Patna, Bihar?
questions.explanation: Parwez Shah (Son of Mughal Emperor Jahangir) built “Pathar Ki Masjid” on the banks of River Ganga, Patna (Bihar) in 1621.

questions.question: On 12 August ________ the Mughal emperor appointed the East India Company as the Diwan of Bengal.
questions.explanation: On 12 August 1765, the Mughal emperor (Shah Alam II) appointed the East India Company as the Diwan of Bengal. Q.352. _______ in Gujarat was the emporium of western trade during the Mughal Period. SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Evening) (a) Navasari (b) Narmada (c) Porbandar (d) Surat Sol.352.(d) Surat. It grew famous for all types of textiles, particularly cotton textiles.

questions.question: The Mughal court chronicles are written in _____
questions.explanation: Persian. Mughal chronicles such as the Akbar Nama were written in Persian. Some of the famous Books during Mughal Reign are Humayun Nama was written by Gulbadan Begum, Tuzuk - E Babari - Babur, Akbar Nama- Abul Fazl, Tarikh E Akbari - Abul Fazl, Tahakik E Hind- Albiruni, Laila Majnu- Amir Khasuru, Shahnamah- Firdousi etc Q.354. With reference to the Land Revenue System of Mughal Empire, the term ' was the amount assessed. SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning) (a) Banjar (b) Polaj (c) Hasil (d) Jama Sol.354.(d) Jama. The arrangements for collection of land revenue consisted of two stages : first assessment and then actual collection. The Jama was the amount assessed whereas the Hasil was the amount received or collected. Banjar was the worst kind of land that was left out of cultivation for five years or upwards.

questions.question: Which Mughal prince translated the Upanishads into Persian in 1657?
questions.explanation: Dara Shikoh. He was the eldest son and heir-apparent of the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan. He completed the translation of fifty upanishads from their original Sanskrit to Persian in 1657 so that they could be studied by muslim scholars.

questions.question: Who was the Mughal Emperor at the time of Battle of Plassey?
questions.explanation: Aziz-ud-din Alamgir II. Alamgir II (Reign - 1754-1759) was the fifteenth Mughal Emperor.

questions.question: Which of the following battles was fought between Babur and Rana Sanga in 1527?
questions.explanation: Battle of Khanwa : Babar emerged victorious against Rana Sanga. Battles of Babar - First Battle of Panipat (1526) : Babar defeated Ibrahim Lodi. Battle of Chanderi (1528): Babar won against Madiniray. Battle of Ghaghra (1529): Babar triumphed over Mahmud Lodi.

questions.question: The real name of Babur, the founder of Mughal dynasty in India was:
questions.explanation: Zahiruddin Muhammad. Real names of some Mughal emperors include: Humayun - Nasir al-Din Muhammed, Akbar - Jalal- ud-din Muhammad Akbar, Jahangir - Muhammad Salim, Aurangzeb - Muhi-ud-din-Muhammad.

questions.question: Medini Rai of Chanderi, Hasan Khan of Mewat and Mahmud Lodi joined Rana Sanga with their forces to fight against which of the following Mughal rulers?
questions.explanation: Babur. He was a descendant of Genghis Khan and Timur, founded the Mughal Empire in northern India .

questions.question: The battle of Khanwa was fought between the forces of the Babur and the Rajput forces led by:
questions.explanation: Rana Sanga.

questions.question: Who made the use of Gunpowder common in North India to defeat enemies?
questions.explanation: Babur (1526-1530): The first Mughal emperor, succeeded to the throne of Ferghana in 1494, when he was only 12 years old.

questions.question: Who was the eldest of four sons of Babur?
questions.explanation: Humayun - The second ruler of the Mughal empire. The Afghan soldier Sher Shah Suri defeated him at the war in Chausa 1539 and Kannauj in 1540. Humayun was the first person who developed a citadel in Delhi, named as “Din Panah”.

questions.question: The first battle of Panipat took place between Babur and _________.
questions.explanation: Ibrahim Lodi. The First Battle of Panipat was fought in 1526. Second Battle of Panipat (1556): Hemu Vikramaditya and Akbar . Third Battle of Panipat (1761): Marathas and Ahmad Shah Abdali.

questions.question: Who among the following Mughal Emperors had assumed the title of Padshah?
questions.explanation: Babur. He was the first Timurid ruler who, after his conquest of Kabul (1507), assumed the title of Padshah which means "king of kings" or "emperor in persian".

questions.question: After years of wandering Babur seized Kabul in_________.
The famous monument, Aram Bagh, was built by Babur. It is located in __________.
questions.explanation: Uttar Pradesh. Aram Bagh - Built by Babur in in Agra. Monuments Built by Babur: The avenue garden in Kabul, the Panipat Mosque and the Kabuli Bagh Mosque.

questions.question: Where was Babur buried for the first time in 1530 ?
questions.explanation: Agra. On December 26, 1530, Babur died at Agra. His body was first laid at Arambagh in Agra but was later taken to Kabul, where it was buried.

questions.question: Who among the following was the successor of Mughal Emperor, Babur?
questions.explanation: Humayun. Babur (Founder of Mughal emperor) was descended from Timur and Genghis Khan. Mughal emperors chronologically : Babur → Humayun → Akbar → Jahangir → Shah-Jahan →Aurangzeb etc. Q.369. As per the Timurid tradition, Humayun had to share power with his brothers. Humayun had the control of Delhi, Agra and Central India, while his brother Kamran controlled which of the following regions? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Afghanistan and Punjab (b) Deccan (c) Gujarat and Rajasthan (d) Bengal and Bihar Sol.369.(a) Afghanistan and Punjab. Kamran Mirza was the second son of Babur, the founder of the Mughal Empire. He was the brother of Humayun, who was born Nasir-ud-Din Muhammad in Kabul. Humayun was the second Emperor of the Mughal Empire, ruling over present-day Pakistan, Northern India, Afghanistan, and Bangladesh from 1530 to 1540 and again from 1555 to 1556.

questions.question: In 1539, the Battle of Chausa was fought between Humayun and ______.
questions.explanation: Sher Shah Suri (Farid Khan, 1540-1545) - Founder of the Sur Empire, constructed the Grand Trunk Road, introduced the first Rupee (silver coin, Rupia). He defeated Humayun in 1539 and 1540 in the battle of Chausa and Kannauj respectively.

questions.question: Sher khan defeated Humayun in the battle of Chausa and Kanauj and forced him to flee to________
questions.explanation: Iran. Sher Khan, an ethnic Pashtun, defeated Humayun in the battles of Chausa (1539) and battles of Bilgram/Kannauj (1540), forcing Humayun to flee to Iran. After these victories, Sher Khan crowned himself Farid al-Dīn Sher Shah and founded the Sur Dynasty.

questions.question: Which of the following cities was built by Humayun in Delhi?
questions.explanation: Dinpanah. Humayun’s Contribution to Architecture: Humayun's Tomb (UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1993) - It was built by his widow Biga Begum (Hajji Begum), Purana Quila (Delhi) - Built as a part of the new city Dinpannah.

questions.question: In which State of India is Sher Shah's Tomb located?
questions.explanation: Bihar (Sasaram). Tombs of Mughal Emperors - Gardens of Babur (Kabul, Afghanistan), Humayun's Tomb (New Delhi), Akbar's Tomb (Sikandra, Uttar Pradesh), Tomb of Jahangir (Lahore, Pakistan), The Taj Mahal (Agra), Tomb of Aurangzeb (Ahmednagar). Q.374. Who among the following medieval rulers focused his attention on the construction of sarais (shelter) for the convenience of travellers ? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (4th shift) (a) Babur (b) Sher Shah Suri (c) Akbar (d) Humayun Sol.374.(b) Sher Shah Suri (1540-1545): Administrative reforms - Introduction of Rupiya, Built Grand-Trunk Road, Staged Dak-Chowkis in Sarais. Q.375. The historical Sher-Shah Suri Marg runs between ___________. SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning) (a) Kanpur and Kanyakumari (b) Delhi and Manali (c) Delhi and Amritsar (d) Lucknow and Kolkata Sol.375.(c) Delhi and Amritsar. The Grand Trunk Road (formerly known as Uttarapath, Sarak-e-Azam and Badshahi Sarak) - Part of National Highway (12, 27, 19, 44, 3) in India.

questions.question: Humayun’s Tomb situated in Delhi is built by ______ .
questions.explanation: Biga Begum. The architect was Mirak Mirza Ghiyath.

questions.question: Mirza Kamran was the brother of which of the following Mughal emperors?
questions.explanation: Humayun and son of Babur and Gulrukh Begum. He came to India in 1538.

questions.question: Akbar’s first expedition towards Deccan was sent to Ahmednagar under the leadership of Prince Murad and _____.
questions.explanation: Abdul Rahim Khan-i-Khanan. Akbar was the third Mughal emperor, and he ruled over India from 1556 to 1605.

questions.question: Who was the revenue minister during the reign of Akbar?
questions.explanation: Todar Mal. Navratnas of Akbar : Abul Fazl - Prime Minister and History chief advisor. Faizi - Education Minister. Birbal - Foreign Minister. Raja Man Singh - Chief of Staff of Akbar’s Mughal Army. Tansen - Culture Minister and Singer. Abdul Rahim Khan-I-Khana - Defence Minister. Mullah Do Piyaza - Home Minister. Fakir Aziao-Din - Religious Minister.

questions.question: After the death of Humayun, the 13 year-old Akbar was coronated in 1556 at Kalanaur in ________.
questions.explanation: Punjab. Akbar was crowned at Kalanaur on February 14, 1556, following the sudden death of Humayun, who died after falling from the stairs of the Dinpanah library. At just 13 years old, Akbar came to power under the guidance of his guardian, Bairam Khan. He later defeated Hemu in the Second Battle of Panipat, securing control over Delhi. Q.381. Who among the following was one of the Navratnas of Akbar? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Purandar Das (b) Swami Haridas (c) Tansen (d) Amir Khusro Sol.381.(c) Tansen. Mian Tansen, originally named Ramtanu Pandey is a legendary figure in Hindustani Classical Music. He is known as the "Sangeet Samrat," or "Monarch of Hindustani Music.

questions.question: Who among the following was the Vakil under the reign of Mughal Emperor Akbar, who received the title of Khan-i-Khanan ?
questions.explanation: Bairam Khan. A prominent Mughal noble and military commander who served as Akbar's regent and chief minister during the early years of his reign. Q.383. Which amongst the following statements is correct about Mughal emperor Akbar? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift) (a) He founded a new religion called ‘Din-e Ilahi’. (b) He fought and won the third battle of Panipat against the Hindu King Hemu (c) He was declared emperor in 1602. (d) He was highly educated and knew many languages. Sol.383.(a) He founded a new religion called ‘Din-e-Ilahi’. The theory of Din-e-Ilahi means belief in one God. The first initiated disciples of Din-i-Ilahi during emperor Akbar included Birbal, Prince Salim, and Abul-Fazl ibn Mubarak. Q.384. Who amongst the following Mughal emperors got classical Hindu mythological texts Ramayana and Mahabharata translated into Persian ? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift) (a) Jahangir (b) Aurangzeb (c) Akbar (d) Shahjahan Sol.384.(c) Akbar was the 3rd Mughal emperor (1556 to 1605). The Mahabharata was translated by Faizi and `Abd al-Qadir Bada'uni and named Razmnama. Literature under the rule of Akbar: Akbarnama (Autobiography of Akbar) and Ain-i-Akbari written by Abu'l-Fazl. Q.385. Which of the following statements about Akbar are true? 1 He introduced the Mansabdari system. 2 He defeated and merged the state of Bijapur in his empire. 3 He made Fatehpur Sikri his capital. SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (1st shift) (a) All 1, 2, 3 (b) Only 1 and 3 (c) Only 2 and 3 (d) Only 1 and 2 Sol.385.(b) Only and 3. The Mansabdari system was a system of ranking government officials and military generals in the Mughal Empire, which was introduced by Emperor Akbar in 1571. Aurangzeb, the sixth Mughal emperor (1658-1707), sent his armies to conquer the Deccan Sultanates. He annexed Bijapur in 1685 and Golconda in 1687. Q.386. When Akbar introduced Mansabdari system, _______ was the lowest grade of Mansabdar. Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 4) (a) fifty (b) one hundred (c) ten (d) one thousand Sol.386.(c) Ten. The term mansabdar refers to an individual who holds a mansab, meaning a position or rank. It was a grading system used by the Mughals to fix rank, salary and military responsibilities. During Akbar's reign, the lowest rank allotted was 10, and the highest was that of 10,000.

questions.question: When was Khandesh merged into the Mughal empire by Akbar ?
questions.explanation: 1601. Khandesh was situated in the Tapti valley, Maharashtra. It was founded by Malik Raja Faruqi. Major military campaigns by Akbar - In 1568 the Sisodiya capital of Chittor was seized and in 1569 Ranthambore. Q.388. Jaimal and Patta were the warriors who were given charge of defending the fort of ______ SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (4th shift) (a) Raisen (b) Ajmer (c) Udaipur (d) Chittor Sol.388.(d) Chittor. Siege of Chittorgarh (1567 - 1568) - It was a military expedition of the Mughal Empire under Akbar against the Mewar kingdom that commenced in 1567 during which the Mughals successfully captured the fort of Chittorgarh.

questions.question: Tansen, the music legend, was a courtier in which of the following courts before coming to Akbar ?
questions.explanation: Rewa. Tansen was initially the court singer of King Ram Chand. His original name was RamaTanu Pandey. Tansen was the title given to him by Raja Vikramjit of Gwalior. Q.390. During the reign of Akbar, _________ was the land that has lain fallow for three or four years. SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Parauti (b) Polaj (c) Chachar (d) Banjar Sol.390.(c) Chachar. Parauti - The land kept out of cultivation temporarily in order to recoup its lost fertility. Polaj - The ideal and best type of land throughout the empire and it was cultivated always and was never allowed to lie fallow.

questions.question: Which of the following cities was the first planned city of the Mughals?
questions.explanation: Fatehpur Sikri. It is located near Agra in Uttar Pradesh. It was built by the Mughal Emperor Akbar in the 16th century. Fatehpur Sikri was built during and 1585. Fatehpur Sikri was declared as UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1986.

questions.question: When was the Battle of Tukaroi fought where Akbar defeated the Sultanate of Bengal and Bihar?
questions.explanation: 1575. The Battle of Tukaroi (Battle of Bajhaura/ Moghalmari) - Fought at Balasore (Odisha) in which Akbar (Mughal Emperor) defeated Daud Khan Karrani (Ruler of Bengal). The battle led to the Treaty of Katak in which Daud Khan Karrani ceded the whole of Bengal and Bihar, retaining only Odisha.

questions.question: _________ administration became the model followed by the great emperor Akbar when he consolidated the Mughal Empire.
questions.explanation: Sher Shah Suri's. Although the Suri dynasty ruled for only a short period i.e. 15 years, it introduced an administration that borrowed elements from Alauddin Khilji and made them more efficient.

questions.question: Ain-i Akbari, a document on life of Mughal ruler Akbar does not contain information about _________
questions.explanation: Ancestors. Abul Fazl (Akbar’s court historian) wrote a three-volume history of Akbar’s reign, titled Akbar Nama. The first volume (Akbar’s ancestors), second volume (events of Akbar’s reign) and The third (the Ain-i Akbari). Ain-i Akbari is divided into five volumes . Q.395. Ajmer became the suba headquarters under the ______. SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (4th Shift) (a) Pallavas (b) Cholas (c) Mughals (d) Delhi Sultanate Sol.395.(c) Mughals. Ajmer Subah - One of the original 12 subahs of Mughal Empire (1526 - 1858). It was established during Akbar's administrative reforms of 1572–1580. The last Mughal - Bahadur Shah Zafar. Q.396. In which year was Kashmir annexed to the Mughal Empire by Akbar? Graduate Level 01/08/2022 (Shift - 4) (a) 1586 (b) 1590 (c) 1592 (d) 1580 Sol.396.(a) 1586. Military Conquests of Akbar (Mughal Emperor, 1556-1605): Malwa (conquered in 1562), Gondwana region of central India (1564), Gujarat (1573), Mewar (1576), both Bihar and Bengal (1576).

questions.question: As described in ‘Ain-i-Akbari’ by Abul Fazl-i-Allami, ‘gaz’ (unit of measuring length) was divided into equal parts called ______.
questions.explanation: tassuj.

questions.question: Who among the following issued Mahzarnama in 1579 ?
questions.explanation: Akbar issued Mahzarnama in 1579. It is a declaration that gives authority to change the religious laws of Islam.

questions.question: Which Mughal emperor built the city called 'Makhsudabad' later popularly known as Murshidabad?
questions.explanation: Akbar. Murshidabad was named by Nawab Murshid Qulī Khan. Akbar (reign - 1556 - 1605) - Constructed Fatehpur Sikri (made it his capital in 1569), Started a new religion Din-i Ilahi (1582), His biography titled Akbarnama (Wrote by Abul Fazl). Q.400. In the context of Mughal administration, which of the following is the most appropriate definition of ‘Abwab’? SSC CHSL 16/04/2021 (Evening) (a) A clerk in the government treasury (b) A court jester (c) A tax levied on the lands over and above the original rent (d) A reward for good governance Sol.400.(c) A tax levied on the lands over and above the original rent in Mughal India all temporary and circumstantial taxes and impositions levied by the government over and above regular taxes were called “abwab”. Jahangir Q.401. The Sisodiya ruler of Mewar, Amar Singh, accepted Mughal service during the reign of_________. Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) Jahangir (b) Shah Jahan (c) Aurangzeb (d) Akbar Sol.401.(a) Jahangir. Amar singh was the eldest son and successor of Maharana Pratap. Akbar (1556–1605). Aurangzeb belonged to the aristocratic Timurid dynasty, and held administrative and military posts under his father Shah Jahan (1628 – 1658). Q.402. Who succeeded in securing trading concessions for the East India Company from Mughal Emperor Jahangir? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening) (a) John Mildenhall (b) Captain Hawkins (c) Captain Best (d) Thomas Roe Sol.402.(d) Thomas Roe was an English diplomat sent by the East India Company in 1615. John Mildenhall was the first British explorer to make an overland journey to India. Captain William Hawkins was an English sea captain who visited the court of Jahangir in 1608.

questions.question: Who among the following wrote the biography of Jahangir known as Iqbalnama-i Jahangiri?
questions.explanation: Mutamid Khan. He was in the court of Mughal Emperor Jahangir (4th Mughal ruler, 1605 to 1627). ‘Iqbalnama-i Jahangiri’ book was written in Persian and it covers the first 19 years of Jahangir's reign. Inayat Khan wrote” Shajahanama”. Abdul Rahim Khan translated “Babarnama” to the Persian language.

questions.question: Sarai Nurmahal is a centrally protected monument of India. It is situated in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Punjab (Jalandhar). Shalimar Bagh, the Begum Shahi Mosque, and the Bachcha Taj are the monuments built by the Jahangir (Fourth Mughal emperor). Q.405. Mehrunnisa married Emperor Jahangir in ______. SSC MTS 26/07/2022 (Morning) (a) 1620 (b) 1602 (c) 1611 (d) 1603 Sol.405.(c) In 1611, Jahangir married Mehrunnisa who was known as Nur Jahan (Light of World). She encouraged Persian art and culture in the court.

questions.question: Identify the Mughal emperor who was imprisoned for the rest of his life in Agra after the war of succession among his sons.
questions.explanation: Shah Jahan (Mirza Shahab-ud-din Baig Muhammad Khan Khurram). He was the fifth Mughal emperor and reigned from 1628 to 1658. Aurangzeb declared himself emperor in 1658 and imprisoned Shah Jahan in Agra Fort until his death in January 1666.

questions.question: Who among the following was chosen by Shahjahan as his successor to the Mughal throne?
questions.explanation: Dara Shikoh. The Battle of Deorai was fought between Aurangzeb and Dara Shikoh. It was fought in 1659. Dara Shikoh was defeated by Aurangzeb in this Battle.

questions.question: Who among the following has written the ‘Badshah Nama’?
questions.explanation: Abdul Hamid Lahori - A historian and traveler who later became a court historian of Shah Jahan. “Badshah Nama” (Padshahnama) is the official history of Shah Jahan.

questions.question: The mausoleum of the Taj Mahal was designed by ____________.
questions.explanation: Ustad Ahmad Lahori was the chief Mughal architect during the reign of Shah Jahan. He was responsible for the construction of the Taj Mahal in Agra and the Red fort in Delhi. Q.410. The art of decoration, called Pietra dura became popular during whose reign? SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (4th shift) (a) Jahangir (b) Sher Shah Suri (c) Shah Jahan (d) Akbar Sol.410.(c) Shah Jahan. Pietra dura - An inlay technique using cut and fitted, highly polished colored stones to create images. Some other buildings and monuments by Shah Jahan:- Red Fort (Delhi), Jama Masjid (Delhi), Shish Mahal (Agra) and Shalimar Bagh (Lahore).

questions.question: Ahmadnagar was finally annexed by the Mughals in_______
questions.explanation: In 1632, during the period of Shah Jahan, Ahmednagar was merged into the Mughal empire. Malik Ahmed was the founder of Ahmednagar (Maharashtra), who established the Nizam Shahi dynasty.

questions.question: Who among the following had been given the title of ‘Sultan Buland Iqbal’ by Shah Jahan?
questions.explanation: Dara Shikoh (Eldest Son of Shah Jahan). Sultan Buland Iqbal (Prince of High Fortune) - Title given on 10 September 1642. His works - Majma -ul-Bahrain (Mingling of Two Oceans), Sirr-i-Akbar (Great Mystery). He was executed in 1659 by Aurangzeb in the war of succession. Aurangzeb Q.413. Which Mughal ruler was responsible for the execution of Guru Tegh Bahadur in the year 1675 ? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (1st shift) (a) Jahangir (b) Akbar (c) Aurangzeb (d) Shahjahan Sol.413.(c) Aurangzeb. Guru Tegh Bahadur was the ninth Sikh Guru, often venerated as the ‘Protector of Humanity’ (Srisht-di-Chadar) by the Sikhs. He founded Anandpur Sahib.

questions.question: Under whose rule did the Mughal empire achieve its largest territorial limits?
questions.explanation: Aurangzeb (1658 - 1707) ascended the throne in after eliminating all competitors, including Dara Shukoh, Shuja, and Murad, in a war of succession.

questions.question: Which Mughal rulers intervention in the succession and internal politics of the Rathor Rajputs of Marwar led to their rebellion?
questions.explanation: Aurangzeb (1658-1707). His Military Campaigns : In the north-east, the Ahoms were defeated in 1663, but rebelled again in the 1680s. Campaigns in the north-west against the Yusufzai and the Sikhs were temporarily successful.

questions.question: Under which of the following Mughal emperors were the Marathas a major challenge to the sovereignty of the Mughals?
questions.explanation: Aurangzeb (Reign : 1658-1707) - He was the sixth Mughal Emperor and also known as Zinda Pir (living saint), Fakir, and Darbesh. He gave the French permission to build a factory in Surat in 1667. Q.417. Under whose reign was the maximum number of books in Persian on classical Indian Music written? SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (2nd shift) (a) Shah Jahan (b) Jahangir (c) Akbar (d) Aurangzeb Sol.417.(d) Aurangzeb (1658 - 1707). He reimposed Jizya and Pilgrim tax in 1679 and ended the celebration of Navroz. Q.418. Which Mughal Emperor has attempted to vandalise the Kailash Temple at Ellora? SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Evening) (a) Aurangzeb (b) Humayun (c) Shah Jahan (d) Babur Sol.418.(a) Aurangzeb {Alamgir, original name MuḥI al-Din Muḥammad (1658 to 1707)} - He stopped music and alcohol in the court and also the activities of ‘jharokha’ (public audience). Sikh Guru Q.419. Gurpurab is celebrated to commemorate the birthday of Guru Nanak dev ji. He was the _________ guru of Sikhs? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift) (a) second (b) first (c) fourth (d) third Sol.419.(b) First. Guru Nanak Dev, the founder of Sikhism, was born on April 15, 1469, in Talwandi, now known as Nankana Sahib, Pakistan.

questions.question: After the death of Shri Guru Gobind Singh, the Sikhs revolted against the ______ under the leadership of Banda Bahadur.
questions.explanation: Mughals. Guru Gobind Singh is famous for his creation of the Khalsa History (Pure) , the military brotherhood of the Sikhs.

questions.question: Who among the following Sikh spiritual gurus is said to have assisted Khusrau, the rebellious son of Jahangir?
questions.explanation: Guru Arjan Dev assisted Khusrau, the rebellious son of Jahangir. He compiled the first official edition of the Sikh scripture called the Adi Granth, which later expanded into the Guru Granth Sahib. He completed the construction of the Golden Temple in Amritsar.

questions.question: Who among the following Sikh Gurus laid the foundation of ‘Khalsa Panth’ ?
questions.explanation: Guru Gobind Singh laid the foundation of ‘Khalsa Panth’ on April 13, 1699, situated in Punjab. It is a name given to the religious structure and the community that manages the affairs of the global Khalsa community.

questions.question: Twenty five percent of the land revenue collected by Marathas in the Deccan was __________ .
questions.explanation: Chauth - It was paid to the Marathas in order to avoid the Maratha raids. It was levied on the lands which were under the nominal Mughal rule. Sardeshmukhi was an additional ten percent levy on lands on which the Marathas claimed hereditary rights. Bhoga (Gupta period) refers to the tax on gifts, flowers, wood, fruits, etc. Bhaga (Mauryan period) - Tax on agricultural land levied at the rate of 1/6th.

questions.question: Baji Rao I or Baji Rao Ballal was the son of ________.
questions.explanation: Peshwa Balaji Vishwanath (1713- 1720). He was the first of a line of hereditary Peshwas from the Bhat family. Baji Rao I (1720-40) - Succeeded Balaji Vishwanath. He was the Seventh Peshwa (Prime Minister) of the Maratha Empire and one of the greatest exponents of Guerrilla tactics after Shivaji. Maratha families: Shindes (Gwalior), Holkars (Indore), Gaikwads (Baroda), Bhosles (Nagpur), Peshwas (Poona).

questions.question: Who among the following was a famous ruler of the Maratha dynasty?
questions.explanation: Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. The Maratha Empire formerly existed from with the coronation of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and ended in 1818 with the defeat of Peshwa Bajirao II at the hands of the British East India Company. Wars fought by Shivaji - Battle of Pratapgad (1659), Battle of Purandar (1665), Battle of Sinhagad (1670), Battle of Sangamner(1679), etc. Vijaynagar Empire Q.426. The founders of Vijayanagar empire, Harihara and Bukka Raya were the ministers of: SSC MTS 18/10/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Kampili (b) Kadamba (c) Western Chalukya (d) Eastern Ganga Sol.426.(a) Kampili. The Vijayanagara Empire was established in 1336 by the brothers Harihara and Bukka Raya of the Sangama dynasty, who belonged to the Yadava clan of the Chandravamsa lineage. Between and 1565, Vijayanagara was ruled by three different dynasties: the Sangama, Saluva, and Tuluva dynasties. The last dynasty was the Aravidu dynasty, which ruled until the seventeenth century. Q.427. Who among the following Portuguese travellers visited the Vijayanagar empire during the reign of Krishnadevaraya ? SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Domingo Paes (b) Nicolo de Conti (c) Ludovico de Varthema (d) Athanasius Nikitin Sol.427.(a) Domingo Paes. Foreign Travellers in India: Megasthenes, Greece (Chandragupta Maurya); Deimachus, Greece (Bindusara); Fa-Hien, China (Chandragupta II); Niccolò de' Conti, Italy (Devaraya I); Fernao Nuniz (Achyuta Deve Raya).

questions.question: Which of the following was the last dynasty of the Vijayanagara Empire?
questions.explanation: Aravidu dynasty. The Vijayanagara Empire had four dynasties: Sangama dynasty (1336-1485 CE), Saluva dynasty (1485-1505 CE), Tuluva dynasty (1505-1570 CE), Aravidu dynasty (1570-1646 CE).

questions.question: Which of the following kings of Vijayanagara took the title of ‘establisher of the Yavana kingdom’?
questions.explanation: Krishna Deva Raya : He founded a suburban township near Vijayanagar called Nagalapuram after his Mother. He wrote the epic Telugu poem Amuktamalyada.

questions.question: The Vijayanagara empire included people from different cultural regions. Which of the following regions was NOT a part of it?
questions.explanation: Maratha. The Vijayanagara Empire primarily included the regions of Tamil, Karnataka, and Telugu-speaking areas. Maratha region was ruled by the Yadava Dynasty and later the Bahmani Sultanate during Vijayanagara's peak.

questions.question: What was the dominant source of income in the Vijaynagar Empire?
questions.explanation: Land revenue. Vijayanagar empire: Sources of income - Land Revenue, tributes, and gifts from vassals and feudal chiefs, customs at ports. Q.432. Who among the following Vijaynagar rulers married his daughter to Firuz Shah Bahmani? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (1st shift) (a) Deva Raya II (b) Deva Raya I (c) Krishna Deva Raya (d) Bukka I Sol.432.(b) Dev Raya I. In 1406 -07, Firuz Shah the ruler of the Bahmani Sultanate, defeated Deva Raya-I, the ruler of the Vijayanagara Empire. Dynasty and Ruler: Sangama Dynasty - Harihara I and Bukka ; Saluva dynasty - Narasimha Deva Raya, History Thimma Bhupala, Narasimha Raya II. Tuluva dynasty- Krishnadeva Raya.

questions.question: The founders of Vijayanagara Empire were the feudatories of which of the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: Kakatiya.

questions.question: The origin of 'Carnatic music' is related to which of the following Dynasties ?
questions.explanation: Vijayanagar. Carnatic Music: Purandara Dasa - A poet-composer of Vijayanagar is the ‘Father of Carnatic Music’. Q.435. Vijayanagara emperor Krishnadeva Raya founded a suburban township near Vijayanagara called Nagalapuram after his __________. SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (4th shift) (a) father (b) teacher (c) sister (d) mother Sol.435.(d) Mother. Q.436. The local communities of merchants were known as _________ in the Vijayanagara empire. SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (3rd shift) (a) Rachavarus (b) Narapattis (c) Kudirai Chettis (d) Gajapattis Sol.436.(c) Kudirai Chettis (Horse merchants). Rachavarus (Rajulu) - Associated with the ruling dynasty (rulers and generals were actually Sudras). Narapati (Rayas) - Lord of Men. Gajapati - lord of elephants.

questions.question: The 'Pattanulkars' migrated from the Gujarat region to the Vijayanagar state. They Were ___________ .
questions.explanation: silk weavers. Important terms related to Medieval history:- Bargir - Cavalrymen, Din - Religion, Gomashta - Commercial agent, Shiqdar - Head of Administrative unit (Shiqq), Subhas - Provinces, Zawabit - Secular law. Q.438. The Amara-Nayakas were in the Vijayanagara Empire. SSC CGL 25/07/2023( 1st shift) (a) forced laborers (b) finance officers (c) ordinary peasants (d) military commanders Sol.438.(d) Military commanders. They were given territories to govern by the Raya and used to collect taxes and other dues from the peasants, traders and craftspersons of the area. Gramas (villages), Gauda (village headman), Sthalas (sub districts), Nadus (districts), {Mandalams or rajyas (provinces)}, Land tax (sist).

questions.question: While historians use the term Vijayanagara Empire and contemporaries of this empire described it as the _______.
questions.explanation: Karnataka Samrajyamu. Vijayanagara Empire (1336 -1646) - Established by Harihara and Bukka on the banks of river Tungabhadra.

questions.question: Raichur doab, the land between Krishna and Tungabhadra was a reason of conflict between the kings of Vijayanagar and _________
questions.explanation: Bahamani . The Bahmani -Vijayanagar conflict started during the period of HariHara Raya I. Both kingdoms wanted to control the fertile and rich Raichur doab lying between rivers Krishna and Tungabhadra. Q.441. Which battle led to the destruction of the Vijayanagara empire? SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Evening) (a) Battle of Raichur (b) Battle of Haldighati (c) Battle of Talikota (d) Battle of Arcot Sol.441.(c) Battle of Talikota (Rakshasi–Tangadi) - It was fought on 23 January 1565 between the Vijayanagara Empire and an alliance of the Deccan sultanates. Aliya Rama Raya (King of the Vijaynagar Empire) was defeated and killed in the battle, which eventually led to the political collapse of the Vijayanagara Empire. The Battle of Raichur - Fought between the Vijayanagara Empire and the Sultanate of Bijapur in 1520. Q.442. Provida style of architecture belongs to which empire? SSC MTS 13/06/2023 (Evening) (a) Vijayanagar Empire (b) Gupta Empire (c) Mauryan Empire (d) Bahmani Empire Sol.442.(a) Vijayanagar Empire Architectural Wonders of Vijayanagara: Queen’s Bath, Lotus Mahal, Elephant stables, Royal platform, Water tanks.

questions.question: The Anantraj Sagar Tank was built by the __________rulers.
questions.explanation: The Vijayanagara empire built the Anantraj Sagar water storage tank using a 1.37 km long dam on the Maldevi river. Maldevi river runs through the Nellore district in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh and empties into the Pennar river.

questions.question: Which Peshwa signed the treaty of Bassein with the East India Company?
questions.explanation: Baji Rao II. The Treaty of Bassein (1802): It was signed between Lord Wellesley and Baji Rao II. Other Treaty: Treaty of Surat (1775) was signed between Raghunath Rao and the British. The Treaty of Salbai (1782) was signed between the Maratha Empire and the British East India Company.

questions.question: Which king of Punjab signed a tripartite treaty with Shah Shujah and the English Company ?
questions.explanation: Ranjit Singh. The Tripartite Treaty was signed by Shah Shujah, Ranjit Singh and Lord Auckland (Governor -General of India) in 1838.

questions.question: In 1850, Kashmir was sold under which of the following treaties to the Dogra dynasty of Jammu ?
questions.explanation: Treaty of Amritsar - It was executed by the British East India Company and Raja Gulab Singh of Jammu after the First Anglo-Sikh War. Treaty of Allahabad : Signed in - 1765 between the Mughal emperor Shah Alam II and Lord Clive of the British East India Company. Treaty of Sugauli - signed between Nepal and the East India History Company in 1815 and ratified by 4 March 1816. Treaty of Purandar – Signed between Jai Singh I and Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in 1665.

questions.question: French possessions in India were restored after the Battle of Wandiwash by the Treaty of __________ signed in the year 1763 between Britain and France.
questions.explanation: Paris. The Battle of Wandiwash was fought in Vandavasi, Tamil Nadu between the French and the British in 1760. This battle was part of the Third Carnatic War. The British defeated the French.

questions.question: The seven years of war in the 18th century was fought between Britain and ________.
questions.explanation: France. The Seven Years’ War, which took place between 1756-1763, was a global conflict that spanned five continents, though it was known in America as the ‘French and Indian War’. It solidified Britain’s stance as the most dominant European country in the world. Reason behind the Seven Years War - Both England and France wanted territories in North America.

questions.question: Who was the Iranian ruler who attacked the city of Delhi and took away an immense amount of wealth in 1739 ?
questions.explanation: Nadir Shah. Battle of Karnal (1739) : Fought between - Nadir Shah and Muhammad Shah. Victory - Nadir Shah easily outnumbered the Mughal forces and the Mughal emperor surrendered. Nadir Shah took the famous Kohinoor diamond from India and Shah Jahan's jewel studded peacock from the throne.

questions.question: Which of the following was the first major and decisive victory for the East India Company on the soil of India?
questions.explanation: Battle of Plassey (1757). This battle was fought between the British East India Company led by Robert Clive and the Nawab of Bengal Siraj-ud-daula and his French allies. The Battle of Sindhuli was part of the unification of Nepal led by Prithvi Narayan Shah, King of Gorkha (later King of Nepal). Battle of Tiruvannamalai (1767) - Fought between the forces of the East India Company and the Kingdom of Mysore, led by Hyder Ali. Q.451. Which of the following Anglo-Maratha wars resulted in merging the Peshwas' territories with the Bombay Presidency? SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift) (a) Fourth (b) Third (c) Second (d) First Sol.451.(b) Third (1817-1819). Anglo -Maratha war (The Great Maratha War) - The War was fought over territorial disputes, political dominance, and control over resources. First (1775-1782) - The Marathas won, Second (1803-1805) - The British won.

questions.question: Mir Qasim name is associated with which of the following battles of India?
questions.explanation: Battle of Buxar (1764) : It was fought between the forces of the British East India Company (led by Hector Munro) and the combined army of an alliance of Shuja-ud-Daulah, Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II and Mir Qasim. The Treaty of Allahabad (1765) was signed after this Battle.

questions.question: The second Anglo-Mysore War came to an end by signing which of the following treaties?
questions.explanation: The Treaty of Mangalore (1784). The second Anglo-Mysore War (1780 - 84) was fought by Hyder Ali, the Nizam and the Marathas against the British. Anglo-Mysore Wars : First (1767 - 69) - Between Hyder Ali and the British, concluded with the Treaty of Madras.Third (1790 - 92) - The British, the Nizam and the Marathas fought together against Tipu Sultan, concluded with the Treaty of Seringapatam. Fourth (1798 - 99) - Between Arthur Wellesley and Tipu Sultan (Died).

questions.question: The Battle of Karnal is known for the invasion of which of the following aggressors against India?
questions.explanation: Nadir Shah. The Battle of Karnal - Fought between Nadir Shah (Persian Empire of the Afsharid dynasty) and Muhammad Shah (Mughal Emperor) in 1739. Nadir Shah emerged victorious in the battle. He took the famous Koh - i - Noor diamond and Shah Jahan's jewel-studded Peacock Throne. He was the founder of the Afsharid dynasty of Iran.

questions.question: Who was the Mughal emperor during the third battle of Panipat?
questions.explanation: Shahalam II (Ali Gauhar) - Son of Alamgir II. Third Battle of Panipat (14 January, 1761): Between Maratha Empires and Ahmad Shah Abdali. (Victory - Ahmad Shah Abdali).

questions.question: The Battle of Khatoli fought was in 1517 between the kingdom of Mewar under Rana Sanga and ______.
questions.explanation: Ibrahim Lodhi. The Lodi dynasty (1451 - 1526, an Afghan dynasty was the fifth and final dynasty of the Delhi Sultanate.

questions.question: In which of these battles the involvement of the Mughal army was not there?
questions.explanation: Battle of Aliwal (1846) - British (led by Sir Harry Smith) defeated Sikh forces (led by Ranjodh Singh Majithia).

questions.question: Which of the given statements is correct? I. When Alivardi Khan died in 1756, Siraj-ud-daulah became the nawab of Bengal. II. In 1757, Robert Clive led the company’s army against Siraj-ud-daulah at Plassey.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Battle of Plassey (23 June 1757) - Bengal (led by Siraj ud-Daulah - last independent Nawab of Bengal) annexed by the British East India Company (led by Robert Clive - First British Governor of the Bengal Presidency).

questions.question: In which year did Tipu Sultan die defending his capital Seringapatam?
questions.explanation: 1799. He is known as Tiger of Mysore. Tipu Sultan was inspired by the Ideals of the French Revolution. Daria Daulat Bagh is known as Tipu Sultan’s Summer Palace. He was finally defeated at the hands of Lord Wellesley.

questions.question: Who emerged victorious in ‘The Siege of Arcot’ in 1751 AD ?
questions.explanation: British. The Siege of Arcot was the battle between British and combined forces of French and Nawab of Arcot. Robert Clive captured the Arcot after the battle. The war ended with the Treaty of Pondicherry in 1754 which made Mohammad Ali Khan Walajah as Nawab of Arcot.

questions.question: In which year was the Treaty of Versailles signed?
questions.explanation: 1919. The defeated Germany after the First World War signed the Treaty of Versailles on 28 June 1919.

questions.question: Which of the following regions was annexed by the British East India Company through the Treaty of Yandabo (1826) ?
questions.explanation: Assam. Treaty of Yandabo was the peace treaty that resulted at the end of the First Anglo Burmese War. It was signed between the British and Burmese. Q.463. In 1818, the Holkar Dynasty signed the Treaty of Mandsaur with the ______. SSC MTS 27/10/2021 (Evening) (a) Danish (b) Dutch (c) British (d) French Sol.463.(c) British. After Malhar Rao II was defeated in the battle of Mahidpur (1817) the treaty of Mandsaur was signed.

questions.question: Which of the following battles did Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah fight, defeating the forces under Henry Lawrence?
questions.explanation: Battle of Chinhat. In the Battle of Chinhat, Barkat Ahmad was declared Chief Army Officer of the rebels. The Battle of Chinhat was fought on the morning of June 1857, between British forces and Indian rebels.

questions.question: In the Battle of Swally (1612) the British fought against the ______.
questions.explanation: Portuguese. The battle took place on 29–30 November 1612 off the coast of Suvali, a village near Surat city. This relatively small naval battle is historically important as it marked the beginning of the end of Portugal’s commercial monopoly over India and the beginning of the ascent of the English East India Company’s presence in India.

questions.question: The Battle of Bedara was fought between the British Army and the Dutch Army in:
questions.explanation: 25 November 1759, during the Seven Years' War between a force of British troops mainly of the British East India Company and a force of the Dutch East India Company.

questions.question: The British annexed Punjab after defeating the Sikhs in the Anglo-Sikh War in the year ______.
questions.explanation: 1849. This war resulted in the fall of the Sikh Empire and The East India Company annexed Punjab and it became part of North West Frontier Province.

questions.question: Who signed the treaty of Alinagar with the British?
questions.explanation: Siraj-ud-Daula . The Treaty of Alinagar was signed on 9 February 1757 between Robert Clive of the British East India Company and the Nawab of Bengal, Mirza Muhammad Siraj Ud Daula. Based on the terms of the accord, the Nawab would recognize all the provisions of Mughal Emperor Farrukhsiyar farman of 1717.

questions.question: In which year did the government of British India pass a law according to which those who converted into Christianity got the right in their ancestral property?
questions.explanation: 1850. The Lex Loci Act of 1850 was an Indian law that allowed people who converted to a different faith to inherit their ancestral property. The Caste Disabilities Removal Act, 1850, was a law passed in British India under East India Company rule, that abolished all laws affecting the rights of people converting to another religion or caste. The new Act allowed hindus who converted from Hindu religion to another religion equal rights under new law, especially in the case of inheritance.

questions.question: What was the term of the Central Legislative Assembly under the Government of India Act of 1919?
questions.explanation: Three year. The elections to the two Houses of the Indian Legislature were held under the Government of India Act, 1919, and the new Legislative Assembly was inaugurated on 9 February 1921. The First and the Second Assemblies were dissolved within their life term of three years. The life of the Third, Fourth and the Fifth Assemblies were extended beyond their normal terms. The Fifth Assembly had the longest inning of ten years. The Sixth Assembly 1946-1947 was, in fact, not dissolved but automatically ceased to exist on 14 August 1947 under section 8 of the Indian Independence Act, 1947. Q.580. Which of the following Acts provided for a system of tribunals and a ban on strikes? SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (1st Shift) (a) The Trade Disputes Act, 1929 (b) Government of India Act, 1912 (c) Age of Consent Act, 1891 (d) Indian Partnership Act, 1932 Sol.580.(a) The Trade Disputes Act, 1929 was a law that aimed to resolve industrial disputes by establishing tribunals to investigate and settle them. Government of India Act, 1912 related to the appointment of a separate Governor of Bengal Province. The Age of Consent Act, raised the age for the consummation of marriage for women to 12 years. Indian Partnership Act, 1932 define and amend the Law Relating to Partnership.

questions.question: Under which of the following Acts was the power to rule India, transferred from the English East India Company to the British Crown?
questions.explanation: Government of India Act 1858 had the following key provisions : The English East India Company was abolished, and India came directly under British Crown rule. A new position, the Secretary of State for India, was created in the British government to manage Indian affairs. A 15-member council was established to assist the Secretary of State.

questions.question: With reference to Morley-Minto Reforms of 1909, consider the following statements. a) They are also called the Indian Councils Act, 1909. b) They increased the strength of Legislative Councils. c) The right to separate electorate was given to the Muslims. Which of the above statements is/are correct ?
questions.explanation: a, b, c. The Indian Councils Act of 1909 was introduced by the British government in India as a step toward including Indians in governance. Named after Viceroy Lord Minto and Secretary of State John Morley, the Act considerably increased the size of the legislative councils, both at the Central and provincial levels. The number of members in the Central Legislative Council was raised from 16 to 60. The act declared Delhi as the capital of British India in place of Calcutta. Q.583. Wood’s Dispatch of primarily dealt with which of the following subject matters? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Education (b) Railways (c) Finance (d) Health Sol.583.(a) Education. The Wood's Despatch of 1854 was a formal letter sent by Sir Charles Wood to Lord Dalhousie, the Governor-General of India, that outlined a plan for educational reform in India. It recommended that primary schools use vernacular languages, secondary schools use both English and vernacular languages, and colleges use English. It is often referred to as the “Magna Carta of English Education in India.”

questions.question: Under which of the following Acts, the Board of Control was established in England to control and supervise the administration of British India?
questions.explanation: Pitt’s India Act of 1784. It was introduced during the tenure of Lord Warren Hastings against the backdrop of growing concerns about the East India Company's mismanagement and corruption in India. Provisions: It gave the History British government control over the East India Company. The Act was also called ‘half-loaf system. Q.585. Which of the following Acts introduced ‘provincial autonomy’ by discontinuing the application of dyarchy? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Government of India Act, 1919 (b) Charter Act of 1813 (c) India Council Act, 1909 (d) Government of India Act, 1935 Sol.585.(d) Government of India Act, 1935. The Act introduced responsible government in provinces, meaning the governor was required to act on the advice of ministers responsible to the provincial legislature. Government of India Act, 1919: Introduced dyarchy. Charter Act of 1813: Ended the East India Company's trade monopoly and allowed Christian missionaries to promote moral and religious reforms in India.

questions.question: Which Act was passed by the British Parliament in the year 1773 AD to regulate the activities of the East India Company?
questions.explanation: Regulating Act. This Act was passed in June 1773. It was a response to the East India Company's semi-sovereign status in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa, which was created after the battles of Plassey and Buxar. The act was intended to address the company's administration, but it wasn't a long-term solution. In 1784, the Pitt's India Act was passed as a more radical reform.

questions.question: Which of the following Acts gave the government enormous powers to repress political activities, and allowed detention of political prisoners without trial for two years?
questions.explanation: Rowlatt Act, 1919 : This Act passed on March 10, 1919, was introduced by British colonial authorities to suppress nationalist and revolutionary movements in India. The Act opposed by Mahatma Gandhi. India Contract Act, 1872: Regulates contracts and agreements in India. Criminal Tribes Act, 1871: Targeted "criminal tribes" and was repealed in 1952. Indian Slavery Act, 1843: Abolished slavery in British India.

questions.question: The British Government passed a law in the year 1856. It was meant for which among the following social reforms?

options.b: Abolition of the Practice of Sati
options.c: Abolition of Practice of Child Marriage
options.d: Law against Murdering of Female Child

questions.explanation: Widow Remarriage. The Hindu Widow Remarriage Act of 1856 was enacted with the efforts of Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar. The draft of the Hindu Widows' Remarriage Act, 1856 was prepared by Lord Dalhousie and passed by Lord Canning.

questions.question: Which Act was enacted by the British which regulated the manufacture, sale, possession and transport of firearms?
questions.explanation: Indian Arms Act, 1878. It was enacted under the authority of Lord Lytton, the then Viceroy of India. It prohibited Indians from possessing, producing, or selling firearms without a government license. The Act was discriminatory as it did not apply to British, Anglo-Indians, Europeans, and certain government personnel. Q.590. Warren Hastings became the Governor-General of Bengal from Governor of Bengal after the passing of which of the following Acts ? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift) (a) Charter Act, 1813 (b) Pitt’s India Act, 1784 (c) Indian Council Act of 1861 (d) Regulating Act, 1773 Sol.590.(d) Regulating Act, 1773. The act was the first step taken by the British government to control and regulate the affairs of East India company in India.

questions.question: The Press and Registration of Books (PRB) Act was enacted in which year?
questions.explanation: 1867. The Press and Registration of Books (PRB) Act of 1867 is a law that regulates the printing, publishing, and registration of books and newspapers in India. The Act was passed during the colonial era and was intended to limit free speech by imposing many procedural requirements for publishing.

questions.question: Under the Charter Act of 1833 in British India, the East India Company’s monopoly on trade with which of the following countries was abolished?
questions.explanation: China. Charter Act of 1833: This act marked the end of the company’s commercial operations, transitioning it into an administrative body overseeing British territories in India. This Act made the Governor-General of Bengal as the Governor-General of India. Lord William Bentinck - The first Governor - General of India.

questions.question: In 1883, which of the following allowed Indians to try Europeans in courts of law?
questions.explanation: Ilbert Bill. The Ilbert Bill, introduced by Sir Courtenay Ilbert in 1883, during the viceroyship of Lord Ripon. It sought to empower Indian judges to try British and European citizens in criminal cases. Q.594. By the Act of _________, the Governor General in Council was given the power to legislate for the whole of the British territories in India. Higher Secondary 20/06/2024 (Shift - 2) (a) Charter Act of 1833 (b) Charter Act of 1793 (c) Charter Act of 1853 (d) Charter Act of 1813 Sol.594.(a) Charter Act of 1833. It established the Governor General of Bengal as the Governor General of India, centralizing control over military and civil administration.

questions.question: The Ryotwari system, devised by Thomas Munro, in which peasant cultivators had to pay annual taxes directly to the government, was prevalent in which of the following present-day states/provinces?
questions.explanation: Tamil Nadu. The Ryotwari System (1820) was devised by Captain Alexander Read and Sir Thomas Munro. Under the Ryotwari system, the land revenue was paid by the farmers directly to the state. It was prevalent in most of southern India, first introduced in Tamil Nadu. It was later extended to Maharashtra, Berar, East Punjab, Coorg and Assam. Mahalwari System (1822) was devised by Holt Mackenzie.

questions.question: Match the following Acts/Policies with the respective years in which they were put into place. Acts/Policies Year A. Pitt’s India Act 1. 1784 B. Permanent Settlement of Bengal 2. 1793 C. Introduction of the Subsidiary Alliance System 3. 1798 D. Abolition of Sati 4. 1829
The Provincial elections were held for the first time in _______ under the Government of India Act, 1935.
questions.explanation: 1937, Indian provincial elections: Elections were held in eleven provinces - Madras, Central Provinces, Bihar, Orissa, the United Provinces, the Bombay Presidency, Assam, the North-West Frontier Province, Bengal, Punjab and Sind. The Indian National Congress (INC) won the majority of seats in the provincial elections, and formed governments in seven provinces.

questions.question: Under the Regulating Act of 1773, the King-in-Council created a Supreme Court in which of the following places?
questions.explanation: Calcutta. Regulating Act 1773 - It was passed by the British Parliament to control the territories of the East India Company majorly in Bengal. The act provided for the appointment of a Governor-General along with four Councillors in the Presidency of Fort William (Calcutta), jointly called the Governor-General in Council. As per this, Warren Hastings was appointed as the Governor-General of the Presidency of Fort William (Bengal).

questions.question: When was the Defence of India Act enacted?
questions.explanation: 1915. The Defence of India Act (1915) - It was an emergency law that gave the British government in India wide powers to suppress dissent and maintain public order during World War I. It was passed by the then Governor General of India Lord Hardinge.

questions.question: Which Act declared that British rule in India would end by 30 June 1948?
questions.explanation: Act of 1947. The Indian Independence Act 1947 was an Act of Parliament of the United Kingdom that granted independence to British India. The Act was passed on July 18, 1947, and came into effect on August 15, 1947. The Act divided British India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan.

questions.question: In India which Act divided the powers between the Central and units in terms of three lists?
questions.explanation: 1935. Government of India Act, 1935 : Contain three lists, Federal List (for Centre containing 59 items), Provincial List (for provinces containing 54 items) and the Concurrent List (for both containing 36 items).

questions.question: In which of the following years did the East India Company abolished the diarchy system of Bengal?
questions.explanation: 1772. The system of Dual Government: Introduced in Bengal by Robert Clive of British East India Company. It lasted from 1765 to 1772. Under this system, the administration of Bengal was divided into Nizamat and Diwani. The Diwani was carried out by the company and the Nizamat by the Nizam. Q.603. Ryotwari system of revenue collection in India, introduced by the British, was based on the_______. SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Smith's theory of rent (b) Ricardian theory of rent (c) Malthusian theory of rent (d) Marx's theory of rent Sol.603.(b) Ricardian theory of rent - The land of higher fertility gets higher rent than less fertile land. Ryotwari System - The peasants or cultivators were regarded as the owners of the land. The cultivators had to pay annual taxes directly to the government. Introduced by Thomas Munro and Alexander Read in in the Madras and Bombay presidency.

questions.question: When was the Secretary of State for India made responsible for the Government of British India by bringing about changes in the Home Government?
questions.explanation: 1858. Charter Act 1858 - The term Governor General changed to Viceroy for the British crown. The first viceroy was Lord Canning. The act ended ‘The Doctrine of Lapse’. It ended the Dual government scheme initiated due to Pitt’s India Act. Q.605. In 1942, the British government sent the___________mission to India. SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th shift) (a) Cripps (b) Linlithgow (c) Cabinet (d) Lansdowne Sol.605.(a) Cripps. It was sent to India to secure Indian cooperation for the British war efforts. It was headed by Sir Richard Stafford Cripps. Gandhi called it 'A post-dated cheque drawn on a failing bank'. Q.606. The result of the English Education Act of 1835 was to make ________ as a medium of instruction for ___________ education. SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Morning) (a) vernacular, higher (b) English, primary (c) English, higher (d) vernacular, primary Sol.606.(c) English, Higher. English Education Act (1835) was proposed by William Bentinck on the Advice of Macaulay. Reforms by William Bentick : The abolition of Sati, the suppression of female infanticide and Thuggee, the abolition of lawlessness, and the abolition of human sacrifices.

questions.question: The Charter Act of 1813 extended the East India Company's rule in India to another _________ years.
questions.explanation: 20. The Charter Act of 1813 (The East Indian Company Act 1813) - Features: It ended the monopoly of the East India Company over commercial trade except trade with China and trade in tea with India. Q.608. The objective of Simon Commission was to________. SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Morning) (a) decide India's Political future (b) decide India's Religious future (c) decide India's Educational future (d) decide India's economic future Sol.608.(a) Simon Commission - It was appointed by the British Government in 1927 under the chairmanship of John Simon (other members were Pathick Lawrence and Clement Atlee) to review the workings of Government of India (GOI) Act, 1919 and suggest measures. Q.609. Which act of the British Parliament was also known as East India Company Act 1793? SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Morning) (a) The Government of India Act, 1793 (b) The Charter Act, 1793 (c) The Regulating Act, 1793 (d) The Indian Councils Act, 1793 Sol.609.(b) The Charter Act, 1793. The act was passed by the British Parliament to renew the charter of the East India Company to trade within India for next 20 years. It was passed during the tenure of Sir John Shore (1793 -1798). Q.610. In __________, the British government enacted a legislation banning the use of printed cotton textiles - chintz - in England. Interestingly, this Act was known as the Calico Act. SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (3rd Shift) (a) 1720 (b) 1700 (c) 1740 (d) 1730 Sol.610.(a) 1720. The cotton textiles which the Portuguese took back to Europe, along with the spices, came to be called "calico". Calico Act , Reason - Textile makers in England were Unable to compete with Indian textiles. Highest cotton producing state (Gujarat).

questions.question: In which year was a law passed in India to make conversion to Christianity easier?
questions.explanation: 1850. This law allowed Indians who had converted to Christianity to inherit the property of his ancestors. The Charter Act of 1813 allowed Chirstian missionaries to enter India and Preach Christianity. This Act asserted the Crown's sovereignty over British possessions in India.

questions.question: Which of the following Indian states was the first to sign a subsidiary alliance with the British?
questions.explanation: Hyderabad. In this system, an Indian ruler had to maintain British troops in his state, either by giving some of his territories or by paying for the maintenance of the troops. It was first introduced by the French East India Company Governor Joseph Francois Dupleix, Later used by Lord Wellesley, Governor-General of India (1798 to 1805).

questions.question: What is the original name of the Empress of India Act and when was it instituted?
questions.explanation: The Royal Titles Act 1876 was an Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom which officially recognized Queen Victoria (and subsequent monarchs) as “Empress of India”. This act was introduced by Benjamin Disraeli. It was repealed on 22 June 1948.

questions.question: Which of the following Acts of 1947 regulates the Indian labor law with regard to trade unions as well as individual workmen?
questions.explanation: Industrial disputes Act 1947. The Rowlatt Act 1919 authorized the arrest, for 2 years without trial, of any person suspected of terrorism living in British India. Indian Council acts (1861, 1892, and 1909). Charter Acts (1793, 1813, 1833, and 1853). Q.615. Which Act passed by British Government of India abolished the Council of India? SSC MTS 14/07/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Indian Independence Act of 1947 (b) India Council Act of 1892 (c) Government of India Act of 1935 (d) Charter Act of 1853 Sol.615.(c) Government of India Act were as follows: Abolition of provincial dyarchy and introduction of dyarchy at centre. Abolition of Indian Council and introduction of an advisory body in its place. Provision for an All India Federation with British India territories and princely states.

questions.question: Which Act was passed in 1929 prohibiting marriage of girls below 14 and boys below 18 years of age?
questions.explanation: Sharda act. The act fixed the marriageable age for girls at 14 years and 18 years for boys. It was sponsor by Harbilas Sarda. Pitt’s India act (1784), Rowlatt Act (1919), Vernacular press act (1878).

questions.question: In which year through the Indian Official Secrets Act was freedom of press curbed?
questions.explanation: 1904. It was enacted during the time of Lord Curzon, Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905 curbed the freedom of Press. Later this act was replaced by the Official Secrets act 1923.

questions.question: In 1877, which of the following viceroys organized a durbar to acknowledge Queen Victoria as the Empress of India?
questions.explanation: Lord Lytton organized a durbar to acknowledge Queen Victoria as the Empress of India. This was the culmination of the transfer of control of British India from the East India Company to the Crown.

questions.question: The capital of the British Indian Empire was transferred from Calcutta to Delhi in:
questions.explanation: 1911. The British government believed that ruling India from Delhi was easier and more convenient than from Calcutta. Therefore, Delhi was officially announced as the capital of British Raj by Emperor George V, on December 12, 1911.

questions.question: In 1905, Hindus and Muslims tied ‘Rakhi’ on each other’s hands to show their unity and their protest against the _________.
questions.explanation: Partition of Bengal. Rabindranath Tagore encouraged Hindus and Muslims to tie rakhis as a symbol of unity and resistance against the Partition of Bengal, promoting a beautiful message of harmony and togetherness. Rowlatt Act 1919 was passed to curb the growing nationalist upsurge in British India. The Morley-Minto Reforms, also known as the Indian Councils Act of 1909, were a set of constitutional changes in British India that aimed to increase Indian participation in the legislature. Q.624. What was the Swadeshi Movement called in the state of Andhra Pradesh? SSC MTS 12/09/2023 (1st Shift) (a) Gadar Movement (b) Quit India Movement (c) Khilafat Movement (d) Vande Mataram Movement Sol.624.(d) Vande Mataram Movement. The Swadeshi Movement started in August 1905 from Calcutta Town Hall against Lord Curzon’s decision of dividing the province of Bengal. The partition led to protest meetings in Bengal under which the pledge to boycott foreign goods was first taken. Leaders of the movement - Poona and Bombay (Lokmanya Tilak), Punjab (Lala Lajpat Rai and Ajit Singh), Delhi (Syed Haider Raza), Madras (Chidambaram Pillai).

questions.question: What is the official reason given by Britishers after partition of Bengal in 1905?
questions.explanation: Administrative Convenience. The real reason for the partition was to divide and weaken the growing nationalist movement in Bengal. After Partition Swadeshi movement gained even more momentum, and the British were forced to revoke the partition in 1911.

questions.question: Before the Partition of Bengal in 1905, Bengal was the biggest province of British India. It consisted of parts of which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Bihar and Orissa. Partition of Bengal in {Lord Curzon announced the partition of Bengal on 20th July 1905, reorganization separated the largely Muslim eastern areas from the largely Hindu western areas}.
