questions.question: At which of the following places was the formal proclamation of the Swadeshi movement made on 7 August 1905 ?
questions.explanation: Calcutta Town Hall. The Swadeshi movement was a direct fallout of the decision of the British India government to partition Bengal. The features of the Swadeshi movement : encourage the use of indigenous goods, boycott foreign goods. The partition of Bengal was annulled in 1911 by Lord Hardinge to curb the revolutionaries.

questions.question: Which of the following parties supported the move for partition of Bengal?
questions.explanation: All India Muslim League supported the move for partition of Bengal. Founders of All India Muslim League are Muhammad Ali Jinnah, Aga Khan III, Khwaja Salimullah, Hakim Ajmal Khan, Waqar-ul-Mulk. It was founded on 30 December 1906. Q.629. Moved by the Swadeshi Movement, ______ painted his famous image of Bharat Mata portraying her as an ascetic figure. SSC MTS 05/10/2021(Morning) (a) Satyendranath Tagore (b) Abanindranath Tagore (c) Jyotirindranath Tagore (d) Dwijendranath Tagore Sol.629.(b) Abanindranath Tagore painted his famous image of Bharat Mata portraying her as an ascetic figure in 1905. The painting is depicted as a saffron-clad divine woman, holding a book, sheaves of paddy, a piece of white cloth, and a rosary in her four hands.

questions.question: Which of the following places is related to Gandhi’s Satyagraha of the year 1917?
questions.explanation: Champaran. India's first Civil Disobedience movement, launched by Mahatma Gandhi in 1917, was prompted by Pandit Raj Kumar Shukla, who urged him to address the plight of Indigo History farmers. Mahatma Gandhi organised the Kheda Satyagraha (1918) in Gujarat. Gandhi also led the Ahmedabad Mill Strike (1918) after returning from South Africa. The Bardoli Satyagraha (1928) was led by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel for the farmers of Bardoli.

questions.question: Who was the Viceroy of India when Mahatma Gandhi started Dandi March on 12 March 1930?
questions.explanation: Lord Irwin (1926-1931). Other Events During his tenure: Simon Commission to India (1927); Harcourt Butler Indian States Commission (1927); Nehru Report (1928); Deepavali Declaration (1929); Lahore session of the Congress (Purna Swaraj Resolution) 1929; First Round Table Conference (1930); Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931). Mahatma Gandhi led the Dandi March (Salt March) in 1930, accompanied by a group of 78 followers, as a nonviolent protest against the British salt monopoly. Q.632. In which year was the Gandhi-Irwin Pact signed ? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) 1935 (b) 1929 (c) 1931 (d) 1941 Sol.632.(c) 1931. The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was signed on March 5, 1931, between Mahatma Gandhi and Lord Irwin, the Viceroy of India (1926-1931). The pact ended the Civil Disobedience Movement, initiated by Gandhi with the Salt March, and was signed before the Second Round Table Conference in London. Q.633. In the second Round Table Conference, Mahatma Gandhi represented which of the following parties? SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Communist Party of India (b) Indian National Congress (c) All India Forward Bloc (d) Muslim League Sol.633.(b) Indian National Congress. Mahatma Gandhi attended only the Second Round Table Conference in London in September 1931, presided over by Ramsay MacDonald. The Conference in London was inconclusive, so Gandhiji returned to India and resumed civil disobedience. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and Tej Bahadur Sapru attended all three Round Table Conferences.

questions.question: In which of the following places did Mahatma Gandhi, along with other Indians, establish the Natal Congress to fight against racial discrimination?
questions.explanation: South Africa. The Natal Indian Congress, founded by Mahatma Gandhi in 1894, aimed to combat discrimination against Indians in South Africa. Gandhiji, born on 2 October 1869, returned to India on 9 January 1915. Q.635. Which important event that started in 1930 played a significant role in motivating and mobilizing Indians to join the non - violent movement for independence? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Salt Satyagraha (b) Quit India Movement (c) Gadar Movement (d) Swadeshi movement Sol.635.(a) Salt Satyagraha. The Dandi March, or Salt Satyagraha, was initiated by Mahatma Gandhi from Sabarmati Ashram on March 12, 1930, and lasted until April 5, 1930, reaching Dandi (Navsari district). C. Rajagopalachari organized the Vedaranyam Salt March along the east coast, while Gandhi led the march on the west coast. The protest was against the British salt tax, and Gandhi defied it by collecting natural salt from the shore. In the Salt Satyagraha, Sarojini Naidu persuaded Mahatma Gandhi to allow women to join the movement.

questions.question: Which of the following leaders had gone to Lucknow to invite Mahatma Gandhi to see the plight of the peasants in Champaran?
questions.explanation: Raj Kumar Shukla. The local Congress leaders Brajkishore Prasad and Raj Kumar Shukla first met Mahatma Gandhi at the Lucknow session of the Indian National Congress in 1916 and invited Mahatma Gandhi to have first-hand experience of the plight of Champaran peasants. Gandhi arrived in Champaran on April 15, 1917, to address the grievances of the peasants who were forced to grow indigo under oppressive conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following Pacts succeeded the Communal Award of 1932?
questions.explanation: Gandhi-Ambedkar Pact. The Communal Award was announced by the British Prime Minister, Ramsay MacDonald, on 16 August 1932, based on the report of the Indian Franchise Committee (Lothian Committee). This award accorded separate electorates for Muslims, Europeans, Sikhs, Indian Christians, Anglo-Indians, Depressed classes (78 seats), and even to the Marathas for some seats in Bombay. Gandhi - Ambedkar Pact is also known as the Poona Pact. Madan Mohan Malaviya signed it on behalf of Gandhi. It provided for the Joint electorate, reserved seats (147) for depressed classes and 18% seats reserved for the central legislature.

questions.question: Mahatma Gandhi called a halt to the Non-Cooperation Movement after the Chauri Chaura incident. Where among the following places is Chauri Chaura located?
questions.explanation: Gorakhpur. Chauri Chaura, a town in Uttar Pradesh was the site of a violent clash on February 4, 1922, during the Non-Cooperation Movement. Protestors set a police station on fire, resulting in the deaths of 22 policemen inside. Q.639. The result of which of the following movements/satyagrahas was the abolishment of the Tinkathia System under which the farmers were asked to cultivate indigo in 3/20th of their holdings ? Graduate Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 3) (a) Khilafat Movement (b) Kheda Satyagraha (c) Champaran Satyagraha (d) Ahmedabad Satyagraha Sol.639.(c) Champaran Satyagraha (1917) was Gandhi's first protest in India against forced indigo farming. Brajkishore Prasad and Raj Kumar Shukla first met Mahatma Gandhi at the Lucknow session of the Indian National Congress in 1916 and invited him to have first-hand experience of the plight of Champaran peasants.

questions.question: Which of the following options is not related to the non-cooperation movement started by Mahatma Gandhi?

options.a: Signing of the resolution of Poorna Swaraj in Lahore

questions.explanation: The resolution for Poorna Swaraj (complete independence) was passed at the Lahore session of the Indian National Congress in December 1929, under the leadership of Jawaharlal Nehru. He hoisted the Indian tricolor flag on the banks of the Ravi river. The non-cooperation movement was launched by Mahatma Gandhi in 1920 to persuade Indians to withdraw their cooperation from the British government and advocate for self-governance.

questions.question: Gandhiji gave his slogan of ‘Do or Die’ during which of the following Movements/Satyagrahas?
questions.explanation: The Quit India Movement (also known as the August Movement) was launched by the Indian National Congress on August 8, 1942. Other key movements by Mahatma Gandhi include the Civil Disobedience Movement (1930), the Kheda Satyagraha (1918) in Gujarat, demanding relaxation in revenue collection for peasants, and the Champaran Satyagraha (1917), opposing the Tinkathia system, which forced peasants to grow indigo on 3/20th of their land.

questions.question: Vallabhbhai Patel and ________ helped Gandhi in Kheda by organising his tour of the villages and urging the peasants to stand firm against the government.
questions.explanation: Indulal Yajnik. Mahatma Gandhi returned to India on 9 January 1915.

questions.question: On whose advice did Gandhi spend a year traveling around British India to know the people of India?
questions.explanation: Gopal Krishna Gokhale. He was a mentor to both Mahatma Gandhi and Mohammed Ali Jinnah.

questions.question: In which year was Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi born?
questions.explanation: 1869. Mahatma Gandhi: Born on 2nd October (observed as International Day of Non-violence). He came back to India on 9th January (celebrated as ‘NRI day’ or ‘Pravasi Bhartiya Divas’ since 2003) 1915 from South Africa.

questions.question: Who was the founder of Harijan Sevak Sangh founded in 1932?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi. Organisation Founded by MK Gandhi: Majdoor Mahajan (1916) in Ahmedabad. It was related to the labour movement or textile movement in Gujarat. All-India Spinners Association (1925), All-India Village Industries Association (1934). Q.646. The famous scientist, Albert Einstein was inspired by whose idea on non-violence? SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (4th shift) (a) Mahatma Gandhi (b) Vardhaman Mahavira (c) Gautam Buddha (d) B.R. Ambedkar Sol.646.(a) Mahatma Gandhi. His Ideas - Truth and nonviolence, Satyagraha, Sarvodaya (Progress of All), Swaraj (self-rule), Trusteeship (Wealthy people to look after the welfare of the people). Q.647. Who among the following returned his/her medal of Kaisar-i-Hind in 1920 ? Higher Secondary 27/06/2023 ( Shift - 3) (a) S Subramania iyer (b) Sarojini Naidu (c) Rabindranath Tagore (d) Mahatma Gandhi Sol.647.(d) Mahatma Gandhi. Kaiser - e - Hind title was given to Mahatma Gandhi by Governor-General of India Lord Hardinge in 1915 for his services during the Boer War (1899 - 1902). Gandhi returned his title in response to the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (13th April 1919). Rabindranath Tagore returned his Knighthood title in response to the massacre. Q.648. In 1918, Mahatma Gandhi successfully led a strike of ________. SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening) (a) Army Soldiers (b) Dalits (c) Mill workers (d) Traders Sol.648.(c) Mill workers. Ahmedabad Mill Strike (1918) - This is considered the first hunger strike led by Gandhi. Q.649. In Kheda, Gujarat, Patidar peasants organised non-violent campaigns against which of the following demand of the British? SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (2nd Shift) (a) Low labour rates (b) Long working hours (c) High land revenue (d) Low price for crops Sol.649.(c) High land revenue. Kheda Satyagraha of 1918 was a satyagraha movement in the Kheda district of Gujarat in India organized by Mahatma Gandhi during the period of the British Raj. The peasant-Patidar community of Kheda, who refused to accept a 23 percent tax increase imposed on them despite a devastating crop failure and an outbreak of plague and cholera, served as the focal point of this satyagraha.

questions.question: When did depressed classes get the reserved seats in provincial and central legislative councils, but they were to be voted in by the General electorate?
questions.explanation: September 1932. Poona Pact - Agreement between Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B. R. Ambedkar - Seats reserved for the depressed classes were increased from 71 to 147 in provincial legislatures and 18 percent of the total in the Central Legislature.

questions.question: Gandhiji, aged ______, arrived in India in 1915 from South Africa.
questions.explanation: 46. Gandhiji (born on 2nd October 1869 in Porbandar, Gujarat) went to South Africa in 1893 as a lawyer, settling first in Durban before moving to Johannesburg.

questions.question: Which of the following Indian freedom fighter said that "Be the change you wish to see in the world" ?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi. His other Famous Quotes: “A man is but the product of his thoughts. What he thinks, he becomes.”, “Nobody can hurt me without my permission.” Q.653. In which of the following years, did Subhas Chandra Bose refer to Mahatma Gandhi as the “Father of the Nation”? SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift) (a) 1942 (b) 1944 (c) 1939 (d) 1941 Sol.653.(b) 1944. Subhas Chandra Bose called Mahatma Gandhi the ‘Father of the Nation’ in a radio address from Singapore on 6 July 1944.

questions.question: The All-India Khilafat Conference in November 1919 took place at:
questions.explanation: Delhi. In early 1919, the All India Khilafat Committee was formed under the leadership of the Ali brothers (Maulana Muhammad Ali and Shaukat Ali), Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Ajmal Khan and Hasrat Mohani, to force the British Government to change its attitude to Turkey.

questions.question: Who among the following called Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose a patriot of patriots?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi. Rabindranath Tagore called Subhash Chandra Bose a 'Desh Nayak'. The famous slogan given by Subhas Chandra Bose: “Dilli Chalo, Jai Hind”, "Give me blood, I will give freedom". Subhas Chandra Bose Autobiography: “The Indian Struggle”.

questions.question: Which of the following events occurred as an after-effect of the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre (13th April 1919) ?

options.a: Hunger strike to settle disputes between the mill owners and the workers
options.b: Individual princes could sign a separate agreement with the British
options.c: Hunter Commission was appointed by the British Government
options.d: Popularisation of Charkha and Khadi and Jail Bharo by Congress volunteers.

questions.explanation: The Hunter Commission came to India in under the leadership of William Hunter to investigate the Jallianwala Bagh massacre. Another Hunter Commission was on Indian Education, prepared in 1882 by William Wilson Hunter.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a reason for slowing down the Non-cooperation Movement?

options.a: Due to the absence of alternative Indian institution, boycott of British Institutions posed a problem.
options.b: Leaders of the movement shifted their focus towards domestic work thus created a void.
options.c: Many lawyers resigned but then absence of income for a longer period of time compelled them to rejoin.
options.d: Khadi cloth was often more expensive than mass-produced mill cloth and poor people could not afford to buy it.

questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi started the Non- Cooperation Movement on September 1920. Lord Chelmsford was the viceroy of British India during the Non-Cooperation Movement. The Chauri -Chaura incident was the driver of subsequent withdrawal of the Non -Cooperation Movement.

questions.question: In which of the following years was the civil disobedience campaign completely Ceased ?
questions.explanation: 1934. It began with the famous Dandi March of Gandhiji, on 12 March 1930. Q.659. Who among the following freedom fighters hoisted the Indian flag at the Gowalia Tank Maidan in Mumbai during the Quit India Movement ? SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Afternoon) (a) Aruna Asaf Ali (b) Sarojini Naidu (c) Tara Rani Srivastava (d) Matangini Hazra Sol.659.(a) Aruna Asaf Ali. Aruna Asaf Ali popularly known as the 'Grand Old Lady' of the Independence Movement.

questions.question: Who among the following was the only martyr of the Quit India phase of the freedom movement who was hanged ?
questions.explanation: Kushal Konwar. Facts of Quit India Movement - The Quit India Resolution was passed by the Congress Working Committee on 8 August 1942 in Bombay. ‘Quit India’ or ‘Bharat Chodo 'slogan was given in this movement . Gandhiji gave the slogan to the people – ‘Do or die’; It is also known as the India August Movement or August Kranti.

questions.question: Which Newspaper was founded by Mahatma Gandhi in South Africa in 1903?
questions.explanation: Indian Opinion. The Indian Opinion was an important newspaper established in in Durban, South Africa, by Mahatma Gandhi and M. H. Nazar. It was a primary communication organ of the Natal Indian Congress.

questions.question: C Rajagopalachari led the Salt Satyagraha in which of the following states ?
questions.explanation: Tamil Nadu. Salt March (Dandi Satyagraha, 12th March 1930 to 6th April, 1930 ) was an act of nonviolent civil disobedience led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi. Other leaders - K. Kelappan (Malabar), Gopabandhu Chaudhary (Orissa). Expansion of British Rule Q.663. Which of the following personalities had the key role in fighting against the British East India Company in the Battle of Porto Novo? SSC MTS 28/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Hyder Ali (b) Maharaja Ranjit Singh (c) Alamgir-II (d) Gopala Nayaker Sol.663.(a) Hyder Ali. The Battle of Porto Novo (1781) was fought between Hyder Ali and the East India Company (EIC), led by Sir Eyre Coote. Hyder Ali was a key figure in the Anglo-Mysore Wars. The First Anglo-Mysore War (1767–1769) was fought between Hyder Ali and the EIC. The Second Anglo-Mysore War (1780–1784) also saw Hyder Ali leading the Mysore forces; however, he died during the conflict, after which his son, Tipu Sultan, continued the war.

questions.question: Tirot Sing was the leader of which of the following revolts?
questions.explanation: Khasi uprising. Tirot Sing, also known as U Tirot Sing Syiem, was a Khasi chief in the early 19th century. The Khasi uprising (Anglo-Khasi War) was a conflict between the Khasi people and the British Empire that took place from 1829 to 1833. The Sanyasi Uprisings took place in Bengal between the periods of 1770- 1820s. Poligar Revolt fought between the British and the Poligars, feudal lords in southern India. The Singpho Rebellion of 1830 took place in Assam. Q.675. The planned large-scale disruption of rail communications and the seizure of arms in Bengal were undertaken under the leadership of _____. SSC MTS 13/11/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Aurobindo Ghose (b) Surendranath Banerjee (c) Chittaranjan Das (d) Jatin Mukherjee Sol.675.(d) Jatin Mukherjee, also known as Bagha Jatin, was a prominent revolutionary leader in Bengal during the early 20th century who fought against British colonial rule. He was a key member of the Anushilan Samiti, a revolutionary organization that planned History large-scale armed resistance against the British.

questions.question: Under the leadership of which of the following revolutionaries was the Chittagong Armoury Raid conducted?
questions.explanation: Surya Sen is also known as Master Da. He founded The Indian Republican Army. The Chittagong Armoury Raid took place on April 18, 1930, in Chittagong (now in Bangladesh). Ras Bihari Bose was the founder of the 'Indian Independence League’. He chaired the Indian Independence League in 1942 to formally launch the Indian National Army.

questions.question: Sido and Kanhu were leaders of which of the following tribal rebellions?
questions.explanation: Santhal Rebellion (Hul revolt) began in 1855, led by Sidhu, Kanhu, Chand, Bhairav, and their sisters Phulo and Jhano. The Malabar rebellion (Moplah rebellion) was an armed uprising by the Mappila Muslims of Kerala in 1921. The Kol rebellion (1829-39) was led by Buddhu Bhagat, Madara Mahato, and Joa Bhagat in the Chota Nagpur region. The Munda Rebellion, led by Birsa Munda, took place in the Ranchi area in 1899-1900.

questions.question: In which of the following years was VD Savarkar sent to Andaman Jail by the British?
questions.explanation: 1911. Vinayak Damodar Savarkar was sent to the Cellular Jail on the punishment of 'Kala Pani’ under the Nashik Conspiracy Case for the murder of the Collector of Nashik District, Jackson. While serving his sentence in the Cellular Jail, he wrote the epic 'Kamala' on the prison walls.

questions.question: In 1910, The United India House at Seattle, USA, was set up by _________.

options.b: Tarak Nath Das and GD Kumar

questions.explanation: Tarak Nath Das and GD Kumar. They were Indian revolutionaries who collaborated to promote Indian independence from British rule. Shyamji Krishna Varma founded the Indian Home Rule Society, India House, and The Indian Sociologist in London. Vinayak Damodar Savarkar and his brother Ganesh Damodar Savarkar established the Abhinav Bharat Society, also known as the Young India Society, in 1904. Q.680. Which of the following groups/parties was started in San Francisco, United States of America during the Indian National Movement? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (b) Swaraj Party (c) Khilafat Committee (d) Ghadar Party Sol.680.(d) Ghadar Party : Founded in 1913 in the U.S. as the Hindi Association of the Pacific Coast, it aimed to free India from British rule. It was founded by Sohan Singh Bhakna and Lala Har Dayal.

questions.question: Bankim Chandra Chatterjee wrote a novel Anand Math based on which of the following rebellions/revolts?
questions.explanation: Sanyasi Rebellion. The Sanyasi Uprisings took place in Bengal between the periods of 1770- 1820s. The Sanyasis rose in rebellion after the great famine of 1770 in Bengal which caused acute chaos and misery. However, the immediate cause of the rebellion was the restrictions imposed by the British upon pilgrims visiting holy places among both Hindus and Muslims. The national song of India, 'Vande Mataram’, is an excerpt taken from the novel Anand Math written by Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay. Q.682. Who founded the Bombay Presidency Association in 1885 along with Pherozeshah Mehta and KT Telang? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (2nd shift) (a) AK Fazlul Haq (b) Badruddin Tyabji (c) Behramji M Malabari (d) Zakir Husain Sol.682.(b) Badruddin Tyabji was the third President (in 1887) of the Indian National Congress and the first Muslim to hold that position. Other Political organisations and founder: London Indian Society (1865) - Dadabhai Naoroji. East India Association (1866) - Dadabhai Naoroji. Poona Sarvajanik Sabha (1870) - G.V. Joshi, S.H. Sathe, S.H. Chiplonkar and Mahadev Govind Ranade. Q.683. What was the name of the campaign led by the Ali brothers and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad to save the Ottoman Caliphate as a symbol of unity among the Muslim community? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Faraizi Movement (b) Ahmadiya Movement (c) Wahabi Movement (d) Khilafat Movement Sol.683.(d) Khilafat Movement. It was a political campaign that took place from 1919 to 1922 in British India. It was a protest against the British government's policies towards Turkey and the planned dismantling of the Ottoman Empire after World War I. The Faraizi movement was started by Haji Shariatullah in 1818. The Ahmadiyya movement was founded by Mirza Ghulam Ahmad in 1889. Syed Ahmed Barelvi started the Wahabi Movement in the 1820s. Q.684. Who was executed as an accomplice to the murder of AMT Jackson ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift) (a) Krishnaji Gopal Karve (b) Matangini Hazra (c) Khudiram Bose (d) Hemu Kalani Sol.684.(a) Krishnaji Gopal Karve. Jackson murder case also known as Nasik Conspiracy (Year 1909). Anant Laxman Kanhere shot Jackson, the Collector of Nashik, at Vijayanand theatre. Kanhere was a member of the Abhinav Bharat society. The event led to the arrest of Savarkar. Abhinav Bharat Society was a secret society founded by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar and his brother Ganesh Damodar Savarkar in 1904. Q.685. Which of the following revolutionists was associated with the Anushilan Samiti? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Rajguru (b) Bhagat Singh (c) Jatindra Mohan Sengupta (d) Sukhdev Sol.685.(c) Jatindra Mohan Sengupta. Anushilan Samiti was founded by Satish Chandra Bose and Barrister Praanath Mitra. Bhagat Singh, Rajguru, and Sukhdev were members of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA), involved in the Lahore Conspiracy Case of 1929.

questions.question: Where of the following was Bal Gangadhar Tilak’s Home Rule Movement active?
questions.explanation: Maharashtra. Bal Gangadhar Tilak launched his Home Rule Movement in 1916. It was primarily centered in Maharashtra, which was his home base. He had significant influence and following in this region. He published his ideas through his newspapers "Kesari" (in Marathi) and "Mahratta" (in English) from Maharashtra. Q.716. Which of the following organisations, divided into two branches, was established by Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak and Annie Besant? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Indian Association (b) Theosophical society (c) East Indian Association (d) Home Rule League Sol.716.(d) Home Rule League. In April 1916, Tilak founded the Indian Home Rule League, with its headquarters in Poona. The league's first meeting was held in Belgaum. In September 1916, Annie Besant founded the All-India Home Rule League, based in Madras. Organizations and their founders : Indian Association - Surendranath Banerjee and Ananda Mohan Bose; Theosophical Society - Helena Blavatsky, Henry Steel Olcott, William Quan Judge.

questions.question: Which of the following events took place in the United Provinces in February, 1922?
questions.explanation: Chauri Chaura Incident took place at Chauri Chaura in the Gorakhpur district of United Provinces (now Uttar Pradesh) in British India. The police there fired upon a large group of protesters participating in the non-cooperation movement. In retaliation, the demonstrators attacked and set fire to a police station, killing all of its occupants. The incident led to the deaths of three civilians and 22 policemen. Mahatma Gandhi halted the non-cooperation movement on 12th February 1922 after the Chauri Chaura incident.

questions.question: Indian National Army was formed in which of the following countries?
questions.explanation: Singapore. The Indian National Army (INA), also known as the Azad Hind Fauj, was a collaborationist armed unit of Indian supporters that fought under the command of the Japanese Empire. It was founded by Mohan Singh in September 1942 during World War II.

questions.question: Being the President of the Indian National Congress, who among the following had called for complete independence from the British Raj in 1929?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru. He was an Indian freedom fighter who later became the first Prime Minister of India. In December 1929, he was chosen as the President of the Indian National Congress during its annual session in History Lahore. At this event, he raised the tricolour flag on the banks of the Ravi River.

questions.question: On 31 October 1940, who among the following was arrested for offering individual Satyagraha to protest against India’s forced participation in the Second World War ?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru. On 31 October 1940, Jawaharlal Nehru was arrested for participating in individual Satyagraha, protesting against India’s forced involvement in the Second World War. During this period, Nehru also engaged in limited Civil Disobedience and spent approximately nine years in jail between 1921 and 1945.

questions.question: Who among the following was primarily an integral part of the Indian National Army (INA)?
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandra Bose. Indian National Army (INA) was a collaborationist armed unit of Indian collaborators that fought under the command of the Japanese Empire. It was founded by Mohan Singh in September in Southeast Asia during World War II. Some notable people associated: Mohan Singh, Habib ur Rahman, Lt. Col Hori Lal Verma.

questions.question: What is the name of the famous British social reformer known for founding the Indian Home Rule League in 1916 ?
questions.explanation: Annie Besant. Annie Besant, an Irish theosophist, started the Home Rule movement in India in 1916, demanding self-government similar to the Irish Home Rule League. She founded the Home Rule League in Madras in September 1916 and established over 200 branches across India. Q.723. Who among the following personalities renounced his knighthood after the Jallianwala Bagh massacre? Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) Syed Ahmed Khan (b) CV Raman (c) Rabindranath Tagore (d) JC Bose Sol.723.(c) Rabindranath Tagore. The Jallianwala Bagh massacre occurred on April 13, 1919, when British troops, led by General Dyer, fired on a peaceful crowd in Amritsar, killing hundreds. In protest, Mahatma Gandhi returned the Kaiser-i-Hind title in 1920. The Hunter Commission was set up in 1919 to investigate the incident.

questions.question: Who among the following was one of the founders of the Swaraj Party?
questions.explanation: Chittaranjan Das. The Swaraj Party, initially called the Congress Khilafat Swaraj Party, was established in 1923 by Chittaranjan Das and Motilal Nehru. This formation took place after the Gaya Annual Conference of the Indian National Congress in December 1922. Other important organizations and their founders: Indian National Congress (1885): Founded by A.O. Hume. All India Kisan Sabha (1936): Sahajanand Saraswati. Azad Hind Fauj (1943): Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose. Q.725. Which of the following Satyagrahas was started by Dr B R Ambedkar in 1927? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Nasik Temple Satyagraha (b) Dharasana Satyagraha (c) Mulshi Satyagraha (d) Mahad Satyagraha Sol.725.(d) Mahad Satyagraha: It is also known as the Chavdar Tank Satyagraha, begun in Mahad (Raigad), Maharashtra. It centered around the Chavdar Tank, a public water source that was reserved exclusively for upper castes.

questions.question: Who among the following leaders founded the women's wing of Congress in 1940 ?
questions.explanation: Sucheta Kriplani (First female Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh from - 67). She sang Vande Mataram on 14th August 1947 in the opening session of Parliament.

questions.question: On 15 August 1947, the first prime minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru, raised the Indian National Flag above the __________ of Red Fort in Delhi.
questions.explanation: Lahori Gate. The National Flag of India was adopted on 22 July 1947, Designed by Pingali Venkayya. Q.728. Who moved the resolution proposing that the National Flag of India be a 'horizontal tricolor of saffron, white and dark green in equal proportion '? SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (1st Shift) (a) Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel (b) Jawaharlal Nehru (c) Mahatma Gandhi (d) Dr Rajendra Prasad Sol.728.(b) Jawaharlal Nehru. The Tricolour was adopted as our national flag at a Congress Committee meeting in Karachi in 1931.

questions.question: Who among the following was the founder of 'Tiger Legion' or 'Free India Legion'?
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandra Bose - founder of 'Azad Hind Fauj'. 'Tiger Legion' was formed in 1941 with the help of the German Government to fight against the British.

questions.question: The authorities of which country denied permission to land the ship Komagata Maru, carrying Indians?
questions.explanation: Canada. The Komagata Maru was a coal-transport steamship that had been converted into a passenger ship by Hong Kong-based businessman Gurdit Singh. It set off from Hong Kong in April 1914, reaching Vancouver’s harbour a month later with 376 people on board, most of them Sikhs. The steamship eventually ended up back in India on 29th Sep 1914 at Budge Budge, Calcutta.

questions.question: The origin of Directive Principles of State Policy can be traced to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Karachi Resolution (1931). The Karachi Session of Congress in 1931 was presided by Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel. Gandhi Irwin Pact - 5 March 1931. It marked the end of civil disobedience. Q.732. Who among the following freedom fighters was one of the founders of the Fergusson College in Pune in 1885 ? SSC MTS 10/05/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Subhash Chandra Bose (b) Bal Gangadhar Tilak (c) Sardar Vallabh Bhai Patel (d) Lala Lajpat Rai Sol.732.(b) Bal Gangadhar Tilak. Other Co-founding members of Fergusson College :- Vaman Shriram Apte, Vishnushashtri Chiplunkar, Mahadeo Ballal Namjoshi and Gopal Krishna Agarkar.

questions.question: Motilal Nehru, C.R. Das gave up their legal practices during which Movement ?
questions.explanation: Non-Cooperation Movement (1920 - 1922). It was organized by Mahatma Gandhi to obtain self governance. Many lawyers gave up their practices such as Motilal Nehru, C.Rajagopalachari, Saifuddin Kitchlew, Vallabhbhai Patel, Asaf Ali, T. Prakasam and Rajendra Prasad.

questions.question: When was Alluri Sitarama Raju arrested ending a two-year armed tribal struggle?
questions.explanation: May 1924. He was publicly executed in Koyyuru on May 7 after being tied to a tree and shot. His final resting place (tomb) is at Krishna Devi Peta, 111 km from Visakhapatnam. In August 1922, he launched the Rampa Rebellion (Manyam Rebellion) against the British. During this rebellion, he was helped by Bobbili Dora. The Prime Minister has unveiled a bronze statue of Alluri Sitharama Raju in Andhra Pradesh to celebrate 125th birth anniversary on 4th July 2022.

questions.question: In which year, the Koya rebellion took place in the eastern Godavari tract?
questions.explanation: 1879-1880. The Koya Revolts rose under Tomma Sora during 1879-80. Other important revolts are Kol Mutiny (1831), Ho and Munda Uprisings (1820-1837), The Santhal Rebellion (1855-56), Ramosi Uprising (1822- 1829), etc.

questions.question: In which of the following regions did Baba Ramchandra mainly lead the peasant struggle during colonial rule?
questions.explanation: Awadh. He led a peasant movement in Awadh against Talukdars and Landlords.

questions.question: At which of the following places did C. Rajagopalachari break the salt law in the year 1930 ?
questions.explanation: Vedaranyam. C. Rajagopalachari broke the salt law in 1930 at Vedaranyam, a small coastal town in the then Tanjore District. The first Indian governor of free India was C. Rajagopalachari. Q.738. What was the name of the women's regiment in the Indian National Army founded by Subhash Chandra Bose? SSC CGL 18/08/2021(Evening) (a) Rani of Jhansi Regiment (b) Rani Ahilyabai Regiment (c) Rani Padmawati Regiment (d) Rani of Didda Regiment Sol.738.(a) Rani of Jhansi Regiment. Q.739. Which maharaja of Manipur signed the Instrument of Accession with the Government of India? SSC CHSL 05/08/2021 (Afternoon) (a) Kulachandra Singh (b) Bodhchandra Singh (c) Nara Singh (d) Gambhir Singh Sol.739.(b) Bodhchandra Singh, signed the Instrument of Accession on August 1947, with the assurance of Manipur's internal autonomy. This agreement marked Manipur's entry into the Union of India, though full integration followed with the Manipur Merger Agreement in 1949.

questions.question: Who among the following was one of the founders of the Congress Socialist Party?
questions.explanation: Ram Manohar Lohia. Congress Socialist Party (Socialist caucus within the Indian National Congress) - Founded in 1934. Other founders - Jayaprakash Narayan and Acharya Narendra Dev.

questions.question: In which city was the Jhanda Satyagraha or Flag Satyagraha of 1923 held?
questions.explanation: Nagpur. Flag Satyagraha is a part of civil disobedience during the Indian independence movement. Q.742._______was executed at Lahore in November 1915 for his role in the Ghadar Conspiracy in February 1915. SSC CGL 09/03/2020 (Evening) (a) Kartar Singh Sarabha (b) Tantia Mama (c) Maganbhai Patel (d) Vijay Singh Pathik Sol.742.(a) Kartar Singh Sarabha. Ghadar Conspiracy (1915) - Plan to initiate a pan-India mutiny in the British Indian Army during World War by the Ghadar Party (United States), the Berlin Committee (Germany), the Indian revolutionary underground in British India and the German Foreign Office. Socio Religious Reforms Q.743. Consider the following statements with regard to Satnami Movement of Central India. a) The movement was founded by Ghasidas. b) The movement was to improve the condition of leather workers. Which of the above statements is/are correct? SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Afternoon) (a) Only a (b) Both a and b (c) Neither a or b (d) Only b Sol.743.(b) Both a and b. Guru Ghasidas, a 19th-century advocate of the Satnami sect, founded the Satnami community in Chhattisgarh, promoting Satnam (truth) and equality. His teachings share similarities with Hinduism and Buddhism. The Satnami movement was led by non-Brahman leaders who worked to empower marginalized communities.

questions.question: Who among the following was the President of the Belgaum Session of the Indian National Congress held in 1924?
questions.explanation: Mahatma Gandhi. The 39th session of INC at Belgaum was held on December 26, 1924. INC Sessions: Bombay, 1885 (W.C. Banerjee) - First session; Madras, (Badruddin Tayabji) - First Muslim President; Allahabad, 1888 (George Yule) - First English President; Lahore, (Jawaharlal Nehru); Haripura, (Subhas Chandra Bose) - Bose’s first term as President.

questions.question: Where was the 1912 session of the India National Congress held in Bihar?
questions.explanation: Bankipore. The 27th session of the Indian National Congress in 1912 was presided over by Raghunath Narasinha Mudholkar. In December 1922, the session was held in Gaya under Chittaranjan Das, while the 53rd session took place in 1940 at Ramgarh, near Ranchi, led by Maulana Abul Kalam Azad. Q.819. Who amongst the following became the president of the second session of the Indian National Congress held in Calcutta in December 1886 ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift) (a) P Ananda Charlu (b) Badruddin Tyabji (c) Dadabhai Nauroji (d) William Wedderburn Sol.819.(c) Dadabhai Nauroji. The first session of the Indian National Congress was held in Bombay in December 1885 with seventy-two delegates. W.C. Banerjee served as its first president, while A.O. Hume took office as the General Secretary. Dadabhai Naoroji also presided over the 9th session in 1893 (Lahore), and the 22nd session in 1906 (Calcutta).

questions.question: The Indian National Congress formally took up the Swadeshi call in its Benaras session of 1905 under the presidentship of _________.
questions.explanation: Gopal Krishna Gokhale. INC Sessions and its President : First Session (Bombay in 1885) - W.C. Bannerjee, Second Session (Calcutta in 1886) - Dadabhai Naoroji, 1919 (Amritsar) and 1928 (Calcutta) - Motilal Nehru, 1929 (Lahore) - Jawaharlal Nehru, (Bombay) - Rajendra Prasad.

questions.question: The Quit India Resolution was ratified in the_________ session of Indian National Congress to launch the movement.
questions.explanation: Bombay session. This session took place at the Gowalia Tank Maidan (August Kranti Maidan), on August 8, 1942, where Mahatma Gandhi gave his famous "Do or Die" speech. The resolution was moved by Jawaharlal Nehru.

questions.question: In which of the following places the Indian National Congress passed the resolution of Purna Swaraj?
questions.explanation: Lahore. On 19 December 1929, the Indian National Congress passed the historic ‘Poorna Swaraj’ (total independence) resolution at its Lahore session, with Jawaharlal Nehru elected as its President. A public declaration was made on 26 January 1930, a day the Congress urged Indians to celebrate as ‘Independence Day.’

questions.question: __________ was elected as the president of the third session of Indian National Congress
questions.explanation: Badruddin Tyabji. Wyomesh Chandra Banerjee was the first president, presiding over the inaugural session in 1885, while Annie Besant became the first woman to hold the position in 1917. History Q.824. All India Kisan Sabha was founded in at Indian National Congress (INC) ________ Session as All India Kisan Congress. Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 1) (a) Lucknow (b) Agra (c) Bombay (d) Delhi Sol.824.(a) Lucknow. Swami Sahajananda Saraswati, who founded the Bihar Provincial Kisan Sabha in 1929, also led the formation of the All India Kisan Sabha (AIKS) during the Indian National Congress' Lucknow Session in 1936. The AIKS, also known as the Akhil Bharatiya Kisan Sabha. Q.825. Indian National Congress celebrated the first Independence Day in Colonial India on _____________ . SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon) (a) 2 October 1929 (b) 29 December 1929 (c) 15 August 1930 (d) 26 January 1930 Sol.825.(d) 26 January 1930. The Indian National Congress passed 'Complete Swaraj' in its Lahore session on 19 December 1929. The president of this session was Jawaharlal Nehru. Q.826. Who led the Indian National Congress at its first annual session? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Surendra Nath Banerjee (b) Dadabhai Naoroji (c) WC Banerjee (d) AO Hume Sol.826.(c) WC Banerjee. Important Congress sessions: First Session - held at Bombay in 1885. Second Session - held at Calcutta in 1886, President - Dadabhai Naoroji. Third Session - held at Madras in 1887, President - Syed Badruddin Tyabji (first muslim President). Fourth Session - held at Allahabad in 1888, President - George Yule (first English President). session (Calcutta) President - Rahimtullah Sayani, National Song ‘Vande Mataram’ sung for the first time by Rabindranath Tagore. Q.827. Who was the first Woman President of Indian National Congress? SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (2nd Shift) (a) Sarojini Naidu (b) Asaf Ali (c) Annie Besant (d) Usha Mehta Sol.827.(c) Annie Besant : First woman who presided over the Calcutta session (1917) of Indian National Congress. Sarojini Naidu - First Indian women president of Indian national congress (1925, Kanpur session) and the first woman Governor of the United Provinces in 1947.

questions.question: Which flag of the Indian National Congress was adopted in 1931?

options.a: A two colour flag with charkha made by cloth
options.b: A tricolour flag made by Khadi with a Charkha symbol
options.c: One colour flag with charkha symbol
options.d: A blue colour flag made by cloth

questions.explanation: Ad - Hoc Flag Committee : Formed in 1947 under Rajendra Prasad. Pingali Venkayya - Designer of National Flag of India (1921). The national flag was adopted on July 22, 1947. Ratio of the length to the breadth of the Indian Flag - 3:2. The national flag of India was first hoisted on 7th August, 1906 in Kolkata at the Parsee Bagan Square (Green Park). The first Indian flag was hoisted on a foreign land by Madame Bhikaji Cama (1907 - Germany).

questions.question: In the 1939 Tripuri Congress Presidential Election, Pattabhi Sitaramayya was defeated by:
questions.explanation: Subhas Chandra Bose was elected as President of the Haripura Congress Session in 1938. He resigned as congress president in April 1939. Dr. Rajendra Prasad replaced Subhas Chandra Bose as the new congress president.

questions.question: The second annual session of Indian National Congress was held at which of the following places ?
questions.explanation: Calcutta (1886, Dada Bhai Naoroji).

questions.question: Self-Government or 'Swaraj' as the ultimate goal of the Indian National Congress-this declaration was made by Dadabhai Naoroji in which of the following sessions of the INC ?
questions.explanation: Calcutta. Dadabhai Naoroji (Grand Old Man of India) founded the Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha in 1851 to revive the Zoroastrian religion and formed the London India Society in 1865. He became a member of the Legislative Council of Mumbai during 1885-88 and President of the Congress Party in 1886 (Calcutta), (Lahore) and (Calcutta).

questions.question: Which Session of Congress and Muslim League reached an understanding of creating a joint front against the British regime?
questions.explanation: Lucknow (1916) - President: A.C. Majumdar; Lucknow Pact signed between Congress (Bal Gangadhar Tilak) and Muslim League (Muhammad Ali Jinnah) to build political consensus; Unity between two factions - Moderates and Extremists of Congress. Q.833. Which among the following sessions of Indian National Congress was the first session to be presided by a lady ? SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Afternoon) (a) Calcutta - 1917 (b) Kanpur - 1925 (c) Lahore - 1929 (d) Surat - 1907 Sol.833.(a) Calcutta - (Annie Besant, 1917).

questions.question: In _________ at its Madras session, the Indian National Congress set up an All Parties Conference to draft a Constitution for India.
questions.explanation: 1927. Indian National Congress (INC) session 1927 (Madras): President - M A Ansari. INC session 1915 (Bombay): President - Satyendra Prasanna Sinha. Importance - Constitution of the Congress was altered to admit the delegates from the extremist section. INC session 1922 (Gaya): President - C R Das. Importance - CR Das and other leaders broke away from INC, Formation of Swaraj Party. INC session 1932 (Delhi): President - Amrit Ranchhorddas Seth. Q.835. The split in Indian National Congress occurred in ________ . SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Evening) (a) 1901 (b) 1905 (c) 1903 (d) 1907 Sol.835.(d) 1907. The Surat Split was the splitting of Indian National Congress into two groups - Moderates and Radicals.
